Ottawa, March 12, 1945.

Mr. J. L. Bryant, Indian Agent, Kamsack, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, the admission of Gerald A. Ironstand to the Pine Creek Residential School is approved.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

February 28, 1945.

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Pine Creek Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child:
English name: Marie Louise Bone (Anitein)
Age: 13
Name of Band: Pine Creek
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: 99
Father's full name and No.: Peter Bone (99 Clement Anitein, Step-Father)
Mother's full name and No.: 99 Maguerite Paul.
Parents living or dead: Father Dead, mother living married to Clement Anitein.
State of child's health: Good
Religion: R.C.
Does applicant speak English?: yes
Previously attended: no, school for years

(Signature of father)
(Step-father)

Note—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

Note—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

March 24, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to enclose herewith, application for the admission of Marie Louise Bone, to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

The girl is non-treaty. Her mother is married to Clement Ahneeohin, No. 99 Pine Creek Band and is therefore his step-daughter. He would be responsible for the welfare of the girl and makes application to have her admitted to the residential school.

I beg to recommend that application be approved.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 28, 1945.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant, the Department approves the admission of Marie Louise Bone to the Pine Creek Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, April 20, 1948.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

With reference to the March Quarterly Return of the Pine Creek Residential School, the Department approves the admission of the following:

Gilbert Gabriel,
Nelson Gabriel.

The following pupils have been absent from the school for over a year:

| No. | No. |
|-----|-----|
| 218 | 241 |
| 231 | 247 |
| 259 | 261 |

If they do not return in the next month or so, application should be made for their discharge in order that their names should be removed from the Quarterly return. If, at any time in the future they wish to return application can be made for their return.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, July 16, 1945.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

With reference to the June quarter return of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, the admission of Andrew Neapew and Alexandre Nepinak is approved.

The Department also approves the discharge of pupils numbered as follows:

Nos. 258; 259; 271; 274; 0238; 208; 218; 251; 239; 241 and 247.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

September 17, 1945.

I beg to enclose herewith an application with respect to Paul James Catcheway, No. 151 Pine Creek Band. The boy is deaf and dumb and is not suitable for admission to the Pine Creek Residential School. The Reverend Principal suggests that the boy be placed in a proper institution where he could learn something that would be useful to him in after school years. There is no institution of this kind in Manitoba at the present time, although I believe there is a school in Saskatchewan.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

DIVISION FILE NO.: 127436
DIVISION: Dauphin
SUB-DIVISION: Roblin
PROVINCE: Manitoba

DATE: October 19th, 1945

Graham RAZOR and William MINTUCK - Valley River Indian Reserve,
Timberlea, Man.
Run-away Boys from Indian School at Camperville, Manitoba.

Reference above, I have to report that on the 17th inst., a phone call was received at this office from Father RUST - Principal of the School for Indians at Camperville, Man., advising that the two captioned noted Indian boys had run away from the school on the 10th inst., and as their homes were at Timberlea, Man., probably they would head for there. Father RUST requested that should they be located to hold them and notify him immediately and he would come from Camperville for them.

In the A.M. of the 19th inst., the writer located Graham RAZOR, age 13 yrs., at Roblin, Man. Father RUST was notified and advised to leave RAZOR at the Mission and he would leave immediately for Roblin to pick him up. Father RUST arrived in Roblin this same day, and after getting Graham RAZOR from the Mission requested the assistance of this detachment to go to the Valley River Indian Reserve with him to try and locate William MINTUCK. The writer and Father RUST located MINTUCK age 13 yrs. at his father's home on the Reserve. Father RUST with RAZOR and MINTUCK left immediately for Camperville, Man., and writer returned to Roblin Detachment.

CONCLUDED-H.O.T.D.C.

Inspector of Indian Affairs

C.C. "D" Div., RCMP, WINNIPEG, Manitoba.
FORWARDED 20-10-45 for your information. Contents:
CONCLUDED H.O.T.D.C.

J.M. DELLA Inspector
C.C. Dauphin S.P.R.

F.R.T COMMISSIONERS
R.C.M Police, Ottawa, Ont.
Forwarded for your information

OCT 23 1945

Officer I/c of C.I.B.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
The Principal, Indian School,
Camperville, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

This little boy who came here with a great deal of tuberculosis is now ready to return to school. For a long time we thought he could not recover and we are very pleased to be able to send him back. If at all possible he should not be permitted to play games of any kind and he should be in bed by nine o'clock each night.

We will send him back to school whenever it is convenient to you. Kindly advise.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Medical Superintendent.

OTTAWA. Feb. 2, 1946.

TO: The Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources, OTTAWA.

Reports dated Roblin, Man.23-1-46, Winnipegosis, Man.17-1-46, forwarded for your information. re: Truancy, Indian School, Camperville, Manitoba.

ATL/AL Enc. for Director Criminal Investigation.
Further to report from our Winnipegosia detachment under the above heading dated the 17th inst., with your instructions appended thereto.

In the a.m. of this date I patrolled to the Valley River Indian Reserve at Timberton, Man., and located the following three boys, and escorted them to Dauphin where they were turned over to the N.C.O. l/c Dauphin Detachment Station to await the arrival of the patrol from Winnipegosia Detachment to return them to the Residential School at Camperville, Man., John Henry SEVRITE - age 15 - Graham RAICH - age 15 and William John MINTUCC - age 15.

This file will now be closed at this detachment, extra copy for the information and file record of the N.C.O. l/c Winnipegosia Detachment.

Forwarded 24-1-46, for your information and further attention and with reference to my telephone instructions of yesterday's date, to patrol to Dauphin to pick up these boys and have them returned to the Indian Residential School.

Kindly expedite your report herein.

D.D.31-1-46.

The N.C.O. l/c., RCMP., WINNIPEGOSIA, Man.

Forwarded 24-1-46, for your information and that of the Dept. of Indian Affairs and further to my minute herein of the 18th instant.

S. U. I. - Winnipegosia.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

DIVISION FILE NO. 463

SUB-DIVISION Detachment

PROVINCE Manitoba

DETACHMENT Winnipegosis

DATE January 17th, 1945

Re: John Henry SEVRITE, et al., (JUVENILES) - Run-away boys from Indian Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba.

1. John Henry SEVRITE - age 15 years
2. Graham RAZOR - age 15 years
3. William John MINTUCK - age 13 years.

Reference the above, I have to report that on the 2-1-46, a telephone message was received from Father REUST, Parish Priest of the Indian Residential School, Camperville, to the effect that the above named boys had run away from the Indian Residential School, Camperville, Man., and requested that this Detachment keep a look-out for the boys as they may pass through Winnipegosis.

All fishing trucks coming from Camperville were checked with negative results, and enquiries were made in the village of Winnipegosis, but no one had seen the missing boys. A check was also made at C.M.R. station and at Bus Depot with negative results.

Physical description of subjects are as follows:

"John Henry SEVRITE - Nationality treaty Indian, age 15, height 5'8", Complex dark hair black, was wearing khaki coveralls, grey air-force pants, grey cap, with fur ear flaps, was wearing heavy low rubbers.

Graham RAZOR - Nationality treaty Indian, age 15, approx. same height and description as SEVRITE, was also wearing clothing similar to SEVRITE.

William John MINTUCK - Nationality Treaty Indian, age 13, quite big for his age, and same description would fit this subject as above mentioned boys. He was also wearing similar clothing.

As the parents of these boys reside in the Valley River Indian Reserve, near Timberton, it is quite possible that the above mentioned boys will be found in this district. I respectfully request that enquiries be made by our Roblin Detachment in this area.

In event that the boys return to the Residential School this office will be advised immediately.

STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION

Cat. 1st RCM, ROBLIN DETACHMENT.

FORWARDED 16-1-46, for your information.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

July 24, 1946.

Nora Nepinak, daughter of No. 75 Pine Creek Band, some years ago gave birth to an illegitimate child in the St. Boniface Hospital, St. Boniface, Manitoba. The alleged father was a white man. No application has been made to have the child admitted to treaty. The child will be seven years old this summer and application is being made to have the girl admitted to Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

I beg to recommend that the child be admitted, the girl is now living on the reserve with her grandparents.

Will you please advise in this matter.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 31, 1946.

Mr. J. Weite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba,

I have your letter of the 24th instant, with reference to Nora Nepinak. As this girl is illegitimate but has resided with her mother, I consider that she is eligible for admission as a grant earning pupil to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School and you may forward the usual application form for her admission to the school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6272, file 582-10, part 3)
Ottawa, January 8, 1947.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

With reference to the December Quarterly Return of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, it is requested that you draw the Principal's attention to the following discrepancies:

1. When a pupil is not in residence for the full quarter the dates as well as the reason for absence should be shown opposite the pupil's name. This applies to pupil No. 262 Joseph Nepinak who was in residence forty-six days only. Pupil # 291 William Ross was absent during the September quarter due to sickness at home. On the December quarter return forty-six days grant is requested. While we presume he returned to school on November 15, 1946, this information should have been shown on the return.

2. All new pupils entering school and those being discharged during a quarter should be shown on the form # 411 for that quarter. On the December quarter # 411 one pupil is shown as admitted namely 309 Hector Gott and yet the return shows pupils numbering from 304 to 310 and 0361 to 0371 as new pupils entering school during the December Quarter.

3. The usual application form and certificate of health is required for Hector Gott.
The discharge of the following pupils is also approved:

# 0267
0333
0345.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Answering your letter of the 7th instant, I wish to inform that pupil No. 256 Adelard Catcheway entered the Gratar Hospital on February 3, 1947. Pupil No. 0342 Sarah Jane Catcheway entered hospital on December 8, 1946.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6272, file 582-10, part 3)
Ottawa, July 18, 1947.

Rev. C. Huest, O.M.I., Principal, Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba.

With reference to the June Quarter Return of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, it is noted that pupil No. 0321 and pupil No. 0353 entered the sanatorium on April 8th and eight days grant was requested. In drawing your attention to circular letter 150-87 dated December, 1944, a copy of which was mailed to you recently, it would appear that these two pupils were entitled to a hospitalization allowance of thirty days and, therefore, a grant of thirty-eight days should have been requested.

It is noted that there are numerous pupils who have been absent from school for at least three quarters. If they are not expected to return, it is suggested that their discharge be applied for. If at a later date they return to the school, the Department should be advised to approve their re-admission.

The Department approves the discharge of the following:

| No.   | No.   |
|-------|-------|
| 0239  | 0355  |
| 0273  | 263   |
| 0279  | 297   |

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, December 18, 1947.

Rev. C. Ruest, O.M.I., Principal, Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Camperville, Manitoba.

With reference to the September Quarter Return of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, it is noted that pupil No. 266 Adelard Catheway has been absent since February 3rd due to hospitalization. On the Return ninety-two days grant was requested but in presuming the pupil returned to school September 1, 1947, we reduced the number of days to thirty. We would appreciate your forwarding the exact date this pupil returned to school.

Another discrepancy was noted for No. 0379 Euphresine Kematch who entered school September 20, 1947, and for whom thirty days grant was requested. If the date of admission is correct, then only eleven days grant should have been asked.

January 3, 1948.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re: 126-110 (WT.E) September Quarter Return.

Answering your letter of December 18, 1947, Re: discrepancies on last quarter return, I wish to inform that Pupil No. 236 Adelard Catcheway, returned to school on June 18th, 1947. I made a mistake by not asking 12 days grant for quarter ending June 30, 1947. The said pupil was really entitled to 90 days grant for Quarter ending September 30, 1947.

No. 0379 Euphresine Kematch entered school on September 20, 1947. The date of admission is correct, only eleven days grant should have been asked.

I wish to apologize for the above mentioned discrepancies and would do my very best to avoid same in future.

Very truly yours,

C. Ruest, O.M.I.

Camperville, Man.

Encl. 3
Ottawa, April 6, 1948.

Dear Father Ruest:

Reverend Father Plourde has forwarded us the attached statements covering the transportation of children to and from the Pine Creek Residential School during the summer of 1947.

Before incurring expenditure for transportation of pupils which you desire the Department to pay, you should write to us and state what amount you consider will be required and explain why it is necessary to provide transportation. In most cases, the Indian parents take the children home and return them without cost to either the school management or the Department.

This practice must be followed in future if you wish to have the Department pay travelling expenses of pupils.

With reference to the attached accounts we are prepared to make an exception but owing to audit regulations we cannot pay the account unless you attach receipts for the various expenditures shown on the accounts. No doubt you have these receipts and they should be attached to the accounts and returned.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. C. Ruest, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Res. School,
Camperville, Man.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Enclosed herewith is Application for Admission of Joyce Peepeetah to the Pine Creek Residential School. While this girl is very young to attend residential school she has no one to look after her as her mother is in gaol and her grandmother is blind and destitute. I would recommend that she be admitted under the circumstances.

W.J.D. Kerley,
Superintendent.
December 6, 1948.

Superintendent,

Broadview, Sask.

In view of the contents of your letter of
the 25th ultimo, the Department approves the admis-
sion of Joyce Peepetch to the Pine Creek Residential
School.

Her admission is not to form a precedent for
the admission of other children under age.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The attached letter concerns the case of the two above children.

It appears that their admission to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School was authorized by your agent and that later on they were spirited away to Birtle Residential School. If circumstances are as described, I am sure that you will want to have these children returned to Pine Creek.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Camperville Man
1-10-49

Rev.F.Plourde OMI
Commission des Affaires Indiennes Oblates
OTTAWA

Bien cher Père,

I want to call your attention upon an affair that took place in the district of Birtle concerning the recruiting of two of our admitted pupils.

0377 Constance COOK adm.Sept.1/47
314 Ivan Cook

When I went for taking back these children after the holidays the parents did not let them go. No explanation was given. When the RCMP was summoned to do the job of telling the parents, the said police found some elusive explanation for not going. When he was told that I would pay the expenses he did not care for.

During that time the local authorities admitted these children at the Birtle Res.School under the pretext that the Father who was a widower had remarried a Protestant woman and was supposed to have his children, who were catholic, re-baptized in the Protestant religion.

During that time what becomes of the first admission of these children to our School? Does it suffice to any minister of any religion to have the children supposedly baptized in their denomination at the will of anybody, to change them from a school were they had been admitted?

The procedure used in this very particular occasion would be for us, Roman Catholics, if acknowledged and accepted by the Department, a mean of recruiting where the whims of some Indian Parents could be changed on our behalf as well; it is a double edged sword.

Yours very truly,

Rev.M.de Bretagne OMI
Principal
October 14th, 1949.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

Constance Cook and Ivan Cook, whose father is Wilbur Cook, No. 274, Waywayseecappo Band, were admitted to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School in September, 1947. Their application forms stated that the religion of these children was Roman Catholic, and their applications were approved by the Indian Agent, who was at that time Mr. A.G. Smith.

We are now advised that these children have not returned to the Pine Creek School, but have been accepted at the Birtle Residential School. From the information that we have on file, it appears that they are not eligible for admission to the Birtle Residential School, and the Principal of that school should not have accepted them.

If they are in the Birtle School, they should be returned at once to the Pine Creek School. Please let me know when you have taken action in this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
Camperville Man
11-Oct'1949

Rev.O.Plourde OMI
Commission Oblate des Aff.Indiennes
OTTAWA Ont.

Dear ahd Rev. Father,

Re- Lawrence Cloud -

I beg to inform you that the Birtle Residential School had admitted No 311, Lawrence Cloud admitted previously at our Pine Creek Res. School on the First Nov. 1947, son of Paul & Annie Cloud, of the Lizart Point IR, Rossburn PO Man.

That child has a sister present at our School and was supposed to be taken back here after the thrashing by his own Father, such was the promise of the parents to the Sub Agent Mr Boyne.

Instead of this he was spirited away to Birtle like were the two others: Constance and Ivan Cook.

If we admit such a strange way of proceeding, I am afraid that we will have no more authority on any discontent Indians.

Yours very truly,

Rev.M.de Bretagne OMI
Principal
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Lawrence Cloud now at Birtle Residential School.

The enclosed letter from Reverend Father Maurice de Bretagne of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School needs no comment on my part.

Would you be good enough to rectify this matter if it can at all be done.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
October 19th, 1949.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

In a letter dated October 14th you were written regarding Constance and Ivan Cook, who were reported to have been placed in the Birtle Indian Residential School, although they are regularly enrolled pupils at the Pine Creek Residential School.

We have now had another letter stating that Lawrence Cloud Pupil No. 311 of the Pine Creek Residential School has been accepted at the Birtle Residential School. This boy was admitted to the Pine Creek School on November 1st, 1947.

If he is at Birtle, he should be returned immediately to the Pine Creek School. Please let me know when you have taken action in this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

December 28th, 1949.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Father Plourde:

I desire to refer to your letters of October 7th and 17th, with reference to Constance and Ivan Cook, and Lawrence Cloud.

We have now received a report from the Principal of the Birtle School which reads in part as follows:

"Please note that neither of the Cook children have been at this school at any time and where they are I do not know. I have never met nor seen either the children nor the parents. I have had telephone enquiries from the father requesting me to admit his children but he was informed that he could not as long as they were enrolled in another school, without the permission of the Department."

Regarding Lawrence Cloud, the Principal writes:

"This boy was brought to the school late in the fall by his parents. I knew nothing of their intentions of sending him here but he arrived when I was away for three days to Calgary. Had I been here I would not have taken him in, but when I came home I could not open the door and send him out to shift for himself. I expect the parents will be at Birtle at Christmas time, and I will send him home with them."

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Grace Atkinson, No. 36, Pine Creek.

It would be appreciated if the necessary authorization be granted to enable the above child to be retained at Pine Creek Residential School to enable her to complete her education.

The child's foster father is dead and the foster mother has left the reserve, whereabouts unknown.

As the child is now 16 years old, she is due for discharge from the School.

It is felt it would be unwise to turn a girl of 16 back to the reserve until her education has reached a stage where we might be able to find employment for her. At the present time she is in grade five.

J.H. Staunton,
Supt., Indian Agency.
October 10, 1950

Mr. J.H. Staunton,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Manitoba.

Re: Pine Creek Residential School

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 2nd instant, the Department approves Grace Atkinson remaining in the above school until June 30, 1951.

If at that time you consider she should remain in the school for another year, you should forward another request.

You may inform the Principal of the above school that the admission of the undermentioned children is approved:

Clements Catagas
Agnes Madeline Catagas
Sheila Ann Catagas
Christianne Moosetail
Glen Eagle
Solange Nepinak

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

15th October, 1950

J.H. Staunton,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Man.

Dear Sir:

Kindly ask Ottawa for authority to keep at school, No. 0354, Christian Gott, who had reached the age of 16 years, but that at the demand of the parents who are working outside of the reserve wishes to stay at the school to finish her education and help her keeping good.

The staff of the School is in favour of backing that demand and we wish that you secure that authorization.

Yours truly,

Sgt. M.de Bretagne O.M.I.
Principal, Pine Creek Resid. School
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ont.

The attached copy of letter from the Principal, Pine Creek Band, re Christian Gott, #0354 on the School roll, is forwarded for consideration.

J.H. Stenton,
Supt., Indian Agency.
October 23, 1950.

Mr. J.H. Staunton,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Man.,

Your file 149/25-2582

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, the Department approves the retention of pupil No. 0354 Christian Gott at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Ontario.

It has been reported that Alex Clearsky 326, Adelia Clearsky 0368 and Lillian Clearsky 0387 did not return after the Christmas holidays to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Alex Clearsky has been in regular attendance at the Waywaysescappo Indian Day School since it opened on April 1st. The other two children are not attending school.

May the Dept. approve the discharge of these pupils effective March 31st, 1951.

J. Rayson,
Superintendent.
June 13, 1951.

Mr. J. Rayson,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Portage la Prairie, Man.,

With reference to your letter of June 11th requesting the discharge of 326 Alex Clearsky Age 11, 0368 Adelia Clearsky Age 12 and 038 Lillian Clearsky Age 10 from the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, it is noted that Alex Clearsky is attending the Waywayseecappo Indian Day School and you are evidently satisfied that he will continue to do so, therefore, the Department is prepared to approve his discharge from the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

In regard to Adelia and Lillian we are reluctant to approve their discharge until we are assured that these children will attend some school. Would you advise what action is being taken to have the two girls attend school either by returning them to the Pine Creek School or attending the Waywayseecappo Indian Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship
and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

May the necessary authorization be
granted, please, to enable Myrtle Ironstand,
#65 Valley River Band to continue her studies
at Pine Creek Indian Residential School for one
more year.

This girl was sixteen (16) years of
age on July 30th., 1951. Her father is in the
Sanatorium and it is felt that with only the
mother to care for her at home she may be in-
clined to get out of hand and associate with
undesirable men.

J.H. Staunton,
Supt. Indian Agency.
August 17th, 1951.

Mr. J.H. Staunton,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Manitoba.

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, we approve Myrtle Ironstand remaining in the above school until June 30th, 1952. After that date, you should again apply for permission.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education
August 14, 1951.

Indian Affairs

Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

With reference to your letter under file 582-10 (E6), dated June 13th, 1951, please be advised that Alex, Lillian, and Delia Clearsky attended Waywayseecappo Indian Day School from 1st of April, day of opening, until the end of the term.

The parents have been advised that Alex and Lillian who are both in Grade 2, will go to the Day School situated on the Reserve, and Delia who was in Grade 5, will be returned to the Pine Creek School as the Day School at Waywayseecappo will be filled with pupils from Grades one to four.

I trust that this action will meet with your approval.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
J. Adyson,
Superintendent.

JR/eb
August 22nd, 1951.

Mr. J. Rayson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School
Your File 127/25-2-582

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant regarding the Clearsky children, the discharge of Alex Clearsky, No. 326, was approved in official letter of June 15th, 1951.

In view of the information contained in your recent letter, the discharge of Lillian Clearsky, No. 038, is also approved.

It is noted that Delia Clearsky will return to the Pine Creek Residential School.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Principal.

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

I am enclosing herewith Applications For Admission to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School for the under mentioned children from the Roseau River Indian Reserve, for reasons as shown opposite each individual name.

Wilson Acobee, No. 333, Father dead.
Frederick Acobee, No. 333, Father dead.
Oliver Seenie, No. 305, neglected.
Aylmer Joseph Seenie, No. 305, neglected.
Richard Seenie, No. 305, neglected.
Marie Stella Larocque, No. 303, mother in jail.
Virginia Larocque, No. 303, mother in jail.
Annette Larocque, No. 303, mother in jail.

If it is at all possible to advise me by return mail, I would appreciate this early advice, as Father Dumouchelle is endeavouring to make arrangements to proceed to Roseau River on October 2nd and I would appreciate being able to advise him as to whether or not these Applications have been approved.

Yours truly,

J. Rayson,
Superintendent.

Dear Mr. Davis:

Enclosed please find application for admission for Caroline Ethel and Marina Sutherland, children of Campbell Sutherland #1234 Peguis Band to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Campbell Sutherland lives 200 yards from Peguis #4 Indian Day School which is taught by an Anglican Teacher.

Campbell Sutherland is quite capable of the support and maintenance of his family.

I am enclosing, herewith, copy of a letter received from Superintendent Minnis regarding a plane load of children taken out from Island Lake to the R.C. School at Camperville (Pine Creek Indian Residential School). As you are aware Father Dumouchel is now the Principal of this school.

Last year the same thing occurred - taking children to Residential School without referring to our officials or having applications approved. It is about time this kind of thing was stopped.

It is noted in Mr. Minnis' letter that five of the children are shown as Protestants. This school has been warned as I advised Father Dumouchel when he was in the office that applications had to be approved before children were taken into Residential School. Therefore, I would strongly recommend that this school be advised to take the children back to Island Lake. We have R.C. classrooms at Island Lake and also a Protestant School. If the Church are made fly these children back at once they will not be so anxious in future to break rules and regulations. I have advised Mr. Minnis by wire to forward all the applications here but not to sign them. As soon as they arrive I will forward them to you.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
Mr. R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

I have before me the applications for admission to Pine Creek Indian Residential School of fifteen Indian children of the Island Lake Band. These children were recruited on the Reserve by Father M. Dutil, O.M.I., and flown directly to Camperville without reference to this office. The applications have now been received from Father DeBretnagne, Medical examination having been given the children at Camperville.

In checking these applications for Church affiliations, I find that five of the children, shown as Roman Catholics on applications, are from families shown on our records as being adherents of the United Church. This is entirely possible, as a good many children whose parents are Protestants are baptized as Roman Catholics by the priests.

However, in the new Indian Act, Sec.117, I note that no child of a Protestant parent may enter a Roman Catholic School except by written declaration of the parent. I wish to know if the signature of the parent on the Application for Admission to Residential School is considered by Dept. as "written direction of the parent". If not, I wish to be advised of the form of written direction necessary in cases of this type, and would ask that a sample of such be furnished me for future use.

Kindly let me have your direction in this matter at the earliest, as I have no wish to become involved in any Denominational argument which may arise over these children.

J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent,
Norway House Indian Agency.
October 6, 1951.

Reverend Paul Dumouchel, C.M.I.,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville, Manitoba.

Dear Father Dumouchel:

It has been brought to my attention that 15 children from Island Lake have recently been brought to the Pine Creek School.

We are further informed that the Indian Superintendent was not consulted before the children were taken from Island Lake and, in addition, five of the children are stated to belong to families shown on the records of the Norway House Agency as adherents of the United Church.

There is a day school at Island Lake conducted under Roman Catholic auspices and consequently no children should be taken to a residential school from that reserve without the Indian Superintendent being first consulted with a view to deciding whether or not admission to a residential school is justified.

As the action that has been taken is contrary to the usual practice in regard to admission of children to a residential school, it will not be possible for the Department to allow per capita grant for them, and they should be returned to Island Lake School at the earliest possible date. It would be appreciated if you would let me know when you have complied with our wishes in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

October 18, 1951

Mr. J. Phelan,
Department of Immigration & Citizenship,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

A month has already elapsed since I have sent through the Indian Agent of Fisher River, Mr. D. Nield, 3 application forms for the admission of three catholic children to the Pine Creek Residential school, at Camperville. The three catholic children are: Marina, Caroline & Ethyl Sutherland, daughters of Campbell Sutherland of Peguis Reserve.

I wonder who is holding these application forms so they will not reach your office, and by so doing deprive these three children from a catholic education, as the parents have the right to choose for them.

We are already in the middle of October, and I would be very pleased if you would rush this matter at your earliest convenience. As our day schools here are all protestants, the parents have decided to send their children to a Catholic residential school and the New Indian Act has provided for that at Article 117.

I am waiting very anxiously for your answer and your approval to their admission to the Pine Creek residential school.

Hoping my request will be brought to your attention immediately,

I remain,

Yours truly,

Reverend E. Pelletier O.M.I.
R.C.Missionary at Fisher River

Rev. E. Pelletier O.M.I.

Mr. R. S. Davis,

Re: Pine Creek School

I desire to refer to your letter of the 26th ultimo regarding the applications for admission of the Sutherland children to the above school. The father of these children is stated to be Roman Catholic and no exception has been taken to that statement. If he desires to have his children receive an education in the Catholic school, I feel that we have no right to refuse him, in view of the Indian Act.

The admission of the Sutherland children to the Pine Creek School is therefore approved.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
The above noted boy, who is twelve years of age, is in the Winnipeg General Hospital with a cast on his leg. Dr. Wood advises me that Joseph should not be sent home, owing to home conditions, but should be put in one of our Residential Schools. The boy's father is dead and the mother has remarried and is now Mrs. Louis Sutherland, Sandy Bay Band. She refuses to sign the application to admit Joseph to school.

Would it be in order for me to send the boy to Pine Creek Residential School, as the hospital bill is running up and the child would be better in a school than the hospital? As the mother does not wish the boy to enter Residential school, I consider it would be better to send him to Pine Creek than the Sandy Bay School.

I might state that Joseph can run around with the cast, so it will not bother him very much.

Will you please wire me at once, upon receipt of this letter, what action to take.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa October 22 1951.

Mr R S Davis
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies
537 Dominion Public Building
Winnipeg Manitoba

CANADA
Indian Residential School
Camperville, Man
October 25th, 1951

Superintendent of Education
Ottawa, Ont.

INDIAN AFFAIRS

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I should have answered your letter of the 6th inst., a long time ago. But due to the fact that the Rev. Father Fiché, Provincial was to call at your Office, I wanted to know about the decisions that would come from your meeting with him. Upon his return to Winnipeg, he has made known to me your views on the matter discussed in the aforesaid letter.

The admission of the Children from Island Lake into the Pine Creek Indian Residential School came before my arrival in Camperville. In the files, I see that they arrived in Camperville on the 8th of September, while I took over as Principal on the 15th of the same month. Father de Bretagne who was then Principal had made all the arrangements with Father Dutil, and had cautioned him to have the approval from the Indian Superintendent of Norway House before taking the children to Camperville. Father de Bretagne was not the less concerned when he saw the children arriving without the proper permissions from the Department. He immediately wrote to Mr. Mennus, asking for approval.

You realise that a quick decision had to be taken, once the children had come to Camperville; either keep them with the hope to see the Department approve of the admission, or send them back to Island Lake. Father de Bretagne took the former decision.

Is it that the Father from Island Lake did not know of the usual procedure for admission of children to Indian School? This I believe to be the case.

You are aware also that ten of those children are from Ste. Theresa Point and five from Garden Hill.
As for the children being from families adherent of the United Church, I am assured by the missionary that they have been instructed and baptised upon the request of the parents.

It might be wise to find from the Missionary himself the reasons that led him to send those children here. Father deBretagne accepted his proposition in the first place, knowing well the difficult situation of our School in recruiting the necessary number of children towards a sound administration of the School.

I am ready to submit to the decision of the Indian Department, and will await to hear from you to take any move. May I mention that the trip from Island Lake to Campbellville has cost $64.00. If we are to send the children back, before the end of the year, I do not know how I will book for the year. Of course this is a minor consideration when we face the whole problem.

Would there not be a means to arrange for approval till June. If then, the Department decides, the children would be left home. This I ask for the welfare of the Children and for no personal reasons or considerations.

You can rest assured, my dear Mr. Phelan, that I realise the hard task that is before you in passing so serious decisions. I would by no means make it harder. In giving you those details, I do not try to be exonerated, since I had no part in the actual situation.

I think I have complied with your desire expressed to Father Provincial, and I hope the informations given will prove that the action taken might have been a false move, but in no way a desire to bring about a situation for which the actual Principal would be penalized.

Knowing that you will consider the case in its true light, I assure you of my wholehearted cooperation in the discharge of your responsibility in settling the problem.

Yours very truly

[Signature]

Principal
October 29, 1951.

Mr. R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
537 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Re: Pine Creek School

I desire to refer to your letter of October 3rd and official letter of October 6th with reference to certain children who were placed in the above school without first receiving the approval of Superintendent Minnis.

In reply to my communication of October 6th, a copy of which was forwarded to you, Reverend Paul Dumouchel, O.M.I., Principal of the Pine Creek School, writes as follows:

"I should have answered your letter of the 6th inst. a long time ago. But due to the fact that the Rev. Father Pichs, Provincial was to call at your office, I wanted to know about the decisions that would come from your meeting with him. Upon his return to Winnipeg, he has made known to me your views on the matter discussed in the aforesaid letter.

"The admission of the children from Island Lake into the Pine Creek Indian Residential School came before my arrival in Camperville. In the files, I see that they arrived in Camperville on the 8th of September, while I took over as Principal on the 15th of the same month. Father de Bretagne who was then Principal had made all the arrangements with Father Dutil, and had cautioned him to have the approval from the Indian Superintendent of Norway House before taking the children to Camperville."
Father deBretagne was not the less concerned when he saw the children arriving without the proper permissions from the Department. He immediately wrote to Mr. Minnis, asking for approval.

"You realise that a quick decision had to be taken, once the children had come to Camperville; either to keep them with the hope to see the Department approve of the admission, or send them back to Island Lake. Father deBretagne took the former decision.

"You are aware also that ten of these children are from Ste. Theresa Point and five from Garden Hill.

"As for the children being from families adherent of the United Church, I am assured by the missionary that they have been instructed and baptised upon the request of the parents.

"It might be wise to find from the Missionary himself the reasons that led him to send those children here. Father deBretagne accepted his proposition in the first place, knowing well the difficult situation of our School in recruiting the necessary number of children towards a sound administration of the school.

"I am ready to submit to the decision of the Indian Department, and will await to hear from you to take any move. May I mention that the trip from Island Lake to Camperville has cost $364.00. If we are to send the children back before the end of the year, I do not know how I will book for the year. Of course this is a minor consideration when we face the whole problem.

"Would there not be a means to arrange for approval till June. If then, the Department decides, the children would be left home. This I ask for the welfare of the children and for no personal reasons or considerations."
In view of the information contained in the Principal's letter, I am inclined to feel that we should approve the admission of the children to the Pine Creek School and (if Superintendent Minnis and yourself consider it necessary, we can discharge some or all of them next June. Please let me hear from you.)

Philip Phelan,
November 1, 1951

Rev. J. Lambert, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Sandy Bay Indian Res. School,
Marius, Man.,

Dear Father Lambert:

It has been brought to my attention that arrangements had been made to transfer the two Houle children from the Sandy Bay to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School without authority from the local Indian Superintendent.

In order to maintain friendly relations with the local Indian Superintendent, it is only fair to arrange these matters through his office. This procedure will not hamper the arrangement in any way but will lead to mutual good will.

When recruiting children for the first time you should also consult the local Indian Superintendent in each case in order that he may approach the Department for authority to admit the children as grant-earning pupils.

We have had complaints from local Superintendents that children are brought to the school first and later the Superintendent is asked to recommend the approval of the admission. This is hardly fair to the Superintendent concerned as he is responsible for all the children in his Superintendency.
and there may be cases that he knows about where children need institutional care more than the children picked out by the Missionary.

Please bear this in mind for future transfers and admissions.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
November 1, 1951

Mr. J.H. Staunton,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Man.,

With reference to a letter dated October 29 from Regional Supervisor R.S. Davis, the Department approves the transfer of pupils O280 Bernice Houle and O281 Irene Houle from the Sandy Bay to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

We are also writing Father Lambert instructing him that no transfer of pupils should be carried out without approval from your office.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
537 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba,
November 9/51.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd inst., which is far from satisfactory. Mrs. Sutherland would like to know:

(1) Why was her son moved from the Winnipeg General Hospital to Pine Creek Indian Residential School without her consent or knowledge or approval?

(2) Why was he not returned to Sandy Bay School from where he was taken?

(3) Why is it necessary for him to be moved so far away making it impossible for his mother to visit him and should the ordinary rights of a mother with respect to her child be ignored and the child placed beyond her reach without her consent or approval as has been done in this case?

Such action would not be tolerated for a minute in the case of a child of a white woman. Surely an Indian mother still has some rights with respect to her own child.

You state in your letter that the matter has been referred to the Department. I presume you refer to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa. Are the mother's rights to be ignored until such time as a disposition of the case and a decision is reached by the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

If there are any good valid reasons why this child should be so far removed from his mother please let me know what they are.

The Indians have been led to believe that under the provisions of the new Indian Act they would be given the rights of a Canadian Citizen.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6272, file 582-10, part 4)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Mrs. Sutherland is at least entitled to have without delay valid reasons why her son should be taken away from her.

Yours truly,

H. A. Lye.
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Re: Joseph Beaulieu

In a letter dated October 19th, Regional supervisor Davis recommended placing the above-mentioned boy in the Pine Creek School. Mr. Davis' letter read in part as follows:

"The above noted boy, who is twelve years of age, is in the Winnipeg General Hospital with a cast on his leg. Dr. Wood advises me that Joseph should not be sent home, owing to home conditions, but should be put in one of our Residential Schools. The boy's father is dead and the mother has remarried and is now Mrs. Louis Sutherland, Sandy Bay Band. She refuses to sign the application to admit Joseph to school.

"Would it be in order for me to send the boy to Pine Creek Residential School, as the hospital bill is running up and the child would be better in a school than the hospital? As the mother does not wish the boy to enter Residential School, I consider it would be better to send him to Pine Creek than the Sandy Bay School."

As it was considered in the best interests of the boy to follow the advice of Mr. Davis, approval was given for the admission of the boy to Pine Creek.

Since the receipt of the letter of November 30, written by H.A. Lye, K.C., we reviewed our file and find that this boy was admitted to Sandy Bay in January, 1949, and the application form was signed by the father.

Early in 1950 the boy was placed in hospital and has not been in the Sandy Bay School since that time.

I telephoned Mr. Davis yesterday and he pointed out again that the boy's father is now dead - that the mother has
re-married and that he considered home conditions unsuitable. He further stated that Dr. Wood did believe that after the boy had been in hospital for some time it would be preferable to have him placed in a residential school rather than in a home on the reserve.

Mr. Davis further stated that it was impossible to return the boy to Sandy Bay as they had their full quota of pupils and he therefore considered it advisable to recommend placing him in Pine Creek.

Mr. Davis said that he would write to us to the above effect.

P. Pholm,
Superintendent of Education.
Ottawa, December 5, 1951.

H. A. Lys, Esq., K.C., LL.B.,
Barrister, Solicitor, Notary, etc.,
Macgregor, Manitoba.

Re: Joseph Sutherland

Dear Sir:

I have had brought to my attention your letter of November 30, addressed to Mr. J. H. Staunton, Superintendent, Indian Agency, Dauphin, Manitoba, and a copy of which was forwarded to the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.

It is understood that you refer to Joseph Beaulieu, No. 234, Sandy Bay Band, who has been in hospital for over a year. In October last, the superintendent of the hospital stated that the boy should be removed from the hospital and placed where he would receive proper care and he was consequently sent to the Pine Creek Residential School.

In view of the contents of your letter, further inquiries are being made and I will write to you again when we receive a report from our field officials.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Director.

With reference to telephone conversation regarding Joseph Beaulieu, #234 Sandy Bay, I am attaching, hereto, a copy of a letter from Dr. Wood, which is self explanatory. I would also like to point out that before Joseph Beaulieu was sent to Pine Creek Residential School the situation was discussed with the Medical Branch.

If Joseph had been placed in the Sandy Bay School, where they are crowded, they could not have given him any extra supervision. This is a case where the boy will have to stay in the hospital or be in a Boarding School. I was not aware that this boy had been a pupil at the Pine Creek School.

I tried to get the mother to sign the application. Mr. Guillas advised the mother by mail that the boy had been placed in the Pine Creek School. He did so by mail as on a previous occasion when trying to get in touch with Mrs. Sutherland he drove to McGregor, Manitoba, where she was reported to be living but she was not home and no one could tell him of her whereabouts.

The only thing we can do is discharge the boy and have the Medical Branch place him in a hospital. Regarding the placing of a child in a school of their own choice - this can only be done when there is room in the school as you know a number of our schools are crowded.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Re: Joseph Beaulieu
#234 Sandy Bay

This boy was under treatment by Dr. A. Gibson during 1951 when in June he was operated on to give him a stable hip. He was then placed in plaster of paris. On October 25th Dr. Gibson wrote this office that he was ready for transfer from hospital and advised that he be placed in a school. The cast had to be changed every three months for a year.

It was clearly necessary that he be in a place where supervision could be given as to the care of the cast and where a good diet could be provided. This was not advisable in a home, particularly his own.

The only satisfactory place for this boy was in a residential school where nursing service and care could be provided and discipline in order to prevent breakdown of the cast and malunion in the operative site. The alternative was to leave him in hospital at a cost of $6.00 or more a day.

In order to provide the care required the Pine Creek Residential School was considered desirable and he was transferred to that school.

W.J. Wood, M.D.,
Regional Superintendent,
Indian Health Services.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship
and Immigration,

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of November 30 and my reply of December 5 with reference to the above-noted boy.

A very complete report has recently been received from the Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies and it appears that it was necessary to remove the boy from the hospital.

There was no accommodation at the Sandy Bay Residential School and consequently he was placed in the Pine Creek Residential School where he could receive proper attention. At the time the transfer was made, our officials endeavoured to get in touch with his mother but were unable to do so.

It is felt that the action taken was in the best interests of the boy.

Yours sincerely,

Director.

FP/IM
Dear Sir:

I have received through the Dauphin Agency the instructions you have issued re THERESE TAIT pupil #0426 Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Had I been consulted before, I would have given you the following information, which might have changed your decision in the matter.

Up to around 1940, the Indian Children from Roseau River attended the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. It was at that time that they were transferred to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. As missionary to The Roseau River Indian Reserve, I was asked many times why the Children from the Reserve could not go anymore to Lebret. I think the explanations I gave were clear and to the point. The Indians of Roseau River would therefore consider a child at the Lebret School as a very fortunate and privileged one.

Even last fall, when it was clear there would be no facilities for these Children at Fort Alexander, the parents insisted that the Children go to Lebret.

The parents know well the position and the advantages of this School. It is true that Therese Tait is there under the direct custody of the Indian Department. But I do not think the Indians, and the Children will understand the legal aspect of this move. To them, Therese will be a fortunate one, to have found her way to Lebret.

My dear Mr. Davis, I have made known to you this information, with the sole conviction that it was not known before by your Department. See in it no reproach, nor any thing of the kind. You and I have at heart the welfare of the Indian Children entrusted to our care, and I felt that my cooperation was wholeheartedly given in doing so.

I remain, yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal

January 30, 1952

Mr. J.H. Staunton,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Man.,

With reference to your letter of January 25th regarding admissions to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, we have noted the contents of your letter and feel that an explanation is required for your future reference.

It is a normal practice that an Indian Superintendent is responsible for all schools in his Agency and the Pine Creek school falls under your jurisdiction. Correspondence dealing with residential school matters is referred to the Superintendent under whose jurisdiction the school comes; consequently all outstanding applications for admission to the Pine Creek school are referred to your office and if some of the children are from other Agencies you are obliged to ascertain from the Principal under what circumstances the children were brought to school and under what Superintendent is responsible for their applications.

It is then your responsibility to write the Superintendents concerned asking them to have these applications forwarded with the least possible delay.

This practice is followed in all our residential schools across the country as there are few residential schools who draw children from one Agency exclusively.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Replying to your letter of February 13, 1952, file No. 582-10 (E6) regarding the children sent from Island Lake to Pine Creek Indian Residential School without authority.

I am in favour of the Roman Catholic children staying at the Pine Creek School until June when they should be discharged. However, I am not in favour of committing myself regarding the United Church pupils remaining at this school until such time as the matter is fully investigated by Superintendent Minnis as to the present religious belief of these children. The families concerned may have changed their religion since the time the records were made up. I am taking this matter up with Superintendent Minnis and will advise you further.

R.S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

April 8, 1952.

Mr. J.H. Staunton,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Man.,

With reference to the March Quarterly Return for the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, the Department approves the discharge of pupils numbered 282, 283, 302, 315 and 349.

It is noted that the first four pupils are fifteen years of age and have been discharged as the parents refused to send them back to the school or the parents claimed that they were needed at home.

Please advise the Principal that the Department is opposed to discharging pupils during the academic year as it is felt that the children should finish the academic year and consequently secure the necessary credits for the grades in which they are enrolled. With reference to the above-mentioned children it is presumed that they are already at home consequently the Department has no choice but to approve their discharge.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Dear Mr. Phelan:

I was reluctant to bring to your attention the case of one of our boys, until I discussed the matter with Mr. G. Marcoux who urged me to write to you.

We have here at school a George McKay age 14 who has become a disciplinary problem to the staff.

It is true that the boy has always been hard to handle, and full of mischief, but since a while, I feel he has become a hindrance to the good order of the School.

It seems that the boy has mental spells and that nothing is to stop him from breaking spoiling and ruining the material at the children's disposal. As soon as the Supervisor has her eyes away from him, he is sure to be in trouble.

There is no point of the regulation that he will not do away with. In recreation he will be rough with the smaller boys, going as far as choking them till they can stand no more.

He is extremely audacious to show others his smartness. Not later than yesterday he was walking on the narrow edge of the roof and could have cause a tragedy.

I have discussed the case with Mr. Marcoux who thinks the boy is a mental case to some extend and who should be sent to a psychiatrist. I made it clear to Mr. Marcoux that no disciplinary measure ever had any effect on him, and that he is a handicap to the Supervisor.

I feel that this boy should be discharged from the Indian Residential School and probably turned to the Health Department for a mental examination.

I am positive that in such dispositions he will not profit by his being in School any longer.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

APPLICATIONS FOR ADMISSION OF CHILDREN TO ROMAN CATHOLIC SCHOOLS WHERE PARENTS STATE THEY ARE ROMAN CATHOLIC BUT DEPARTMENT OFFICIALS STATE BY LETTER OTHERWISE.

1. Harper Family - This family is from the Norway House Agency in the Province of Manitoba and both parents are living. The father has signed the applications requesting the admission of William age 13, Victoria age 13 and Luke age 9 to the Pine Creek (R.C.) residential school.

On the application form the religious denomination is shown as Roman Catholic. The Regional Supervisor, Mr. R.S. Davis states by letter that these children are of the United Church faith.
According to Marcoux's letter the applicant's religion would be U.C. Same for mixed marriage. Children should attend Protestant school. (Sgd) L.F.

Original on 150-7.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attn. Mr. P. Phelan, Superintendent of Education

May I refer to your letter of October 9, 1951, your file No. 582-10 (E) re Pine Creek School.

Mr. Davis has discussed the contents of this letter with me and has directed me to answer it.

In view of the fact that five of these applicants' parents are adherents of the United Church, Mr. Davis does not feel that he should approve the admission of these children to the Pine Creek School, which is a Roman Catholic School. If, however, you feel that you should approve their admission, Mr. Davis feels that they should be discharged next June, with which I concur.

The question of children of Protestant parents being admitted to Catholic Residential Schools is a hot bed here in Manitoba. As the Act reads (Sec. 117) "except by written direction of the parent" it is strongly recommended that an approved form be printed and sent to the Principals of the Residential Schools and the Superintendents of Agencies, to be used in such cases.

Attached please find application forms.

G. H. Marcoux
Regional Inspector of Indian Schools for Manitoba.

2. Hastings Family - This family is from the Norway House Agency in the Province of Manitoba and both parents are living. The father has signed the applications requesting the admission of Isaac age 9 and Juliette age 11 to the Pine Creek (R.C.) residential school.

Mr. J.H. Staunton,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Man.,

With reference to your letter of August 8th, the Department approves the admission of Harvey Michael Nepinak to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

With reference to the application for Irene Nepinak who is not related to the above-mentioned boy, it is noted that in this case both parents are living and that this girl has previously attended Darveau School.

for Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Pine Creek Indian Res. School
Camperville, Man
August 11th, 1952

1952 AUG 14 PH 1:48

Mr. Philip Phelan
Superintendent of Education
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In a telephone call, a few days ago, Mr. J.H. Staunton, our Indian Superintendent at Dauphin, inquired about the children from Garden Hill, Islans Lake, whether they had been sent home.

In a letter from the Regional Inspector of Indian School, Mr. Marcoux, dated March 12th, I was asked to discharge these five children at the end of the academic term. This I have done, and the children were returned home at the end of June.

When Mr. Marcoux was here, in May, I asked him if the discharge was to effect the children from St. Theresa Point. He did not know. A few days ago, I asked him the same question, but he did not have any definite answer, and he advised me to write to your Office.

I know that the Missionary from St. Theresa Point is anxious to send some of his children here, since the school facilities there are not adequate. In my letters I have told him to have the proper authority before sending any children here.

I would appreciate your decision on this matter. Will you be kind enough to let me know the views of your Department on this question.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Paul Dumouchel, O.M.I.
Principal.
Mr. R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor,
538 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Davis:

Enclosed please find an application for admission for Elizabeth Ann Sutherland to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Last year applications were forwarded for three children of the same family as this child and they were approved by the Department so this being the only other Catholic child on this Reserve that is of school age I recommend that she be admitted with her sisters.

Yours truly,

D. A. H. Nield,
Superintendent.

August 19, 1952.

Rev. P. Dumouchel, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Res. School,
Camperville, Man.

Dear Father Dumouchel:

With reference to your letter of August 11th regarding the Island Lake children who are still in the Pine Creek Indian Residential School in view of the fact that the Island Lake Indian Day School is not completed, it will be in order for these children to remain at the Pine Creek school for another year.

With reference to the fourth paragraph of your letter regarding the children who are at St. Theresa Point and should be admitted to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, you are advised that we wired Superintendent Minnis regarding these children and you should arrange to forward the necessary applications for these children to him for consideration.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Theian,
Superintendent of Education.
August 19, 1952.

Mr. D.A.H. Nield,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Hodgson, Man.,

With reference to your letter of August 11th, the Department approves the admission of Elizabeth Ann Sutherland to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Norway House, Manitoba.
August 30th, 1952.

Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Admissions to Pine Creek Indian Residential School

Receipt is acknowledged of your telegram of August 19th, in which you state that representations have been made regarding children in the St. Theresa Area, Island Lake, Manitoba who should be admitted to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, and your telegram requested advice on which children I consider should be admitted.

Your communication, first read by me upon my return from Cross Lake Reserve on August 22nd struck me as a little confusing. I was uncertain whether it referred to new pupils desirous of entering this term or whether it referred to the five children whose status has been the subject of considerable correspondence. I proceeded to Island Lake on the 23rd and interviewed both Father Rho and Father Dutil concerning this situation. Father Rho advised me that there are some twenty children at St. Therese Area whose parents had expressed a wish to have them attend a Residential School. He was good enough to list these children for me with the details of their family circumstances and with an indication of those whom residential schooling would be necessary. There were six in number, three of whom were intended for Cross Lake and three for Camperville. These applications are enclosed herewith having been approved by the undersigned and I trust, will receive Departmental approval.

On August 8th last I submitted to Mr. R. S. Davis, Regional Supervisor, Winnipeg, originals of letters received from Father M. Dutil, O. M. I. at Island Lake, Manitoba concerning the five
August 30th, 1952.

children of Protestant parents who were sent to Pine Creek School in the fall of 1951, and whose applications were held up at that time by lack of approval from this office. Also enclosed in my letter to Mr. Davis were letters from parents of these children requesting their admission to a Roman Catholic Residential School. This formal request on the part of the parents appears to comply with the provisions of Section 117 of the New Indian Act, and as the children were baptized as Roman Catholic and lack any day School in the area of the Reserve in which they reside (Garden Hill) I have now approved these applications and same are attached for your consideration.

I trust this letter will provide the information requested in your telegram of August 19th. However I would appreciate advice from you as to the nature of the representations made Department and referred to in your telegram. As you are aware it is necessary to deal with Residential school applications on an individual basis, and I would not care to generalize on the eligibility of any children in that particular area.

J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent Indian Agency,

Enc. Applications

JDM/NM

Sept. 12th, 1952

Mr. J. Rayson
Supt. Indian Agency
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Re File: 127/25-2-582

My Dear Mr. Rayson:

I am in receipt of your letter dated on the 10th inst.

I have to report that the children whose applications for admission are in your Office have been taken to the School, when all the other children from Roseau were taken back on the 1st of September.

I know of the regulations of the Department in ordinary circumstances, but in the present case, the admission of these children would have meant another trip from Camperville to Roseau, a distance of 350 miles. The expenses involved are to be met by the School, and the time such a trip requires is not always available.

Since you had admitted the children from the same families, last year, it was thought that it would be advisable to take them, even though they would be listed on the Quarterly Returns as per the time of their admission by Ottawa.

I had asked Father Bilodeau to contact you on the matter, but when he passed in Portage, the Office was closed, the first Monday of Sept. being a holiday.

It is with no intention of bypassing the orders of the Department that these children were taken here, but it was judged more practical due to the actual circumstances.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Paul Dumouchel, O.M.I.
Principal.
October 22, 1952.

Mr. J. Rayson,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Portage la Prairie, Man.,

We enclose herewith an application for admission to the Pine Creek Residential School for William Roy Paul, #121 Lake Manitoba Band.

This 14 year old boy has for the past 2 years attended the Lake Manitoba Indian Day School. His attendance there has presented quite a problem as he is much older and bigger than his classmates whom are all of grade 3 status or under. In order to keep the boy occupied and disciplined, the teacher finds it necessary to spend considerable time with him and feels that in doing so she is giving him too much of her time in proportion to the rest of the class.

It was thought that if William Paul could be sent to a residential school, it would relieve the tension at the Day School and also the boy's school work and his general personality would improve with being surrounded by other children of his own age rather than much younger children as is the situation at present.

May we have your decision on this matter.

Yours very truly,

J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent.

Re: Elsie Mae Kipling,
#1165 Peguis Band.

We enclose herewith an application for admission to Pine Creek Indian Residential School in respect to the a/m girl.

The mother of this child recently deserted the family and we understand, is not likely to return. The home is situated 2½ miles from a day school and the child's attendance has not been regular due to impassable roads in both spring and fall season. The father, a Councillor of Peguis Band, usually is employed as a fisherman during the winter months and this motherless child would be denied the comforts of a home and school attendance.

We recommend this application for your consideration and approval.

Yours truly,

J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent.

She is well developed physically and although she is young for Residential School, under the circumstances I would recommend that her admission be approved.

John Gilbert HOULE, #114 Waterhen Band:
This child has been cared for by the grandfather, Edwin Houle, #68 Waterhen. He is an illegitimate child of Edwin's daughter now committed. The step-father has never accepted any responsibility for the child's maintenance and until the death of Mrs. Edwin Houle there was no problem.

I recommend that Department approval be given for admission.

A. Nicholson,
A/Supt. Indian agency.

Joseph Lawrence Murdock 421 "
Louis Alfred Murdock 421 "

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attn. Mr. P. Phelan, Superintendent of Education

I am enclosing, herewith, applications for admission to the Pine Creek Residential School for Tom and Louis Crate, #395 Fisher River Band, both of these children being United Church faith. I am also attaching a request from the parents that these children attend Pine Creek R.C. Residential School. These forms were left at the office by Father Dumouchel, Principal, Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

You will also find attached a letter from Superintendent Minnis. Would you please give me a ruling on this case. You will note the applications have not been approved by Mr. Minnis.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

RSD/MH
Enclos.
Mr. R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor,
Norlyn Bldg., 309 Hargrave St.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Davis:

Re: Admissions to Pine Creek Res. School,
Tom & Louis Crate, #395 Fisher River.

The enclosed applications are submitted for a decision from the Department as to the eligibility of the a/n children for admission to a Roman Catholic Residential School, and applications have not been approved by the undersigned.

Applicants are the sons of Louis and Gertie Crate, #395 Fisher River Band. Both these parents and their sons, Tom and Louis are shown on Agency records as adherents of the United Church of Canada, as outlined on application forms. The children have been attending the Fisher River U.C. Indian Day School, but their attendance has been interrupted considerably due to their residing at the far north end of the Reserve, some 2½ miles distant from the school, across the river; plus the fact that their father, a commercial fisherman took the family to the fishing grounds on Lake Winnipeg during fishing seasons. About a year ago, the family moved to within a short distance of Murdoch Day School (U.C.) where the children attended part of 1952-53 term. It was presumed by this office that the family had made this move with easier access to schooling in mind, as both boys are only at the grade 2 level.
A verbal request for admission of the children to the Pine Creek School was made by the parents yesterday, and a visit was paid the writer by Reverend P. Dumouchel, O.M.I., Principal of the Pine Creek School. Father Dumouchel informed me that the mother was preparing to enter the Roman Catholic Church, and that the parents were willing to have the boys do likewise. At my request, Father Dumouchel secured signed statements to this effect, plus a statement signed by both parents agreeing to the admission of their boys to Pine Creek School. Originals of these three statements are attached. I informed Father Dumouchel that I could not conscientiously approve of the admissions, but would submit the case to Ottawa for decision.

There is no doubt that, at the present time, both parents and children are adherents of the United Church, and that the father, Louis Crate, will continue this adherence. The applications appear to be based on the future conversion of the mother and the two applicants to the Roman Catholic faith, plus consent of both parents to admission of the children to Pine Creek. There is no Roman Catholic Day School on this Reserve, and had the parents and children been bona-fide Roman Catholics at the time of application, with the desire to educate the children in a school of their own faith, I would have approved the applications.

It should be mentioned that the elder of the two applicants, Louis Crate, was taken to St. Mary's Roman Catholic Residential School at Kenora, Ontario, in 1949, but his admission was found irregular and the child returned home. Correspondence in this connection may be found on Ottawa file #465-10 (D.l.A.); Department's decision in the matter being conveyed to the principal of Kenora Residential School in a letter written April 1, 1950 by the late Mr. D. M. McKay. Mr. Davis' file #136/25-2-465 is also quoted in this connection.

My own thought in regard to these applications is that they should be denied for the present, and re-submitted at a future date, when religious affiliations of the mother and the two applicants may be so stated on the applications as to conform to the Department's requirements.

It would be appreciated if the Department would hand down a decision in regard to the attached applications, advising Father Dumouchel by letter of the action taken, with copy here. In the meantime, I intend advising Mr. and Mrs. Crate that their
children should continue to attend the Murdoch U.C. Indian Day School while the question of admission of the boys to Residential School is under advisement.

Yours truly,

J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent.
We, the undersigned, ask the Department of Indian Affairs to allow our children, Louis and Tom, to be taken to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

(Signed)

(Louis Crate)

(Mrs. Gertie Crate)

(Napoleon Reeves)
I, the undersigned, after having taken the necessary instructions, wish to be received in the Roman Catholic Church.

Mrs. Gertie Crate

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6272, file 582-10, part 4)
I, the undersigned, give my free consent to my children, Louis and Tom, to be received in the Roman Catholic Church.

Louis Crate

Napoleon Lachlan
