Dear Father Dumouchel,

We have recently received letters from Mr. R.S. Davis, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies and Mr. J.D. Minnis, Superintendent, Fisher River Agency, together with applications and statements signed by the parents regarding the admission of Louis and Tom Crate to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

It is noted from this correspondence that the Crate family is of the United Church faith and it is the parents' intention to become Roman Catholics in the near future. However, as this family is not yet recognized as of the Roman Catholic faith, the admission of these children to the Pine Creek Residential School is denied.

Under no circumstances must these children be admitted to the Pine Creek School.

Yours sincerely,

R.F. Davis,
Acting Superintendent of Education.
Rev. P. Dumouchel, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Res. School,
Camperville, Man.

Dear Father Dumouchel:

We have recently received letters from Mr. R.S. Davis, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies and Mr. J.B. Minnis, Superintendent, Fisher River Agency, together with applications and statements signed by the parents regarding the admission of Louis and Tom Crate to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

It is noted from this correspondence that the Crate family is of the United Church faith and it is the parents' intention to become Roman Catholics in the near future. However, as this family is not yet recognized as of the Roman Catholic faith, the admission of these children to the Pine Creek Residential School is denied.

Under no circumstances must these children be admitted to the Pine Creek School.

Yours sincerely,

R.F. Davy,
Acting Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Enclosed please find application for admission to
the Pine Creek Indian Residential School for the following
children of the Roseau River Band:

Donald Henry, No. 295
Thomas Henry, No. 295
Margaret Patrick, No. 291
Larry Patrick, No. 297
Vera Pierre, No. 298.

I will forward you four of the applications un-
signed as I drove to the Roseau River Reserve September 7th
to investigate the reason for these children wanting to
attend the Pine Creek Residential School. Father Beaulieu
visited the Roseau River Reserve and picked up all of the
children except Margaret Patrick.

According to Mr. Brad, Asst. Indian Agency, all
of the above mentioned children live close to the day school
on the Roseau River Reserve and Mr. Lambert the teacher, claims
he has room in this classroom for them.

Mr. Brad recommends that Margaret Patrick be sent
to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School as home conditions
are not very good.

D.A.H. Nield,
Superintendent.

FORM 1A-406-

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6272, file 582-10, part 4)
September 14, 1953

Mr. D.A.H. Nield,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Portage la Prairie, Man.,

With reference to your letter of September 8th, the Department approves the admission of Margaret Patrick to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

With reference to the applications for the other four children, we are writing Father Dumouchel regarding placing these children in the Pine Creek School without consulting your office.

A copy of this letter is attached.

R.F. Davey,
Acting Superintendent of Education.

Enclosure
September 18, 1953.

Rev. P. Dumouchel, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Res. School,
Camperville, Man.,

Dear Father Dumouchel:

A complaint has recently been received to the effect that Donald Henry, Thomas Henry, Larry Patrick and Vera Pierre have been admitted to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School without the knowledge of either the local Indian Superintendent or the Assistant Superintendent on the reserve.

It is also reported that the above-mentioned children live close to a day school on the Rosseau River Reserve and the teacher indicates that there is room for them. It is reported that Father Beaulieu visited the Rosseau River Reserve and picked these children up and took them to the Pine Creek School without first consulting the Indian Superintendent.

Please advise the necessity for placing these children in the Pine Creek Indian Residential School and why the matter was not discussed with either Superintendent Nield or Assistant Indian Superintendent L. Brad. For your information, the Department will not allow Per Capita Grant for these children until the matter is clarified.

Yours sincerely,

R.F. Davoy,
Acting Superintendent of Education.

Re: File 582-10(E6)

Dear Mr. Davey:

This will acknowledge your letter of Sept. 18th, re children from Roseau River Indian Reserve admitted to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

Vera Pierre was taken to the School upon the urgent demand of her parents. She is a girl of 13, and according to her parents, she becomes hard to handle at home, and they thought that a few years at the Residential School would do her good.

Donald Henry and his brother Thomas are here because their father thought that Donald, of Grade VII would do better if he could have the periods of study available at a Residential School, but hard to have in their homes. Since Donald was coming, the father wanted his brother to come along also.

Larry Patrick was sent here, because his parents realize that the boy is reluctant to go to school on the Reserve. They had the experience with one of their daughters, older than Larry, who not returned to the Residential School became impossible to handled.

I regret that these children were taken here without the knowledge of the Superintendent or the Assistant Superintendent, but I know that Father Beaulieu did not know of the procedure in taking new children to the School.

Hoping this will clear the matter, I remain,

Yours truly,

Rev. Paul Dumouchel, O.M.I.  
Principal.

Sir:

I have to advise you that on the 27th instant I received a telegram from Mr. A. Ogletree dated at Dauphin, Manitoba asking for authority to have the milk cows at the Pine Creek School tested as it had been found necessary to destroy two of them. I immediately got into communication with Dr. George Hilton, Department of Agriculture, Ottawa, and after an exchange of one or two more telegrams received one this morning stating that arrangements would be made to test the cattle at the School upon the distinct understanding that reactors must be destroyed, and no compensation paid.

I will write you again after I receive the report of the Veterinary Surgeon.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., April 29th, 1925

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant 126-1-14, and reply to say that a test has been made of the cattle at the Pine Creek Residential School, and 18 head of milk cows have proved to be reactors. I am enclosing herewith a copy of the Principal's report.

This is a heavy loss for the school, and it seems to me that the Department should come to their rescue. I strongly advocate that nothing but a good milking strain of cows be sent to this institution, if the Department will consider the purchase of cows.

I do not like the idea of keeping diseased cattle anywhere near the school once we send in an accredited herd; it would be a serious mistake. Nor do I approve of sending cattle there until the stables have been passed by a competent Veterinary as being safe.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 4, 1925.

Sir:

I have your 208-11A of the 29th ultimo and I note with regret that 18 head of milch cows have had to be destroyed at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. I should be pleased if you would make a definite recommendation as to how many animals should be purchased. You might ascertain how far the school authorities can assist. I agree with you that the stable should be made safe before an accredited herd be allowed to move in.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Before more cattle are shipped there we should have the Veterinary Inspector visit the school again to see whether the necessary steps have been taken to clean up the barns. I am ascertaining from Father Brachet how many cows the school would be prepared to purchase on their own account, and advise him that the Department are willing to assist him but think that the school should bear some of the cost. As soon as I hear from him I will communicate with you and give you my recommendation on the matter.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Sir:-

I am in receipt of your letter #126-1-14 of the 4th instant in connection with the 18 head of milch cows that have to be destroyed at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

I beg to inform you that I have just received a communication from Mr. Olette, the Agent, with a copy of a letter attached from the Principal of the above mentioned school, in connection with the cattle. Father Brachet suggests in this communication that he be allowed to keep the cows until Fall with a view to securing a better price for them, and states that he has them in a separate pasture. He closes his letter by asking the Agent to recommend that the Department furnish him with milch cows to replace the ones that reacted under the tuberculosis test.

I might say that the Reverend Father's suggestions do not meet with my approval, as I think it would be absolutely wrong to keep the cattle that are infected with tuberculosis around the place, and even if they are kept in a separate pasture there is no doubt they would get mixed with the other cattle sometime during the summer. It would be a useless waste of money to buy a new herd of cows and place them there under present conditions, as, coming in contact with the other cattle they would probably become infected with the disease. If the tubercular cattle are got rid of now, the sun would kill the tubercular germs in the pasture where they are kept. Whereas if they were kept there until Fall the germs would not be killed by the frost. The only solution is to get rid of all the cattle that have reacted, and thoroughly clean up the barns before any more cows are purchased. I am writing to the Principal to this effect.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter #126-1-14 of the 4th ultimo in connection with the 18 head of milch cows which were destroyed at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, these cows having reacted under the tubercular test. I beg to inform the Department that this matter was taken up by me with the school, and the Principal advised me that the state of his finances at the present time did not permit him to spend any money in the purchasing of additional milch cows. Under these circumstances I would recommend that the Department purchase about 10 head of good milch cows for this school to replace the 18 head that will be destroyed. The cost of these cows will be somewhere in the neighborhood of $90.00 each shall be pleased to have your authority for this expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Health of Animals Branch

Ottawa, June 24, 1925.

Dr. J. H. Grisdale,
Deputy Minister of Agriculture,
Ottawa.

Dear Dr. Grisdale,

I beg to advise you that Mr. Graham, Superintendent of Indian Agencies at Regina, requested in March last that immediate arrangements be made to test the herd of cattle at the Pine Creek Indian School in Manitoba. This school is situated in the Dauphin district, and as the herd did not contain the required number of registered cattle Mr. Graham was informed that the Department could only accept it under the supervised herd plan.

I later received a communication from the Reverend J. Bracket, the person in charge of the Indian School and I forwarded, in accordance with his request, the usual agreement form which must be signed in this connection. This form was duly signed and the herd was tested on April 2nd and 3rd last. The report of the test has not, however, yet been forwarded to this office, owing to the fact that difficulty has been experienced in getting the nineteen animals, which reacted, destroyed. According to the agreement form signed there were fifty cattle in the herd.

Dr. Still advises me that Inspector Bishop informed him that Mr. Bracket made arrangements to ship the reactors to an abattoir in Winnipeg immediately the roads were in a fit condition to drive them to Winnipegosis for loading on the cars, while he was on the premises. As Mr. Bracket did not do so Dr. Still wrote to him on April 7th and again on May 28th. He then took the matter up with Inspector Bishop, who wrote to Mr. Bracket and received a reply on June 6th stating that he had turned the reactors loose on the open prairies far away from the Indian School after the test was conducted. He also stated that these reactors were now dispersed through the bush and swamps and that it would be impossible to gather them up again until the fall. He, however, agreed to have them all destroyed before winter and to allow none of them to go near the premises again. Mr. Bracket does not consider a retest of this herd necessary.
It is quite evident that Mr. Bracket is ignorant in regard to the measures which should be taken in connection with the control and eradication of tuberculosis, as he apparently thinks it is all right to turn reactors loose on the prairies and does not think it is necessary to retest a herd in which about 38 per cent of the cattle reacted.

I am of the opinion that the Department is wasting time and money in endeavouring to clean up a herd with a man of this character in charge, but as it is evidently a Government institution I have thought it well to draw your attention to this case, as you may consider it advisable to take the matter up with the Department of Indian Affairs here.

In the meantime I have instructed Dr. Still to take no further action in the matter.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) George Hilton.

Veterinary Director General.
Ottawa,
June 25, 1925.

Dear Sir,

I am including, herewith, a copy of a letter addressed to me by our Veterinary Director General with reference to the testing of the herd of cattle at the Pine Creek Indian School in Manitoba.

You will note that the Veterinary Director General is of the opinion that under present conditions it is useless to attempt to clean up this herd, but before taking any action in the matter I should be glad to hear from you.

Yours very truly,

J.H. Grisdale,
Deputy Minister.

Chg. Dept. I. A.
Ottawa, June 27, 1925.

Sir:

With further reference to official letter of this file number of the 17th instant, relative to milch cows at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, I wish to confirm my night letter of yesterday's date as follows:

"Reference Department letter seventeenth instant. Report from Veterinary Director General indicates that reactors in herd Pine Creek Residential School have not yet been destroyed. Do not purchase milch cows until conditions for new animals are satisfactory."

I have received from the Deputy Minister of the Department of Agriculture a copy of a communication to him from the Veterinary Director General and it appears that the Rev. Principal at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School did not destroy the reactors following the test for tuberculosis. The Principal informed the local officer of the Health of Animals Branch that the animals would be destroyed in the fall and that he was unaware that a further test would be necessary.

When making arrangements with principals in this connection in future, special safeguards will have to be taken, or the Health of Animals Branch will hesitate to cooperate with us.

Please write to the Rev. Principal at Pine Creek and be guided by instructions of my night letter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, June 27, 1925.

Dear Dr. Grisdale:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, enclosing copy of a communication from the Veterinary Director General with reference to the herd of cattle at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, in Manitoba. I regret to learn that the Rev. Principal did not destroy the reactors after the completion of the test.

Upon receipt of your letter, I telegraphed the Indian Commissioner at Regina that no replacements to the herd be made until after the reactors were destroyed and conditions were found satisfactory.

I have to thank you for the assistance of the Health of Animals Branch in this connection and I will send instructions to our officers who arrange for tests, so that there will be no repetition of this difficulty.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

J. H. Grisdale, Esq., D. Sc. A.,
Deputy Minister,
Dept. of Agriculture,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir:-

I am in receipt of your telegram in connection with the purchase of cows for the Pine Creek School to replace the ones that re-acted under the tubercular test, and note what you state that the Veterinary Inspector General has indicated that this herd has not as yet been destroyed.

I beg to inform you that I had no intention of purchasing these cows until such time as the instructions of the Veterinary Inspector were carried out. I wish to quote a portion of my letter written to Father Brachet on the 12th ultimo with reference to this subject.

"I wish to inform you that I think it would be a great mistake to keep the cattle around after being condemned by the Veterinary Inspector, and I think you should act on his instructions, and get rid of the animals affected immediately, for if you keep them around they would probably sometime or another get mixed with the other cattle and in that way more of your herd would likely become infected. Under the present arrangements I would be absolutely opposed to buying any more milch cows until such time as you get rid of the tubercular cattle, and the sooner this is done, the better. As soon as these have been shipped I will arrange with the Veterinary Inspector

The Secretary,
Dept.of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
to go over the stables again and see that all necessary precaution has been taken. I will then view favorably the question of the Department giving you some assistance in the way of purchasing more milch cows, if you will be good enough to let me know how many new cows you will require."

I am again writing to Father Brachet today advising him of the telegram I received from the Department and pointing out my instructions to him of the 12th ultimo. I realize that it would be a great mistake to spend $1000 on the purchasing of milch cows and put them into a barn that had not been properly fumigated.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa,
January 31, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

The Department would appreciate your advising the number of milking cows at the Pine Creek Residential School at the present time. When were they tested and are you satisfied that they are free from bovine tuberculosis?

If you find it necessary to purchase milk for use at your school please let me know if this is secured from tuberculosis free herds.

An early reply to this letter would be appreciated.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. Leandre Gauthier,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville, Man.
EX'D.

Ottawa,
February 22, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

Enclosed for your information is a copy of official letter of January 31 to which no reply has yet been received. I would appreciate your supplying the information requested in that letter at the earliest possible date.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. Leandre Gauthier,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville, Man.
Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville, Manitoba.
7 March 1938.

R. A. Hays
Superintendent,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Welfare and Training Service,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter I26-I-14, dated Ottawa 31 January 1938, I beg to inform you that we have altogether 16 milking cows, 9 of which are giving milk at present.

Our cows are tested regularly twice a year by Dr. Caldwell, from Dauphin, Manitoba. The last test, made in November 1937, proved to be satisfactory.

We do not purchase any milk. Our cows supply all the milk necessary.

Very truly yours,

L. Gauthier, O.M.I.

WINNIPEG, August 13, 1941

MANITOBA

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Attention Mr. P. Phelan,

Dear Sir:

The milch-cows of the Pine Creek School are far from giving satisfaction. They are poor producers and therefore, expensive to keep.

As you have never, to my knowledge, supplied this School with good milkers, would it be in order to ask for two or more good cows?

I am told that pure bred animals can be purchased in Northern Manitoba directly from farmers at reasonable prices. If given authority by the Department, one of our Brothers could do the purchasing at no cost to the Department.

May I hear favorably from you regarding this matter.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6272, file 582-14, part 1)
Ottawa, August 18, 1941.

Dear Father Plourde:

Your letter of the 13th instant, addressed to Mr. Phelan, has come to me for consideration and reply. Mr. Phelan is at present absent on holidays and is not likely to return for a period of 2 weeks.

I am of the opinion that we have never supplied cows at residential schools at any time since I entered the Department. It is just possible, of course, that cows may be supplied, together with other equipment at the time a residential school is established. In any event, the funds at our disposal this year are not sufficient to justify us in considering the purchase of live stock at Pine Creek this year.

If, as you say, the cows are unsatisfactory, I am of the opinion that the Principal would be well advised to dispose of them and buy regular dairy cattle.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
The Secretary  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Ottawa

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. Philip Phelan

On August 13 last I wrote the Department regarding the supplying of a few milch cows for the Pine Creek Indian School. On the 18th I received an answer to my letter signed by Mr. R.A. Hoey, in which he informed me that it was not the practice of the Department to supply cows to Residential School; but he stated that he would leave the matter to you as soon as you returned to Ottawa.

You are no doubt aware that not later than last year you supplied several milch cows to a few Residential Schools. This precedent is sufficient to authorize you to comply with Father Ruest's request.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6272, file 582-14, part 1)
Ottawa,
September 22, 1941.

Dear Father Plourde:

I have your letter of the 15th instant with reference to the request of the Principal of the Pine Creek School for an additional cow.

The matter has been fully considered but we cannot see our way clear to favourably consider the request. As a matter of fact we are not even purchasing cows for use in agencies at the present time.

In a letter dated March 7, 1938, the then Principal of the Pine Creek Residential School wrote as follows:

"We have altogether 16 milking cows, 9 of which are giving milk at present. Our cows are tested regularly twice a year by Dr. Caldwell from Dauphin, Man. The last test made in November, 1937, proved to be satisfactory. We do not purchase any milk. Our cows supply all the milk necessary."

The natural increase from the above number of cows should have ensured sufficient milking cows to continue to provide the milk that is needed. As a matter of fact the report of the Principal for the calendar year ended December 31,

Rev. J.O. Plourde, C.M.I.,
619 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.
1940, stated that they had 20 cows at the Pine Creek School but did not definitely state if all of them were milking.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of
Theodore Cook, Pupil No. 186,
of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School at Campbellville,
who died at Campbellville (place) on December 2nd, 1935.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? December 1st, 1935.

2. At what time of day? 6:15 a.m.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? The doctor was called.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? He was given a dose of milk of magnesia.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? Milk of magnesia.

6. When was the doctor called? 7:30 a.m., December 1st, 1935.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? Doctor Medd would not remove him; he was too ill.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school? Doctor Medd brought a nurse to help take care of the child.

9. Add any other useful information here.

At 8 a.m., when the child vomited, we noticed his eyes and face swelling; he seemed very sleepy. We immediately called the doctor.

[Signature]

Principal.

No fault of school staff.

Thorne Cook, Pine Creek Residential School

have been recorded? Yes. If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

The Department Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Respected Sirs:-

On Sunday December 1st I was called to Pine Creek Indian School to treat Cook. I went at once and found this boy in coma. His face and eyes were puffed and swollen. Features pale, pulse irregular and little slow, respirations normal per minute but with a rattle in throat. The urine was loaded with albumen. There was some twitching of muscles. I made diagnosis of an acute nephritis. The chest appeared negative. There was no sign of regitity of neck or back. The ears were negative. There was vomiting when I arrived and I was able to elicit that this boy had a headache.

I irrigated bowels with good results, placed boy in hot pack between woolen blankets in warm room isolated and gave sips of soda water. I secured Nurse Whale from Winnipegosis and continued treatment remaining at Pine Creek till boy died Monday morning. Monday morning I found signs of a pneumonia with pulse, temperature and respirations much increased. I believe the two conditions had developed at about the same time and as result this little boy died.

The Superintendent of the school and staff had done everything possible. They assisted in every way. I had been called as early as anyone would expect. The condition was acute rapid, with a sudden termination which was expected and which
was unavoidable.

Mr. Cook at Shoal River reserve was notified Monday by wire to effect that his little boy had died. It was impossible to notify him sooner or before death took place. A married sister of this boy, who was living at Pine Creek was called and brought her to the school to be present also a sister in the school.

On Saturday this boy was skating and appeared well. I know this Cook family and this boy and can report that he appeared well to me. The ailment was acute and the termination sudden. I believe everything was well done that could be done to help this little boy. Every attention was given. The School Staff under the direction of a wonderful Sister Superior, had done everything that was possible under the circumstances.

I have the honor to be,

Sirs,

Your obedient servant,

A.E. Medd
Winnipegosis Sept/9th38.

Mr. J. Waitr,
Indian Agent,
Portage La Prairie.

Dear Mr. Waitr,

Re. Alexander Cook- Shoal River Reserve.

This boy took sick with temperature and cough at Pine Creek School May 1st. He was isolated and seen by me and was detained at the school - given nursing care and medicine. This boy was thoroughly checked and I realized that I could keep him at the school for further observation which was necessary and then have him checked by the T.B. clinic at Dauphin and further disposed of. There was no improvement - his parents were notified of his condition on three separate occasions. He was too sick to be taken to Dauphin to the T.B. Clinic. I had him removed to the Crerar Hospital Winnipegosis June 9th.

His condition did not improve. The cardinal findings as shown by the chest were - cough, expectoration, irregular temperature, sweating, haemorrhage from lungs, loss of appetite, and weight.

The haemorrhages were the late findings. There was no t.b found in first specimens of sputum later I had definite T.B. bacilli in sputum.

The chest was explored for fluid or pus but none found.

The findings in the chest were respirations in first two weeks of May 20 to 26 per minute Pulse 100 to 110 and temperature 100 to 101.
The last part of May respirations were 20 to 28 per minute, temperature 101 to 102 and half with pulse increase. During June the respirations remained at thirty per minute and the temperature varied but remained rather higher and the pulse increased; this was due to haemorrhages and involvement of the lungs.

This condition carried through till time of death. The lungs showed a progressive involvement with spread of area involving whole of left lung and upper part of right right lung.

The general medicines used were stimulating expectorants in the first instance—rest and good nursing care, with isolation. Later the complications were dealt with as thought necessary. For haemorrhages he had calcium lactate—ice bag—sedative.

The condition was steadily progressive to fatal termination.

The Summary—

I believe that there will be detention at the larger Indian schools of such cases where isolation can be maintained. The reasons for this is that we will have breakdowns at school of Indian children who mostly have been contacts as in this case. The second reason for this detention is for diagnostic purposes and I believe that any child with expectoration should be isolated and sputum test made.

If all chest cases are sent out on temperature and cough there would be no end of the number sent away when it would not be necessary and when we would not know if we had tuberculosis or not to deal with.
Where the parent is at a distance it is not pleasant to have the responsibility of a little child that is not progressing well.

Repeated check ups will not avoid the breakdowns we will still have first diagnosis of T.B. made at the schools - There will still be detention at the school and good care given each child and disposal of such child and in reasonable time where we feel that something can be done to save that life it will be sent to Sanatorium. This case was discussed with Staff Of T.B. clinic at Dauphin and I made the case known and the boys condition discussed along with his brother who was at the clinic.

In my opinion everything was done and good attention given to Alexander Cook while at the Pine Creek School and I have given him the best of attention. I realized that his progress was not good. I reported same to parents and School Principal.

I expect that we will have others that will have their break downs at school and as I review this case I can visualize that any other case will be handled in much the same way.

Yours Truly

A.E. Medd
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Re: Theresa THOMAS - Treaty Indian, Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Camerville, Man., Death of:

ASSISTANCE TO DEPT. INDIAN AFFAIRS

5-6-42.

1. Referring to the above I have to report that on the above date Dr. A.M. MND, Winnipegosis, Man., called at this detachment office and stated that the above named girl had died at Pine Creek residential school on May 24th, 1942 and that it was necessary to hold an enquiry into the cause of death, further that he had received a letter from the office of the Indian Agent Portage La Prairie, Man., and that it was requested by the Indian Agent J. Waite to attend the enquiry and that he had requested that someone act for him as chairman on the board of enquiry. Dr. MND therefore requested that the writer accompany him to Camerville for the purpose of sitting as chairman on the board of enquiry.

2. As the writer had several other files in this district it was decided to accompany the Doctor. I therefore left Winnipegosis at 2:00 p.m. per car (gratis) and proceeded to Camerville, Man., where the enquiry was conducted. The death of the captioned was noted and it was learned that she had died from advanced tuberculosis, the immediate cause of death being a hemorrhage. The writer acted as chairman of the board.

3. Other files in this district were attended to and the writer returned to Winnipegosis at 9:40 p.m. the same date.

4. Extra copy of this report attached hereto for the information of J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage La Prairie, Man.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Albert NEPIKAM, #196 Pine Creek Band, Pupil No. 324, of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School at Camperville, Man., who died at Pine Creek (Indian Reserve) on April 8th, 1951.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

FORM No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? 7th April 1951
2. At what time of day? 2 p.m. (Sunday afternoon)
3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? 4th April
4. What means were taken to afford relief? Search
5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? 4th April
6. When was the doctor called? 2.15 p.m. 7th April 1951
7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport?
8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?
9. Add any other useful information here.

Boy had left school to home without permission

Principal.

Note: If the deceased pupil dies in hospital at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who attends him at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to this memorandum.
B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Albert Higgins from September 1947 to April 1951. The immediate cause of death was Encephalitis. He had walked about 12 miles in attempt to reach home at Smith's Island. Fell into ditch. The contributory cause of death was Rickets due to rickets - became exhausted - lay down to rest 1½ miles from home at Smith's Island - where his body was found.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? N/A

Did they follow out your professional instructions? N/A

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

N/A

[Signature]
M.D.

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of Albert Nepinak, #196 Pine Creek Band (Pine Creek Indian Residential School) have been recorded? Yes. If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

DIVISION FILE No.

DIVISION: Dauphin
SUB-DIVISION: Winnipegosais
DETACHMENT: Winnipegosis
PROVINCE: Manitoba
DATE: 9th April 51

File Reference: Albert HEPINAK, Treaty Indian, Pine Creek Indian Reserve, Sudden Death by Exposure (WINNIGEOSIS DEP. CASE)

Name of Deceased: Albert HEPINAK
Age: Born 13th December 1940
Cause of Death: Exposure to the elements

Place of Death: Pine Creek Indian Reserve, approx. 4 miles North West of Indian Residential School
Date & Time of Death: Between the hours of 12 Midnight 8.4.51 and 4.00 A.M. 9.4.51

Coroner: Dr. Wm. BASHUCKY, Winnipegosis, Hon.
Witnesses: Arsene HEPINAK, T.I., Father of deceased
Joseph HEPINAK, T.I., Uncle of deceased
Lindy HEPINAK, T.I., Age 13 years
Roy HEPINAK, T.I., Age 13 years
Gordon HEPINAK, T.I., Age 13 years

Survived by: Parents and small brothers and sisters, Treaty Indians of Pine Creek Reserve

A.R.V. No.: 8th April 51

At approximately 4.30 P.M. this date, the writer was advised by telephone by Dr. Wm. BASHUCKY, Coroner, that he had received a phone call from one of the sisters at the Indian Residential School at Comperville to the effect that one of the boys of the school had been found dead. No other particulars were received at the time.

The writer accompanied by Dr. Bashucky and Sgt. R.L. Shell patrolled to the school via Dr. Bashucky's private car. Father de BERTAGNE, Principal, was interviewed and gave the following statement:

Comperville, Man.
6th April 1951

Albert HEPINAK was a pupil of this Pine Creek Indian residential school. About 4.30 P.M. 7th April, I saw John FLATFOOT, T.I., and he said "I met three of your boys and I think they were beating him". He said one was Arsene HEPINAK's boy. As soon as John told me I went to see the Supervisor in the yard. I said John told me some boys go across the river. Then George HEPINAK says, "yes my brothers going home I'll go and get him back."

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6272, file 582-23, part 1)
Par. 2. Cont'd.

GET HIM BACK." Albert's father who was working on the farm had also gone home so I was not worried when they didn't come back. At 6:30 p.m., the little boys came back all wet with no supper, that had gone to look for the first boys. When they came to the river they came back because they did not cross for fear of getting wet. I then considered Albert and the other two were in a house at the west side of the Reserve. I saw Arsenio this morning and he said that Albert hadn't come home. He left after the mass to go to Camille Nepinak's the boy's grandfather where he thought he must be. After dinner at 2:10 P.M., Father Phillpott told me Paul Moosetail is here with Gordon and Lindy, two of the runaway boys who had left with Albert. Then I suspected that Albert might be lost. I questioned the two boys then decided to go and hunt for him to see if he had not reached another Indian house and at that very time Noel Nepinak, T.I., came to tell me that the boy had been found dead by his father. I asked the sister to call the Coroner and went to the house to tell the boy's father Arsenio not to move the body but it was already in the house.

SIGNED REV. P. deHartagne,
Principal R.N.S.

3. Father de Hartagne explained that it is customary if any of the boys leave that other members of the family will go to look for them as was the case in this instance when the deceased's brother George and two other boys started after the three boys who had left. The boys got their feet wet crossing the meadow and did not attempt to cross the river but returned to the mission. He did not have any reason to believe that the deceased was not safe with the boys he left with until the other two were returned to the mission by Paul Moosetail.

4. The following statement was taken from Lindy Marchese, one of the boys who left with the deceased:

STATEMENT OF LINDY MARCHESI, T.I., AGE 13, APRIL 8TH, 1951.

At 4:30 yesterday, Gordon Moosetail left, and Albert Nepinak left the mission with me. We walked a few miles and came to the river on the way to Gordon Moosetail's home. I crossed the river first. I jumped in the water and walked and swam to the other side. Gordon Moosetail followed me walking through it, but Albert said "I cannot go across I am going to go back." He was about half way across the river. Then he took his coat off, and the last I saw him he went back across the trail we had come on. We were all soaking wet and we were very cold when we got home. When we got to Moosetail's I told Mrs. Paul Moosetail that Albert had been with us and went back.

SIGNED Lindy Marchese, R.N.S.

The statement of this boy refers to the Duck River which runs through the reserve. Gordon Moosetail could not be interviewed at this time as his father had come to the mission and taken him home which is six miles across the reserve by team and it was already 10:30 P.M.
Per. 4 Cont'd.

WAS ALREADY 10:30 P.M. WHEN THE PATROL RETURNED TO THE MISSION.

5. The patrol proceeded via the mission truck with Father deBRETAGNE about 5 miles into the reserve to the home of the father of the deceased. Here Dr. BASHUCKY made a thorough examination of the deceased; it was about 7:00 P.M., and the doctor stated the boy had apparently died during the early morning hours of the same day and had been dead approximately 16 to 20 hours. He stated there were no marks of violence on the body and that the deceased had apparently died of exposure. The deceased had on dry clothes and the father explained that the one he was found in were soaking wet so he had changed them. He produced the clothes which were tied in a bundle and which consisted of blue denim coveralls, 1 pair brown striped pants, 1 pair of green socks, 1 pair of grey socks, black rubber ankle boots, blue sweater, white combination underwear. These clothes were all soaking wet and were identified by the father as those the boy wore at the mission.

6. The following statement was taken from the father of the deceased:

BEGIN:

STATEMENT OF ARSENE NAPINAK, T.I., Pine Creek Reserve, April 8th, 1951.

I went to church at 10:00 A.M. today at the mission. Father deBRETAGNE asked me if my boy Albert NAPINAK, age 10, was at home. I told him he wasn't. I thought he was at the mission where he stays. The father then said he had left the mission yesterday and went to the west line with some of the boys. After mass Noel NAPINAK, T.I., told me that two of the boys were at home on the west side of the reserve. Then I went to look for my boy. I took the trail he would take coming home and about two miles from home found him lying dead on the bottom of an old hay stack. I went back and got my brother Joe who was following me and he brought the horse over and we took the body back as far as another stack 200 yards away. Then Joe went home and got a team and we took his body to the house. Then I sent Noel NAPINAK to tell the priest. It was 2:00 P.M. today when I found the body. It was quite cold and stiff. I believe he died from getting wet and cold and exhausted.

SIGNED Arsen NAPINAK, R.H.S.

At this time Arsen NAPINAK pointed out that the boy had walked approximately 2½ to 3 miles from the point to where he had been in the river to where his body was found. At this time it was quite cold and the going was very tough the horses at times being knee deep in snow and water. The boy had been following a trail which he knew led direct to his home. The patrol, accompanied by Arsen and Joe NAPINAK proceeded by team to the spot where the body was found as indicated by the boy's father. He pointed to the spot in the hay. From the look of the hay the boy had apparently tried to gather enough together to keep warm but had given up and just lay on the hay exhausted. At the time the patrol was made it was quite cold and Dr. BASHUCKY pointed out that anyone soaking wet would soon become numb with cold.

Continued, Page 4.
HURT WITH COLD (Par. 6 cont'd)
and be unable to move, after which his body temperature
would lower gradually to a point where his heart would
cease to function. The temperature during the night would
go below freezing.

7. The patrol then returned to the house of Arseno
NEPINAK. The following statement was taken from Joe
NEPINAK:
Pine Creek Reserve, Man.,
April 8th, 1951.

STATEMENT OF JOSEPH NEPINAK.

I followed my brother Arseno who went to look for
his son. I was about a mile behind him on a little lake
and my brother came and said he had found his son Albert's
body. He showed me where he was lying on a hay stack
bottom and I recognized him. We took him a little ways
on my horse then I went for a team to take him home.
SIGNED Joseph NEPINAK.

8. It would appear that the deceased, accompanied
by two other boys from the mission Lindy MANCHESTER, Age 13,
and Gordon MOOSETAIL, Age 13, left the mission with the
intention of going to the home of Paul MOOSETAIL. Gordon's
father. About 4 miles from the Mission in a North Westerly
direction they came to the Duck River. Here Gordon and
Lindy crossed the river which was open by wading through it
but Albert got half way across then turned back and got out
the side he had come from. The water was about 4 feet deep.
Then he proceeded back on the trail until he came to the
trail leading to his father's house. He started out along
this trail but only got about 2½ miles before he was over
come by the cold and could go no further and perished from
exposure. There are no houses along this trail. It also
appears that the other boys who were also not thought he
would get home alright as they arrived at Gordon's father's
place which was a mile and a half West of the river.

9. Dr. BASUCKY stated that in his opinion no inquest
was necessary and released the body to the boy's father for
burial. The writer concurs with the opinion of the Coroner.

10. The writer would suggest that this file remain
open until Gordon MOOSETAIL can be interviewed. Extra copy
this report handed direct to Dr. BASUCKY for his information
extra copies attached.

S.U.T.
D.D. 23.4.51.

Col.
(S.B.H., Littlewood, #12752)

Mr. J.H. Staunton, Dept. Indian Affairs, Dauphin, Manitoba.

FORWARDED 12-4-51, for your information, perusal, and file record.

2. From perusal of this report it appears as though the deceased, together with Gordon Moosetail and Lindy Mancheese ran away from the R.C. Indian Residential School at Camperville, Manitoba with the intention of going to the home of Gordon Moosetail. On the way to Moosetail's home they had to wade across the Duck River. The deceased who apparently decided he could not get all the way across the river, turned back from the middle of same and then tried to walk to his own home. After walking a distance of about two and a half miles he could go no further and attempted to cover himself with hay. Unable to do this the boy apparently lay on the hay exhausted and succumbed to the cold.

3. Gordon Moosetail, one of the above mentioned boys, will be interviewed in the near future and a further report will be forwarded to you in due course.

(W.W. GRAY) SGT. FOR

I am enclosing, herewith, a copy of a letter from Superintendent Staunton and also a Police Report regarding the death of Albert Nepinakm Treaty Indian, due to exposure. Albert you will note was a pupil of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. As death was due to exposure no one is to blame.

April 21, 1951.

Mr. R.S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
537 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School

We are in receipt of your letter of the 16th instant enclosing reports regarding the death of Albert Nepinakm, pupil of the above school.

I may have gathered the wrong impression from the reports, but I am not satisfied with the action taken by the Principal. It appears that the boys ran away from the school, and yet there is no mention of any member of the staff making an attempt to locate them. It has always been felt that when pupils run away it is the duty of the staff to make an endeavour to find them and bring them back. Occurrences such as the one we are discussing reflect on our residential school system and on those operating the schools.

I would appreciate it if you would investigate this matter further at the earliest possible date, because if necessary, we must issue special instructions to the principals of all residential schools regarding the procedure that must be followed when pupils desert.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education
ATTENTION: Mr. P. Phelan

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

With reference to your letter of April 21st, file '149/25-1-582 (E)', Inspector Marcoux went to the Pine Creek School and investigated the case further.

The impression you have from the reports, etc., as expressed in your letter, is not quite correct, due to the fact that some details were not mentioned in the reports. The following may clarify the matter:

1. The deceased boy's father was working at the school at the time.

2. The Principal thought the boy had followed his father home. Nevertheless, he sent the boy's brother to get him.

3. The following day the father came back to the school and told the Principal that the boy was not at home, but was probably at his grandfather's home.

4. Action was taken to check on this information and a search was started. This search resulted in the finding of the body.

It appears to me that in this case reasonable steps to find the boy were taken, and no blame is attached to the Principal of the school.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

GHM/ES
May 29, 1951.

Mr. R.S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of
Indian Agencies,
537 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.,

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter dated May 22nd dealing with the death of Albert Nepinak pupil of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

It has been noted that Inspector Marcoux went to the Pine Creek school and investigated the case and that you are satisfied that in this case reasonable steps to find the boy were taken and no blame is attached to the Principal of the school.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir,

The Indian School here has for some years had a grant from your Government of $1440.00 per annum being $72.00 each per annum for 20 pupils.

When this grant was first made the premises then occupied were of a very inferior character and the number of pupils mentioned were as many as the building would accommodate. Since then a new and commodious building has been erected by the church Board under whose auspices the work is conducted at a cost of some $4000.00. There are now 30 pupils on the roll and the accommodation is sufficient for 40, but the amount provided for maintenance is insufficient.

During February last your Inspector Major McGibbin made a very thorough inspection of the school and of the tepees at the Indian Village and he seemed to be very favorably impressed with the progress made and the manner in which the work is conducted, and in his report recommended strongly that the number of pupils supported by your Government be increased from 30 to 30. It is to this recommendation that I now beg to direct your attention, and I trust the same will have your favorable consideration.

Hoping to hear from you in this connection, I am

Dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 21st instant, asking favourable consideration to the proposal to increase the grant to the Indian school in your vicinity so as to provide for the maintenance of 30 instead of 20 pupils. In reply I regret to have to say that as the estimates are all prepared, and it had previously been decided not to increase the appropriation for Indian education beyond the sum estimated for, it is not possible for me to, at present, comply with your request.

I shall, however, have the claim which you make on behalf of the school officially noted for consideration when I take up the whole question of Indian education, which I purpose giving my careful attention to during the recess.

Portage-la-Prairie, Kan.
Portage La Prairie Boarding School

This school is situated about one quarter of a mile east of the town of Portage La Prairie. The buildings are frame on a stone foundation and are heated with hot air and lighted by electricity.

It is a Presbyterian School. The Indians attending the school are Sioux. There is accommodation for forty pupils.

This school was built by the Presbyterians and the Govt contributed nothing, either for land or for the cost of erecting the buildings. (See D. Moore's letter of the 25th January on file No. 58244)

This school was first opened as a Day School in 1890 with 26 pupils enrolled and an average attendance of 10. The Dept paid a grant of $300 per annum to Calgary for the teacher of the Day School, $12 per capita for each pupil over the number of 25. The Day School continued to be paid at this rate till the end of the June quarter 1893 when it ceased to be run as a Day School. It is now conducted altogether as a Boarding School.

The Boarding School was first started during the year 1891 and was run in connection with the Day School till the end of the June quarter 1893. A grant was given by the Dept towards the support of the Boarding School in 1891 which...
amounted to $1000.00 being for 20 pupils @ $50.00 per capita. The same amount was paid for school in 1897. (See annual reports for 1891-97 in the statement regarding Indian schools.)

At the beginning of the March quarter 1897, the amount was raised to $73.00 per capita for 20 pupils (see Letter of Rev Prof Baird on file No. 94600).

This school has been paid on the same basis viz.: ($72.00 per capita for 20 pupils) since the above date.

Two teachers are supported by the Presbyterian Church and are paid $300 each from the funds of the Church.

For all particulars regarding the size, dimensions or construction of the Portage La Prairie School see Report No. 1194696.

The land in connection with this school comprised four small lots, equal to about 1/4 acre in all.
Sir,

I beg to draw the Department's attention to the following matter. Ever since the Treaty was made, the Indians of the Long Plain reserve in the Portage la Prairie Agency, have resisted all efforts to place a Missionary or Day school on their reserve. Neither would they consent to their children being sent to a Boarding or Industrial school. But lately a change has apparently come over a few of them and Principal Hendry of the Portage la Prairie Sioux Boarding School, assisted by Indian Agent Logan has succeeded in getting four pupils of school age from that reserve, very much against the wishes and efforts of the Indians there. He also has four Sioux children of school age at the school over and above the number allowed, for which he does not receive any grant.

This school under Mr Hendry's management has kept out of debt, and I would be glad to have any Official of the Department visit there without warning. They are always ready and up to the mark, and the Pupils from that institution are a credit to them.

Mr Hendry remarked to me lately that he found the expense of keeping eight extra children was more than he could finance for without going into debt, on his present grant, and he was afraid that after all his trouble he would have to send the four children back to the Long Plain Reserve.

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa.
Reserve. The school being for the Sioux he supposed he should give them the preference. But I asked him to keep them for a short time until I wrote the Department to see if I could get a grant for the extra pupils.

Mr Hendry says the two eldest pupils in the school will be leaving this winter, which will leave him with six extra children on hand and I would be very pleased if the Department could arrange to allow him a grant for that number over and above the 25 at present allowed.

It seems too bad altogether to allow children to go back to the Long Plain Reserve after trying for so many years to get them, and if these are kept at the school it will probably lead to others being sent in the future.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant

My Dear Sir:

There is an Indian Reserve near Portage la Prairie called the Long Pains Reserve, that has been impervious to Christian and educational influences up to the present time. However, a change has come, as it is manifestly coming to many reserves. Mr. Hendry the principal of the Portage la Prairie Boarding School, has received a few of these children and others want to come, but he says, on the present per capita grant for twenty-five, he cannot finance it. He had, when I was there, thirty or thirty-one, I think, in the school. Would it not be a pity to refuse any who want to come, and especially after long years of quiet effort to induce them to care for the education of their children?

Would it not be possible to make a per capita grant for thirty instead of twenty-five for the Portage School? I hope this will prove possible in the interests of the children and also in view of the increased cost of living in the west, as well as elsewhere. There is no doubt that the changed conditions will make necessary at an early date a revision of the administrative policy.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

R. P. MacKay

My Dear Sir:

Yours received of Oct. 16th. re the appointment of Mr. Hendry to Alberni, and enquiring as to whether or not a successor has been appointed at the Portage.

I had not the impression in my mind that it was expected that we should report such appointments to the Department. They are made by the Western Committee, and I am not aware whether or not they have been under a similar impression. When I think of it, however, I recognize the desirability of keeping the Department in fullest touch with what is being done. In the future I shall endeavor to keep that in view.

I am sorry that so many changes are being made. Mr. Hendry, who has done such satisfactory work at the Portage, had a desire to try the British Columbia climate. This request was made some years ago, and only now did the opportunity offer. He was accordingly appointed to Alberni and entered upon his duties.

At the same time that the vacancy occurred in Alberni we had from Mr. Millar of Ahousaht a request for a change on account of the climate, his throat being affected by the damp on the Pacific coast. Accordingly Mr. Millar was appointed to the Portage to succeed Mr. Hendry. This was even more regretted than Mr. Hendry's removal, because Alberni is a much more difficult place to fill and Mr. Millar has been doing admirably. A letter just received from Mr. Ross says that Mr. Millar has brought the work at Ahousaht to a higher level, possibly, than any other man we could have sent. He has left everything in good shape for his successor. The day school in particular has made great progress since Mr. Millar came into the work.

Mr. Millar not only left the Mission, but took Miss Mackay, the teacher, and they are to be married in a week or two. Together they will take charge of the Portage school. Further complications arose from the fact that Mr. Ross became engaged to Miss McNeil, who has been matron at the Ahousaht school, and who has proved herself indispensable, not only because of her ability as the matron of the home, but because of her work in the village amongst the people. It therefore became the problem whether to allow Miss McNeil to go to Ucluelet, or have Mr. Ross transferred to Ahousaht. Mr. Millar when leaving wrote stating that it had become a necessity that there should be two men in Ahousaht. Not only because of the duties of the principal in looking after the institution and the farm, for there a farm, as you know, of ten acres or so, secured by the draining of a shallow lake, but also because of the difficulty in securing wood, and in addition at times the discipline amongst the bigger boys, and even in
Mr. Stewart,

dealing with the village, require two men. The strain proves too great for one. This view was entertained by our Committee and Mr. Ross has been appointed as industrial teacher, and we are looking for a principal who will be the Day School teacher as well as principal. Such we have not yet in view, and we have also the difficulty of having Ucluelet again vacant.

We are finding greater and greater difficulty in discovering suitable men, and we are exceedingly desirous of not employing men of poor qualifications. I think I can say that in the last few years the average of agents in our schools has risen considerably. We would like to employ none but competent men.

That is where we stand today, and in writing I recognise how important it is that you should have been kept acquainted with these facts, for it is your work even more than ours.

I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

RPM/NBA.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant in reference to certain changes made or contemplated by the Presbyterian Church in the management of schools conducted under its auspices in the West.

The transfer of Mr. Hendry to Alberni and of Mr. Millar from Ahousaht to Portage la Prairie was approved, and the Department trusts that each will meet in his new field with even a greater measure of success than in the old.

The appointment of Mr. Ross as industrial teacher at Ahousaht is also approved and, notwithstanding the difficulty experienced in securing the services of capable men, which the Department fully appreciates, it is hoped that you will before long be in a position to make the appointment of a capable person to the Principalship of this school. In the meantime it is presumed that Mr. Ross will take charge.

Rev. Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a report from its Inspector on the Portage la Prairie Boarding school which shows that, while excellent work is being done at this school, the building and surroundings are unsatisfactory. The Department is of opinion that the only way to overcome the difficulty referred to would be to erect a new building in a more suitable locality, and would like you to give this matter your serious consideration and submit your suggestions. It is thought that if the present building and site were disposed of enough might be obtained to go a long way towards erecting an up-to-date institution which would meet the needs of a school of this class.

In view of the Inspector's report the Department does not feel justified in going to any great expense in providing material for repairs to the old building, but there are some matters which should be attended to at once. There are no fire escapes on the building and something should be done to remedy this defect.

Mr. Millar is admitted to be an excellent Principal and, if better facilities were provided, his field of

Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sirs,-

I beg to report to the Department that during the second week in January we were visited by an epidemic of measles of a very virulent type which was followed by pneumonia. There were five cases of pneumonia and on January the 31st a little girl seven years old succumbed to the disease. We engaged a trained nurse and another officer on the staff to take Mrs. Hendry's work so that she could give all her time to the sick children as she is a graduate nurse but our best efforts was not enough to pull them all through.

Dr. Hasshard has been very kind and has visited the school almost daily since the outbreak. The little girl who died, Edith Chaske, had only been in school a month, but her mother was with her the week before her death.

We are still struggling along as best we can as many of the children do not seem to recover their normal condition and we are not yet safe with all our pneumonia cases.

Your obedient servant,

W. A. Hendry

Ottawa, May 31, 1912.

Mr. Pedley,

In reply to your inquiry I beg to say that there is now a boarding school at Portage la Prairie conducted under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church where provision is made for thirty-five pupils. The school is situated within the limits of the town of Portage la Prairie and the site comprises only two acres. The building is old and it will be necessary to erect a new one at an early date, as the present building cannot be remodelled to meet the requirements of the Department under the new contract. A suggestion was made to the Presbyterian Church in 1910 that they sell the present building and site and purchase a farm on which to erect a new building. Matters went so far as to choose the location, a farm of 250 acres about two miles from the town, and a sketch plan was prepared by the Rev. J. L. Miller, who was Principal last year. The Church wished the Department to erect the proposed new building.
On February 20th of last year Rev. D.F. MacKay was informed by the Department that it was not prepared to assume the cost of a new building and it was pointed out that it might be a good investment for the Church to do so and this drew the maximum grant of $125.00 instead of $100.00 that would be paid if the building were owned by the Department. On the 24th of that month Dr. MacKay replied giving his own personal views and pointing out a number of difficulties from the financial standpoint in the way. Nothing further has been done in the matter.

The Presbyterian Church is this year making extensive alterations and additions at Birtle and Cecilia Jeffrey, which will entail almost as much expenditure as the erection of new buildings, and they are also putting up a new building at Round Lake. I presume, therefore, that they will not, at present at least, be prepared to consider a new building at Portage la Prairie and no provision has been made by the Department in this year's estimates. This is where the matter stands at present. The first thing to be decided is who will assume the obligation. As the Presbyterian Church at present own all their boarding schools, I am of opinion that they will eventually decide to erect this building and thus control the ownership and obtain the maximum grant.
I have never been in favour of the purchase of a site at Portage la Prairie and the erection of a building to be owned by the Department. When I was at Portage la Prairie I went personally over several locations on which a school might be placed and the farm of 250 acres mentioned before is by far the best location. Your memorandum has been dealt with entirely as effecting the Presbyterian Church at Portage la Prairie. If the application is from another source I can only say that it would scarcely be possible for the Department to assist the establishment of another denominational school in that district, which has heretofore been recognized as the field of the Presbyterian Church.

Sir,

I beg to ask the Department if the grant for the Portage la Prairie Boarding School could be increased five pupils, from 35 to 40 pupils, until such times as they get into the new building.

There are now on the roll 41 pupils and there are three others signed to enter. The parents are bringing their children and they do not like it when they are not admitted.

Mr. Hendry the principal tells me that he can rent a house across the road directly in front of the school and that he is adding two more members to the staff. Ten of the small children can find splendid accommodation in this house, leaving only thirty in the school building for the winter months. The extra grant on the five pupils would pay for the rent of the house and help to provide for the pupils. They would thus secure a good start in their work and be broken in to school discipline before going into the new building.

I would very much like to see this grant increased five pupils since Mr. Hendry will provide the accommodation and the help to look after them.

Trusting to hear from the Department as soon as possible to enable Mr. Hendry to secure the house.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary.

Dear Dr. Grant,

I am favourable to organizing a nursing staff for your schools, but I do not think we could afford just now, to appoint a nurse for each school. I think it would be advisable to begin with one or at most two nurses for the four boarding schools in Manitoba and Saskatchewan, that is Portage la Prairie, Birtle, Crowstand and Round Lake. One of these nurses would always be available in cases of epidemics. If there were no diseases of an epidemic nature at the schools they could spend three or four months at each school in rotation. If this plan commends itself to you, we might see if we could engage the services of one or two nurses.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Andrew S. Grant, D.D.,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am very anxious, for the betterment of our Indian Boarding Schools, that the Government should make it possible for us to have a trained nurse in each one of these schools, to have general oversight and care of the children from a health point of view. I think that, if the Government would agree to such appointments, we could greatly increase the efficiency of the school, and improve, in every way, the health of the children, as you are aware that there are a great many skin diseases among these children, and other diseases that are contagious, and, for the safe guarding of the children, it is necessary that the greatest care should be taken in these boarding schools to prevent the spread of anything of this kind, and, if possible, to correct these conditions. We are striving, in every way, to improve the efficiency of these schools now, and hope that the Government will come to our assistance in this matter, as we are spending a great deal of money and time in this work.

I hope that you have given instructions regarding the
necessary improvements at the File Hills School.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

General Superintendent of Home Missions
Presbyterian Church in Canada.
Mr. D. C. Scott,
Indian Department,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Your letter of January 28th received. I appreciate very much your decision in the appointment of two nurses. I was hoping that you might go a little further and appoint a third, so that there would be no interprovincial jealousies, as far as these three Provinces are concerned. However, we will have to be thankful for what you have granted, and hope for favourable consideration of others later. Now, I am going to proceed at once to secure the names of two fully qualified nurses of the right type who would undertake this work, and, when I find them, I will submit the names to you for your approval, stating, as you set forth, the salaries allowed.

Yours very sincerely,

Andrew S. Grant
General Superintendent of Home Missions
Presbyterian Church in Canada.

A.S.G.-A.V.
Re nurses in Indian Boarding Schools

Mr. D. C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Your favour of January 20th received. If you would adopt the principle of providing a nurse for each of the Indian Boarding Schools, and agree, for the year 1914, to furnish three nurses for three of these schools, say Cecilia Jeffrey in Ontario, Birtle in Manitoba, and File Hills in Saskatchewan, (the first two named have been rebuilt by us, and the latter by you recently, and are equipped so that a nurse in these centres would be of great benefit, and could work to advantage, because the plant is there); then next year, when Round Lake, Portage la Prairie and Crowstand would have their new buildings, we might get the additional number required for these. My idea is that these nurses should be permanently a part of the staff, to look after the children with diseases that come into the school, not only skin diseases, but tubercular conditions, and also care for the health of the children in the school, insisting on habits of cleanliness and of health.
and having general care, especially of the girls. Where such service would be rendered, a great deal of sickness would be prevented, and better results would be obtained in the School, saving a great deal of expenditure in the way of drugs and medical attendance, and thus saving the Government money. I would like very much if you would arrange the matter on these lines, and let us select the nurse, subject, of course, to your approval, you fixing the salary to be paid, and then they would be part of our staff, and under the control of the Principal of the School.

Speaking as a medical man, I feel confident that this would be in the interests of the work, both from the standpoint of the Government and the Church. I hope you will see your way clear to follow my suggestion.

Thanking you for the interest that you have taken in this matter,

I am,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

General Superintendent of Home Missions
Presbyterian Church in Canada.

A.S.G.-A.V.

Dear Dr. Grant,

In further reference to your communication of the 21st instant, re appointment of nurses in Indian Boarding Schools, I beg to say that I have decided to try the experiment by appointing temporarily two nurses, one to be stationed at the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School where medical attendance is not readily available, and one to be appointed at Pile Hills Boarding School on the understanding that her services will also be available for given periods at Portage la Prairie and Round Lake.

I regret that the funds at my disposal will not permit me at present to go more extensively into this scheme, but, should experience show the wisdom of the move I shall be prepared at a later date to give the question of extension due consideration.

It is to be understood that these
two appointments are temporary, the continuance to depend upon results. Salary will be $600 per annum, the School authorities to provide food and lodging. When you are in a position to nominate graduate nurses for these positions I shall be pleased to have the names with full information respecting qualifications etc.

Yours very sincerely,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dr. A. S. Grant,
Superintendent Board of Home Missions,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
Confederation Life Building,
Toronto, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have been looking for trained nurses for File Hills and Cecilia Jeffrey, and think that in the Nursing At Home Mission here there are two nurses graduating in March that are admirably adapted for this work,—capable as nurses, with experience in Christian work as well, and I feel that we could have from this source exactly the combination that we want in these Boarding School, and hope that you will accept our judgment in this matter, and agree to our appointing two, one for Cecilia Jeffrey, and the other File Hills School, at once. Mr. Sweet speaks of the hospital that you have in the colony. Would it be possible, now that that is temporarily closed, that the nurse that was there would be available for this position? Dear Mr. Scott:

The standard that you have set up for the new Boarding Schools, where we furnish the buildings, or where you furnish them, as far as grade A is concerned, makes it absolutely impossible for us, after we have paid the salaries of the workers, to maintain the school on the Government grant, and there is coming to us from every quarter much dissatisfaction, and I feel that it would be absolutely necessary, if we are going on with this work, that the Government should increase the rate of the per capita grant to enable us to continue the work.
