Dear Mr. Scott:

Yours of March 19th, acknowledging the receipt of mine, received. Contract, or no contract, it is apparent that the Government will have to give some additional assistance for the maintenance of these larger schools, as they are now equipped, or, if I can judge the temperament of my Board, the possibility is that we will withdraw from these schools altogether. I know how you are situated, and that you are governed by certain regulations, and the enormous expenditure on the part of the Government for this work makes it difficult to meet the growing demands, but, if we are going to get results, we have to get more liberal support from the Government for these schools.

I am,

Yours very sincerely,

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department that the City fire brigade are pleased to be at the service of the new Indian School in course of construction at Portage la Prairie. They wish, however, that the Department supply 500 feet of 4 inch hose for use on the two outside hydrants. This would make it unnecessary for the City fire Department to take any hose out to the school should there be a call sent in, and in the meantime, the school could get the hose attached and turn the water on. Also, the brigade do not wish to have 500 feet of their hose so far away in case a fire should break out over town at the same time, as they require all their own hose at times.

Awaiting the Department's advice in the matter,

I am,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr Scott,

I was out to the new school today,
and they are getting on quite rapidly.

There was a notice in our local paper last night
(the clipping I herewith enclose) stating it was likely
the new Indian School might be used for the
troops. The general opinion among those who know,
how well the building is being finished, is that it
would not be good policy to use it for barracks, as
it would only serve this use, for say about six weeks.
I do not think it will be ready for any one before
the 1st of March anyway, and suppose the troops
will move to Dewell Camp about the 1st of May
where they camp every year.

I am of the opinion they would do the School more
damage in a month or so than for school work in
a year, or perhaps years, if they acted as they have
in the Armoury building, where our office is situated,
as they have certainly been going some at the Armoury.
It might be that they could get the old school,
which would accommodate for keeping.

Thus again, there is the agricultural buildings
on the fair grounds which could be made com-
fortable, the same as at Winnipeg and Brandon.
There are all kinds of buildings on the fair grounds
which could be used for heating.

Those who have seen the Armoury, say it would
do the school great injury, considering the short
time the troops would occupy it.

I considered it my duty to advise you regard-
ing the above.

Yours respectfully,

A. Hogan
Ind. Aff.

Senior Officer Receives Enquiry as to Accommodation—Details for Mobilization

An Ottawa dispatch says that Major-General Hughes has issued a statement explaining in detail the plan of mobilization to be followed in connection with the third contingent. The principle of decentralization will be followed more closely in the case of the first or second. In the case of the first, mobilization was conducted at the centralizing point; in the case of the third it will commence at local and company headquarters.

The statement is as follows: The mobilization of the second contingent is well advanced, and the third contingent is being raised and mobilized on the following system:

There are three classes of centres—recruiting, organizing and mobilization.

Recruiting centres will be at every company and squadron headquarters, or at any town or centre in the battalion district. Recruiting officers will visit these places at regular periods if no officers are already there.

The organization centre will be where the company or squadron units will be located. The recruits on being selected in the various localities for the company will be sent to these organizing centres promptly.

These will be billeted. Receiving an allowance, they will be under control of their officers and may be uniformed, equipped and drilled. The local active militia company officers of all ranks are expected to take active interest as recruiting officers, each for his own company, and the men recruited from each locality should be entered on the local active militia company roll before being forwarded to the organizing or company centre. When each company is organized it will be forwarded under its officers to the mobilizing centre for the whole battalion. Officers of all ranks, both of the active militia and those selected for the overseas force are each and all expected to take personal interest in this organizing and the success or failure in any active militia officers in these localities.

Minnie Report

Indian School Portage La Prairie.
May 31st, 1915.

During the past month we have had an epidemic of Rubella; ten children were in quarantine, the last two being released this morning. All bathrooms & lavatories & the school in general are kept in a sanitary condition so the disease cannot have been carried to us by visitors.

Four girls have had infected eyes bathed with Boracic sol., Argent sol. & treated with Ointment.

Three girls and one boy have enlarged glands painted with Dodine daily.

One child has a chronic suppurating ear syringed and treated with Boracic daily. Another had a slight attack of tonsillitis but recovered quickly after using Saline gargle.

The new children who have come to us were all Reducible, these all had to be bathed & treated with ointment. Another boy has had two elevated teeth extracted & is receiving a tonic & extra nourishment.

There has also been numerous minor dressings for cuts & burns, and with the exception of four or five every child receives God's Blessing & learning.

Mrs Anna Bolton.
Ottawa, 9th June, 1915.

Povesh Report

Portage La Prairie Indian School,
June 30th 1915.

Another case of Varicella developed during June but recovered speedily; we have had also one case of Diphtheria, one of Influenza, one of Bronchitis, one of Stomach Complaints, one of Tubercular Gonorrhea and one with a growth on his eye. He will be under the Doctor's care for some time yet; the others are recovered having been treated with Sprays, Liniment, Tonics, Antitoxin & Ointment.

There is always the administering of Tonics & Tonics dressing infected fingers and airing & disinfecting classrooms.

The work would be much more effective and convenient if we had two cupboards, one at each end of the building supplied with a few instruments, so would like to ask the Department if it would be possible for them to supply: Mixing Trays, Dressing Forceps, Probes, Speculas, Scalpels, Dressing-basins, Bass-basins and wash-basins that the children may be kept separate.

Mrs Anna Bolton.
Ottawa, 13th July, 1915.

Rev. Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 1st instant, and the communication which you enclosed from Miss Bolton, Nurse, Portage la Prairie Boarding School; and in reply I beg to say that the Department requires a definite recommendation from you with regard to her request for two cupboards, one at each end of the building in which to hold supplies; and also with respect to her request for artery and dressing forceps, dressing basins, etc. You should give an estimate in detail of the probable cost, not only of providing the cupboards but also the instruments, etc., asked for by the nurse and you should state whether you consider the same are required. I may say that the Department is not prepared to incur any expense of an unnecessary character.

With respect to the nurse's remarks on the cases treated, I may say that the same have been read with interest, but it would be more satisfactory if she had also given information of a general character with regard to the health of the pupils of the school.

Your obedient servant,

Sirs,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the Department's letter No. 119,469-1 dated July the 13th, 1915, in reference to Nurse Bolton's monthly report for June, in which she made a request for medicinal cupboards and instruments etc.,

In reply I beg to say that she has no place to put anything in the way of medicines on the first floor flat where the hospitals are situated. Two medicine cupboards one for the boys hospital and one for the girls hospital would save the nurse many a walk to the next floor below on which the dispensary is situated. These cupboards can be made 4 feet 6 inches high by 24 inches wide with two doors and nicely stained for $8.00 each possibly a little less. If the Department see their way clear to grant these cupboards I shall send an itemized account of the cost.

Regarding the Nurse's request for dressing instruments and dressing basins, I beg to say that we can purchase the latter ourselves and we are so near the Doctor that we do not need the dressing instruments.

I have asked the nurse to make her report more general in character which I trust she will be able to do.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Logan forwards eight applications for admission to the Portage la Prairie Boarding School.

The return for the June quarter showed that they had 55 pupils then enrolled at this school. Four have been admitted since and the eight additional applications sent in by Mr. Logan would bring the enrolment up to 67. Sixty pupils are allowed for at this school from the first of April, last, prior to that date the grant was only paid for 40. If the eight applications sent in by Mr. Logan are approved the enrolment will overrun the appropriation by seven.

On the 26th of April, last, you instructed Mr. Logan to visit the reserves in company with the Principal and try and persuade the Indians to send a number of their children to this school. These last applications are the result of Mr. Logan's recruiting efforts and, as the school has accommodation for 75 pupils, will you authorize the admission of these children and allow the school to recruit up to its capacity.

[Signature]

Rev. Sir,-

Dear Sir,

I have just returned from the west where I spent a few days at the new Indian School at Portage La Prairie, and thought I would like to send a note of appreciation for what the Department has done in the building of the Indian School.

I have visited schools in all parts of the west and can truly say the one at Portage

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
is the best planned School I have ever seen in. I could not suggest any improvement that could be added that comes from my knowledge and experience of public building of the same kind. Please do not think I am finding any fault—just say suggested an improvement would be added another School. As I understand of one large furnace you put in two small ones it would not suit as for the comfort of the whole but a great saving I feel. I know the system efficiency in my own home and in several institutions with which I have been connected by being on the main street Road. In the early spring and late fall our furnace was sufficient to heat the living rooms and make all comfortable without heating all the house where heat was not needed. I must congratulate you on the thorough perfect arrangement of the school. Perhaps you will remember the four ladies who met you and Mr. Reddy in conference came from So. and you thought you said her name first—in the present letter it was—"be keen as many complaints—must get little credit for that—we try to do. I hope you will accept my hearty appreciation of what you have done for the Indians by building
Such a school at Portage la Prairie and not take my own children as it was meant to be. Any helpful suggestions acting kindness for this long letter.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Miss Craig,

First Report of Portage La Prairie Indian School.

Indian School,
Portage La Prairie,
Aug 30th 1915.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I beg to present the following report:

The children of the Portage La Prairie Boarding School are as a whole in good health; on returning from their vacation they were all treated for lice and bathed. There are still under treatment for intestinal troubles. One child had an infected hand treated with antiseptic dressings for a week but is quite recovered now; there has also been numerous minor treatments for bronchitis, coughs, colds etc. The weather is very hard too making it necessary to use precautions for the prevention of sickness.

I am instituting sanitary bags for the older girls, & supervising the cleaning of Bathrooms & Lavatories.

One of the children while playing went with an accident & had to have three sutures in a wound over her eye, but is playing again now.

There also one case of whooping cough & am endeavouring by isolation to prevent its spread through the school.

Rose Anna Bolton.
Indian Boarding School,
Portage la Prairie,

September 7th, 1915.

Sirs,-

I beg to herewith enclose Nurse Bolton's report for the month of August, 1915.

I beg to draw the Department's notice to the statement that the hardness of the water is causing scrofula. Our water supply is filtered from the Assiniboine river, and is soft when compared with water taken from artesian wells. We have only one girl in school who has glands sufficiently enlarged to be noticed and no scrofula.

I would like to have this point referred to Dr Harvey Hassard the Department's medical officer in charge of the school as he would know if the water was causing scrofula.

Trusting that my suggestion is not out of place and if so that you will kindly overlook it.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,

Dear Mr. McLean:

With reference to the payment of the salaries of nurses in our Indian Boarding Schools, would you see that the moneys for this purpose are forwarded monthly to the Treasurer of our Church, so that we may pay the salaries of these nurses directly from our office, as we do in the case of all other workers. While these cheques are made out by us to the individuals, they pass through the hands of the Principal of the school rather than go directly to the worker. I hope you may be able to comply with this request, as confusion has arisen because of the other method.

I understand that an allowance of $60 a month is made by the Government in the case of the Cecilia Jeffrey School. The same ought to apply in the case of other schools as well, but the amounts in all cases should be sent direct to the Treasurer here.

Yours very sincerely,

A.S.G.-A.V.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter No 119469-1 I beg to state that it is ridiculous that Nurse Bolton should state "that hardness of the water is causing scrofula". The hardness of water will not cause scrofula.

After receiving your letter I inspected the school and found that each child is particularly free from any skin affection. On questioning the Nurse what she meant by her letter, I found that it looked as if she had no foundation for making such a report.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Boarding School
Portage la Prairie
Man.

3rd May, 1916

Nurse's Report.

The health of the children for the month of April has been very good indeed. We have had no cases of any serious illness.

But my treatment list I have 16 names. Six of these girls who are having a building up tonic work as a preventive than cure. The other ten are having simple dressings done, coughs, ears etc attended to.

The boys have specially enjoyed splendid health, not one case of illness among them.

Every morning the dormitories are thoroughly ventilated while the beds are being made; the lavatories also are well aired.

The children are taken for a walk every day between 4-6 p.m. weather permitting. Days we can not take them out we open the veranda doors and let them play outside.

Isabel W. King (Nurse)
Indian Boarding School,
Portage la Prairie.

Sirs,

I beg to inform the Department that nurse Hughes, the resident nurse on the staff of the school, was called to Winnipeg owing to the dangerous condition of her gentleman friend who was sent home from France recently. He was buried by a shell during the Battle of the Somme in August and instead of getting better after reaching Winnipeg he is getting worse.

Nurse Hughes sent Miss Estella Clark, to take her place in the meantime. Miss Clark is a graduate of a Scotch hospital, has had a large experience and is very capable.

I trust that this will meet with the approval of the Department.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

I beg to ask the Department if it would be possible to increase the grant to the Portage la Prairie School by 10 or 15 pupils. The Inspector thought that the accommodation would stand for this increase as he compared it with Brandon school. We could use the four monitor rooms, the sleeping balconies and the sick rooms for most of the time, for sleeping accommodation.

The school at Ahousaht is now closed and possibly we could get part of their grant.

I have nine pupils signed up over and above my 75 which I am allowed grant on at present. I am sure we could get 10 or 12 more from the Long Plain reserve which is only fourteen miles away.

An extra grant of even ten pupils would help me through financially until the war is over. It would be a very great help.

Should the Department see wise to give this increase I shall be indeed greatly obliged.

I remain,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary.

Ottawa, Ont.,

Ottawa, October 19th, 1918.

A. Ogletree, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Serious matter to break up boarding school. Like to know reason for recommendation. If influenza in school sending children home would communicate it to reserve, could not school be quarantined? What does Hendry think? Give matter further consideration and wire me.

Duncan C. Scott.
Sir,

In your telegram of the 19th instant, I beg to say that in suggesting closing of the Indian School here it was only a precautionary measure; there are some 76 pupils in this school and if the influenza broke out it would be impossible to take care of these children with the present help and it would be impossible to get outside help; there are several cases of influenza in the City and is spreading, several doctors are down with it, Dr. Nassard our own doctor is down with the disease and seven of the nurses in the Hospital.

I consulted the Mayor and Medical Officer of the City and both advised sending the children home for a short time until the danger was over as the children would have a better chance in the open than they would closed up together.

The influenza has not broken out in the school yet but will be only a short time until it does as it is spreading very fast in the City, there were 10 new cases reported last night and Mr. Hendry the Principal is very anxious to be relieved of the responsibility of the serious situation and the parents of the children are very anxious to have the children home.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-1, part 1)
I cannot see it is a serious matter to close the school for a short time as the pupils will return when the danger is over, in any case it would be better to close the school for a short time than to have the disease break out and loose a number of children then the Indians would blame the authorities for not allowing their children to come home.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Department.

D. G. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

When the Department's order came saying that we could let the children out until the Flu was over nearly all the Reserves were under quarantine and only 21 of the small children were let go home on reserves where there was no Flu. So far we are free while all the institutions in Portage have the disease, the Provincial School for boys has 65 cases and the institution had to be managed by help from Winnipeg. We put a quarantine on before any cases came to Portage and I am the only one who leaves the building.

I beg to refer to the Department's letter dated December 24th, 1918, No. 119469-1, in connection with pupil No. 975, Amy Young of the Portage la Prairie Boarding School.

The girl was sent home with her mother where she will be well cared for in every way.

This girl is not a bad girl at all but Edward Pashe who has acknowledged being responsible for the girl's condition is a bad character in every way. He has seen six months of jail, was very abusive to his wife and was a threatening sort of a character.

The authorities think it best to make him pay for the keep of the child and this will be done as soon as the child is born.

Regarding the discharge of the girl I beg to ask the Department if they think it wise to bring the girl back to school after the child is born and leave her here until she is nineteen or twenty years old. If she leaves school now, not yet sixteen years old and in this condition, she will not have a fair chance to keep right. On the other hand, if she is brought back until she is twenty years old, the past will be forgotten, she will have developed independence of mind, and she might turn out a very good woman.

I remain,

Your obedient servant,

CANADA
FALL ASSIZES, 1919.

Portage la Prairie, Man., November 6, 1919.

To His Lordship, Chief Justice Mathers:

May it please your Lordship:

We, the Grand Jury of the Portage la Prairie Fall Assizes for the year 1919, beg leave to submit the following report:

But first, we wish to thank your Lordship for your magnificent address, especially as to the advice as to the duty of everyone to assist their country as much as possible in every way to get back to normal conditions, and we trust that the sentiments of your address will bear fruit. We also wish to thank the Crown Prosecutor, Mr. Card, for his assistance, and congratulate him on the fair and concise way each indictment was laid before us. We have had under our consideration nine indictments, for all of which we have returned True Bills.

According to your instructions we have visited the various public buildings as follows:

The Provincial Gaol.

We were escorted through the gaol by sheriff R. H. Home and turnkey Mr. Thompson, who showed us every courtesy and assistance. We interviewed every prisoner in the gaol and were pleased to find only eleven male prisoners incarcerated and no females, five of these prisoners being aliens. In no case were there any complaints.

We understand that some years ago better ventilation of the prisoners' cells was recommended by the Grand Jury, but so far there is nothing done. We recommend that an electric exhaust fan be placed over the door at the west end of the corridor, which would draw off the foul air and give good circulation throughout.

We recommend that the pump pit in the boiler room be enlarged, there not being sufficient room to work at the machinery properly in the present state. Further, that the pit should be deepened at least two feet to allow for proper drainage as there is some...
Difficulty in drawing off the condensed steam throughout the building.

The Hospitals.

We next visited the Hospital and the Jury were conducted through the whole building by Supt. Miss Purvis and Head Nurse Miss Ronnie. At present there are only sixteen patients, eight male and eight female, which in comparison with the same date last year when there were 52 patients, shows the City and District are to be congratulated on the improved health condition. The wards throughout are everything that could be desired and show every care and are certainly a great credit to Miss Purvis and her staff. The Jury were pleased to note that the new laundry building and equipment, separate from the Hospital, is nearly completed. This improvement has been required for many years.

Home for Incurables.

At the Home for Incurables we were met by Asst. Supt. Mr. McKinnon, and Matron Mrs. Campbell. The whole building was thoroughly inspected and everything was found in excellent condition so far as the management and care of the inmates was concerned. We wish to congratulate Mrs. Campbell and her assistants on the splendid, systematic, and businesslike way the Institution is conducted. There are in the Home for Incurables one hundred and fifty-five male patients and ninety female, and in the Old Folks' Home forty-eight male and thirty-six female patients.

The Jury would recommend that all of the floors in the rooms now housing the idiots and imbeciles should be covered by non-absorbent cement or tile, as they are at present far from sanitary, and it is utterly impossible for the attendants to make it so. The children's playroom and dormitories are lamentably overcrowded and we ascertained that with the present building accommodation it is impossible to improve matters. The matron informed us that in the Old Folks' Home and in the Home for Incurables, there is not a single empty cot.

We also wish to draw the attention of the authorities to the fact that the buildings at present have no adequate fire protection, as the hydrants are only supplied from a six-inch main, which could...
only supply two streams and which would be absolutely useless should a building of this size catch fire, and in case of a break in this main, which is constructed of wood pipe, the whole water supply would be cut off. Even for sanitary purposes it is a very serious matter for an institution of this kind, and we would recommend that an eight-inch iron main be laid from the pumping station, up Campbell St., and connected with the other line, and necessary valves placed so in case of a break either line can be used, or in case of a fire an abundant supply of water be had. There being nearly four hundred souls in this house, under the circumstances should a fire occur and for want of sufficient water lives be lost, somebody would be criminally liable.

Farm Buildings.

The Farm Superintendent showed us over the outbuildings; the stock was only in fair condition; the dairy cows were not as clean as they should be, and show lack of care. Of course, we do not know whether the assistance is sufficient there or not. There is certainly ample room for improvement.

In 1916 the Grand Jury recommended that the stables be painted both inside and out. It is still anything but a credit to the Institution. We have ascertained that 2 years ago sufficient paint was purchased for this purpose, but the said paint is still in the basement of the building, and we would recommend that it be put to its proper purpose in the spring. The litter-carrier in the stable has been out of order for months and should be repaired at once, as the present mode of doing the work is most inconvenient and entails great loss of time. We understand that there have been plans made for some time for a laundry to be built away from the main building. This, in our estimation, should be done at an early date, the present one being divided up into three separate rooms, and therefore very inconvenient for the work to be done efficiently, besides, where it is at present operated is very unsanitary.

Indian Schools.

Mr. Hendry the Sup't, and Mrs. Hendry the Matron, showed the Jury around this Institution with great pride, for which they have every reason. It certainly is a credit to themselves and staff.
There are 75 pupils in the school and we understand they are all anxious to learn. The only recommendation we have to make in this instance is that the walls and interior of this building, principally the basement, should be given a coat of paint, as apparently nothing has been done since the building was erected.

Industrial School:

We then visited the Industrial Training School, and under the guidance of Supt. McKinnon and Matron Mrs. Robinson the Jury made a thorough inspection. In the building at date there are 91 boys, 19 of whom came from Alberta. We found everything in a satisfactory condition, and it is quite evident all through the building that Mrs. Robinson the Matron is doing excellent work. The trades now being taught are Cabinet-making, Baking, Laundry work, Tailoring, Sewing. Shoemaking and Blacksmithing seem to have been discontinued. The shoe-making instructor is now only occupied in repairing the boys' boots. We think this is a mistake and that the latter two trades should continue to be taught. The stables and outbuildings were then visited and Supt. McBride showed the Jury through the buildings, and the Jury were one and all unanimous in their praise of the condition of both horses and cattle, and great credit is due to the individuals in charge and to the boys who ably assist them. We noticed in the root-houses the splendid and abundant assortment of vegetables which were produced in the gardens by Mr. Colin Newman. The amount of produce per acre shows that the land must have been brought into a very high state of cultivation.

In connection with the cattle stable we find the Supt. very much handicapped as there is neither steam nor hot-water connected, and would recommend that a large size feed boiler be installed there or that the authorities adhere to their original plan. We also find that the gardener is still very much cramped for room, the present conservatory not being adapted for plant-raising, and further, it is located at the extreme limit of the pipe-line. There should be a 30 x 40 greenhouse built immediately off the power-house, where sufficient plants could be raised for all the public buildings, and it could be built by the employees of the Institution.

We further recommend, as was recommended in 1916, to the proper

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
authorities for their due consideration, that the farms of both the institutions should be taken out of the hands of the Superintendents and placed entirely under the jurisdiction of the Minister of Agriculture, as we consider that the superintendents are sufficiently busy without attending to the operation of the farms.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

(Signed) R. H. H. Pratt,
Foreman.

Health report for September 1920.

On Sept. 14th one of the boys had hemorrhage from the lungs, he recovered all right and was out again in a week. Doctor visited twice.

EXTRACTED FROM THE MINUTES OF THE MEETING
OF
THE BOARD OF HOME MISSIONS AND SOCIAL SERVICE.
March 30 - April 6, 1921.

"An overture from the Presbytery of Portage la Prairie, supported by the Synodical Committee of Manitoba,

'strongly urged the Board of Home Missions and Social Service to immediately approach the Government, and press upon the Government the advantage of increasing the accommodation of the Indian School at Portage la Prairie, to a minimum capacity of 180 pupils.'

On motion of Dr. Edmison, seconded by Rev. A.C. Strachan, it was agreed to forward the request to the Government."

[Signature]
General Secretary.
"In Winnipeg, and within Manitoba College there, on the 8th day of March, 1921, the Synodical Committee on Home Missions and Social Service met.

Inter alia:-

An Overture from the Presbytery of Portage la Prairie re the Indian School enlargement, was read and considered. It was agreed to heartily endorse the Overture, and to unite with the Presbytery of Portage la Prairie in urging our Board of Home Missions and Social Service to take the matter up with the Government at once, and press for the increase of accommodation suggested."
"To the Board of Home Missions and Social Service, Presbyterian Church.

WHEREAS compulsory education of Indian children has been decided upon by the Government of Canada, as set forth in the 1920 amendment to the Indian Act, Ch. 50, making it imperative upon the Government to increase Indian School accommodation within the Province of Manitoba, and

WHEREAS Portage la Prairie, on account of its geographical situation, is the most advantageous point in the Province for recruiting Indian children, and

WHEREAS already the school at Portage la Prairie has established friendly relations with the Indians upon Reserves at Portage la Prairie, Long Plains, Griswold, Swan Lake, Gypsumville, Roseau, Pequis, Hodson, and Dog Creek, from which pupils must in the future be drawn, and

WHEREAS pupils without canvas are applying for admission to the Portage la Prairie School, quite beyond the capacity of the present School to accommodate, and

WHEREAS the Government has already made large expenditure in establishing and equipping the Indian School at Portage la Prairie, and has recently added 125 acres to the farm connected with that School, affording sufficient acreage for farm work and instruction for a much larger number of pupils than can attend at present, and

WHEREAS Mr. and Mrs. Hendry, the experienced Principal and Matron of the Portage la Prairie School have long since proved
their capacity for and adaptation to the work of Indian education, as well as ability for much larger service, and have throughout the history of the School maintained a very high order of efficiency along education and moral lines, and throughout the period of financial depression have conducted the School with rare financial success, and have been able to add largely to the equipment of the School from surpluses accumulated during this period, and

WHEREAS it would be proportionately easier for Church and State to provide facilities for 75 additional pupils at a point where the work is well established than to create a new centre-

The Presbytery of Portage la Prairie, having taken the whole situation into careful consideration, would strongly urge the Board of Home Missions and Social Service to immediately approach the Government, and press upon the Government the advantage of increasing the accommodation of the Indian School at Portage la Prairie to a minimum capacity of 150 pupils, and to pledge the Government to support the work to the full extent required by the Government from the Church to adequately carry on the work from the educational, moral and religious standpoints, and in every way perform the duties devolving upon the Church, where Church and State co-operate for Indian uplift.

Extracted from the Records of Portage la Prairie Presbytery, by-

P. E. Scott,
Acting Clerk."
Ottawa, May 6, 1921.

Dear Dr. Scott:

At the recent meeting of the Executive of our Board, we had before us the following Resolution from the Presbytery of Portage La Prairie; re the work of Rev. Mr. Ross, who is engaged in doing follow-up work in the vicinity of Portage La Prairie. I thought you would be interested to learn how our experiment at this point is working out. We have felt for some time that a good deal of the work in our Schools has been lost because so little has been done on the Reserves.

"The Presbytery of Portage La Prairie having heard the report of the opening of the Indian Church on Long Plains Reserve, and having heard of the encouragement which our missionary, Mr. Ross, is receiving in winning the favor of this Indian band, which has defied former efforts to evangelize, desire to record our gratitude to the King and Head of the Church for the success that has attended Mr. Ross' efforts. We would further, for the encouragement of our Home Mission Board, mention Mr. Ross' statement that his work would have been a failure had it not been for the foundation laid in the character of the younger Indians by the work of the Indian Industrial School at Portage La Prairie, and assure them that no mistake has been made in the appointing of Mr. Ross to this particular work."

Yours sincerely,

JHE/HC

Reverend Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 6th instant, in which you inform the Department that Miss M. McKay, who possesses a second class professional certificate, has been engaged as teacher at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to inform you that the Department does not require notice in connection with the appointment of officers to the staff at a residential school. We rely on the church authorities to select suitable incumbents and have no consent to make, unless inspectors or others report unsatisfactory services. The Department wishes to have nominations in the case of teachers at Indian day schools and principals of Indian residential schools, but the selection of workers at residential schools is left to the management.

Your obedient servant,

Regina, Sask. Sept 11th, 1925.

Sir,

My next visit was to the Portage la Prairie School. It is needless for me to say very much about this school as you know what it is like. It certainly is an excellent institution and a credit to any community. I think the Department is very fortunate having a man like Mr. Hendry at the head of this institution. The school is situated close to the city of Portage la Prairie, and unless it was properly managed we would come in for a great deal of criticism, as there are some the best farmers in the vicinity at this point, and everyone of any note who comes to Portage la Prairie is brought out to see the Indian school and its surroundings. They had just commenced threshing when I arrived. This year they have everything under crop + no summerfallow whatever. Mr. Hendry is under the impression that he can farm the land successfully without summerfallow by rotating the crops. For instance, this year he has about 15 acres in potatoes and about 12 acres in corn. He intends putting this into wheat next year, and the ground he has in wheat this year is to be sown with potatoes and corn next year. In fact, he grows everything on this farm that it is possible to grow here in the West. I say some of the finest pumpkins, vegetable marrow and squash that I have ever seen. He also expects to thresh about 7,000 bushels of grain. What wheat he had threshed when I was there was running about 30 bushels to the acre and graded No.2. The whole place looks more like an experimental farm than an Indian boarding school, and the beauty of it is that the work is all done by the Indian boys. The only men around the place are Mr. Hendry and one other man. I must say I always find it a great pleasure to visit this institution. Mr. Hendry is thoroughly practical, and my only regret is that we have not more men of his stamp at the head of Indian boarding schools. I would say that it would do some of the other principals a great deal of good to spend a day or so with Mr. Hendry at the school, and see how he handles the affairs of the institution. The school was filled to capacity, and I believe three or four over the amount the grant calls for, as he has no trouble in recruiting.
Continued-----------

recruiting all the children he can handle. This school is in an excellent financial condition, having several thousands of dollars to its credit, and with this year's crop another large surplus will be added. While I was there I made arrangements for the building of the addition to the chicken house and the implement shed.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

EDUCATIONAL WORK CONTINUED

RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.—This school is under the Presbyterian Mission, with Mr. W.A. Hendry, as Principal and Mrs. Hendry, as Matron, whose capabilities as teacher and matron admit of little improvement. Mr. and Mrs. Hendry are devoted to their work, and know the Indian character well and does everything in their power for the welfare of the pupils, who have the good fortune to be admitted to this school. They are assisted by a competent staff, comprising an Asst. Matron, Nurse, two Teachers, Dietitian, Seamstress, Farm Instructor etc., number of pupils on Register 92 with average attendance 92. The work of this school during the year has been very satisfactory, the attendance has been always over the number allowed (90).

If there was enough room the Attendance of this school could be raised to 120 pupils. The work of the class room has been well done, and the pupils have made good progress. There has been very little sickness during the year, but one pupil died last November, she was taken to the Hospital and received the best of care but nothing could be done for her, with the exception of this one, the pupils have enjoyed good health. Dr. George A. Hassard is medical adviser for this school.

The work on the farm was very successful, and the Wheat crop was 1800 bushels. Oats 2000 bushels. Barley 1000 bushels Potatoes 2000 bushels and 100 tons of Corn and vegetables of all kind for house use.

The discipline of this school is all that could be looked for and the pupils are happy, contented and obedient and try to do the very best possible to make progress with their work and studies.

The finances of this school are in good shape and are closing the year with a good balance to the credit of this school and a good stock of provisions and fuel on hand.

Sgd by pat [signature]

Portage la Prairie, Man. - Feb. 17th 1927

We the people of the Sioux Village of Portage la Prairie called a meeting tonight just for the purpose of looking into matter of the decision that was handed out between the Continuing Presbyterian and United Church in Indian work in the Province of Manitoba by the Commission.

First of all we would like to call your attention to take fully into consideration and look into this matter carefully and would like you to settle this matter which would make things easy for us and our children.

It was about the year 1852 when the Presbyterian people seen us wandering around like wild beasts in this country. Some nice kind ladies didn't like the way we were at the time so in that year they started a Mission work among us Sioux Indians just north of the City of Portage la Prairie, in a tent. When they got things going nicely they told us that they were going to teach us how to read and write English also.

Well, ever since then we have been loyal to the cause of the Presbyterian Church. This Church was really the one that built the Church and our Indian School in the first place. When you come to find out the facts, start plain, it is starting back from 1852, 45 years ago, we have been having church service every Sunday, our children going to school. Instead of 35 years there has been three different generations in both church and school service, starting from 1852 up till today, a long way off before the other Reserves start in church and school service.

We have been told by Mr W.A Hendry the Principal of the Indians that all our children will be turn out of the school and sent to some other school. To this point we do not believe it and will not stand for it. To this point we wish to say that in case of sickness both us and our children it is very hard proposition for us to bear as we have no money to go and see our children if they get sick when they are put in some other school. Some of the parents of the pupils are old and some are widows. What will they do in case of sickness when their youngsters are taken away?

In the next case the reason why we call on the Presbyterian people to take charge of church service, we did not have any service in our church for 15 years, starting from 1914 to 1927 but only 25 Sundays in the 13 years, all this work was in charge of Mr W.A Hendry the Principal of the School but he only carried out half of his work and got paid for it all.

In December 10, 1926 of last year was the day appointed by Govt to take a vote for the Union but to this we did not know a thing about it until later in the year. In this month of May 1927, five weeks later after the set date for the church voting, he taking up votes, going around the people to vote for whom making them promise for six weeks.

After he got the votes he did not carry out any of his promises at all, not even one promise that he made in the village.

At Long Plain Reserve he tried to take a vote on the Church but he was turn down and turn out of the Reserve altogether. He than asked them if they want Mr Ross to come and take charge of their Church service, to this they voted "Yes" not knowing what church he said Mr Ross belong. He made out his report that they were not for Union when they really did not vote for Union because they don't know it yet. To this point we would like your department to take it serious and look into it carefully. The Long Plain Indian Reserve are in favor with us and want us to make the appeal against the decision about the school settlement. We hold us we have more to say in the school settlement because we were the ones that started it, both church and school, 35 years ago with the Presbyterian Church.

The last point of all we wish to tell you that we are loyal to our country, way back in 1812 our grandfathers fought under the British flag against the United States. In 1895 our same tribe fought under the flag against the French halfbreeds in the west, called the North West Rebellion.

In 1914 the time of the Great war, 6 of our boys offered their service for over seas but we are sorry to say that only two out of the eight went ov seas, the rest of us that stayed at home both young and old, women and men, took up collections in money, handed them over to the Red Cross fund to help the boys who were over seas during the war, not only our boys but to all.

So this show that we all stand loyal to our country, our both flags, British and Canadian, our Church and last of all, our school. So we wish to ask your kindness from your Department to have this school turn over to the Continuing Presbyterian Church where we can have our children.

Sir:

The Department has received a petition signed by Councillors Peter Ross, John Posha and John Chaske, of the Sioux Village of Portage la Prairie, in which they state they have been informed that, as the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School has been placed under the auspices of the United Church in Canada and as they, themselves, have remained members of the Presbyterian Church, their children will be removed from the school and sent to other schools.

I have to request that you will explain to these people that there will be no change as regards the attendance of their children and that there is no intention of having them removed from the Portage la Prairie School and sent away to other schools. You should use your utmost endeavours to assure these Indians that there will be no change in the present arrangements insofar as the providing of educational facilities for the education of their children is concerned. You might let me have a report in this connection.

Dear Sirs:

Many of the Indians from the Sioux Village South of the town are coming to me about a list of names which they claim was sent to The Department of Indian Affairs, with many names on it which they claim were put on without their consent. If such a list reached the Department would it be possible for me to secure a copy of same?

There are only 98 people in the Sioux Village and 34 of these are fourteen years of age and under. Of the remaining 64 forty signed up to remain with the United Church leaving only 24 to go Continuing. Therefore if the list has forty or more names on it one cannot understand how it can be bonifide.

There are only Seven pupils in school from the Sioux Village and Six of them are the children of United Church parents with one pupil of Continuing Presbyterian parentage.

Thanking you for a copy of the list if such reached Ottawa.

I am, Very truly yours,

W. A. Neudorf
Prin.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, March 18, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to a petition which reached the Department concerning the future management of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. A writing, dated the 17th ultimo and signed by Peter Ross, John Posha and John Chaske as Councillors of the Sioux Village Reserve, was directed to Ottawa. They asked that the school be handed over to the Continuing Presbyterian Church, so that their children would not be sent away to a distant institution. I wrote Mr. Indian Agent Ogilvie, directing him to inform these Sioux Village petitioners that there would be no change concerning the attendance of their children. In the second communication to our representative, I stated in part as follows: "If the parents make application for their children to the local institution, they will receive the same favourable consideration as heretofore."

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.,
October 7, 1930.

A word about the effect on the school of lowering the discharge age from the 18th to the 16th birthday.

I have found the discipline more difficult at the ages of 14 and 15 years than at 16 and 17 years. There is less logic and more impulse in their mental workings; they will run away from school more readily and fall for acts of immorality. Their breakages are very much higher, have not much definiteness of aim in their work, are less polite to teachers, more disobedient and less truthful. It is strangely wonderful how Indian children will clear up especially in the 17th year. Every instinct to get away from all routine and the four walls of the building seems to be at its highest point in the 14th and 15th years.

At 17 and 18, they are more steady and are a great help to the discipline of the school, if one gives them an opportunity to take charge of a task with other children under them. They are a very great factor in discipline if carefully managed.

Again, when the boys receive their discharge at the end of the 15th year the value of the training they receive in farm work is very little when compared with those who remain in school to the end of the 17th year. At an Indian plowing match with over forty entries the four best plowmen on the field were four of our school graduates. There are good men who never have been in school but the farmers on the plains say that the school boys are rounded off in their work and can do anything on the farm. We cannot give this finish to boys of 14 and 15 at all. A boy of fourteen years is not fit mentally to work a four-horse team unless they are plugs and no one can do good work with such horses. We formerly thought a boy of 15 was too young to put with a four-horse team. We only gave them four horses for the first in the 16th year. The same can be said about the training of the girls, in cooking, sewing, ironing, general housework. We do not expect much from our own children beyond their class-room work at the ages of 14 and 15 years. We should expect less from Indian children. We have a history and tradition in work and economy entirely absent in the Indian but we make their children work heavier. The breakages and dangers of accidents and mishaps working with farm machinery and school equipment are greatly increased with the employment of these young children as compared with the older ones of 16 and 17 years of age. They are not able for the heavy work either on the farm or in the school. The trend of the residential schools will inevitably become more academic and less industrial as the Indians are already complaining about the children having to work too much.

The Meriam report of the U.S.A. Indian work uses very strong language about overworking children in their schools. They say "that no industrial work should be done by children until they reach the 15th year and that it is done because the small amount of money allowed for food and clothes makes it necessary to use child labour." (Page 375) and their grant is $270.00 per capita against our $160.00. The report further states, "The labour of children as carried on in Indian Boarding Schools would, it is believed, constitute a violation of child labour laws in most States." (Page 376)

It is a very difficult problem to get the work of an institution done with some 14 girls and 10 boys on the half day plan. There is the cooking, mending, laundry work, general housework and dormitories for over 100 including...
staff, the care of the lavatories, wash rooms and three floors of over 9000/ft² to be scrubbed and kept clean. It means only seven girls in the morning and seven in the afternoon, 14 and 15 years old to do the work, and we receive a circular letter from Regina (No 120, Copy enclosed) telling us that these 14 and 15 year old girls must learn to milk cows, make butter, bake bread and do garden work. The Inspectors will carefully inquire into these matters and report etc., A girl at this age is physically at her lowest, it is her adolescence period. All the 16 and 17 year old girls are on the reserve, where some have cows and there is a farm instructor on most reserves, and the girls have next to nothing to do in house work, or any other kind of work. These young girls in school have too much to do as it is.

Coming to our second question - an increase in the per capita grant. The grants in Canada are not entirely standardized. I think there is a difference in a few dollars in some of the schools. Schools with larger attendance, as a rule, receive the larger grants. The opposite is the case in the U.S.A. Portage grant is $160.00 per capita on 90 pupils. This is not enough. This year, because of the low price of grain, and last year because of drought, I have had to put per capita grant into the farm to carry it over. The farm is a liability and will continue so with prices at their present level. The lowering of the discharge age means more hired help and we can no longer cook our bread as these young girls cannot stand the work and this will mean an outlay of $500.00 more each year.

The U.S.A. Indian Boarding Schools are much the same as ours with farms attached. The Principals of those schools who have called to see us cannot understand how it is possible for us to finance. In the U.S.A. schools of over 200 pupils they receive $270.00 per capita and the Principal's salary and transportation of children is paid extra. In the schools of 200 pupils or less, the Minister of the Interior can increase the grant as high as $300.00 per capita with Principal's salary and transportation of children extra. (Feb. 21 1925,43 Statute L 958.)

Take the per capita grant of Portage school, $160.00 on 90 pupils $14,400.00. Here are a few of the fixed expenses that cannot be changed very much.

| Item                | Cost   |
|---------------------|--------|
| Clothing            | $2500.00 |
| Food                | $5000.00 |
| Wood                | $1200.00 |
| Salaries            | $6500.00 |
| Light, water, power, range | $700.00 |

$15,900.00

No one can make much change in these items and in some of them no change at all. The farm was our help but now it is a liability.

(Sgd.) W.A. Hendry,
Prin.
Ottawa, November 21st, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

Rev. Mr. Beaton of the United Church Board of Home Missions informs the Department that you have written concerning the age for discharge from Indian residential schools and the amount of per capita grant at Portage. I may say that the Department hopes to secure a Vote which will enable us to make a slight increase in your grant from the beginning of the next fiscal year, viz., April 1st, 1931. It is hoped that $165 can be fixed as the rate per annum for next year.

With reference to the age of discharge, I may say that it remains at eighteen, as heretofore. Principals, Indian Agents and others interested are expected to bend every energy towards keeping those children that would profit by the full course in the residential school until they reach the age of eighteen years. The Statute during the past few years provided for the compulsory attendance of physically fit Indian children at school between the ages of seven and fifteen years. At the last regular session of Parliament, the section with reference to compulsion was repealed and the following substituted therefor:

"Every Indian child between the full ages of seven and sixteen years who is physically able shall attend such day, industrial or boarding school as may be designated by the Superintendent General for the full periods during which such school is open each year; provided that where it has been made to appear to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General that it would be detrimental to any particular Indian child to

Rev. W. A. Hendry,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
have it discharged from school on attaining the full age of sixteen years, the Superintendent General may direct that such child be detained at school for such further period as may seem to be advisable, but not beyond the full age of eighteen years, and in such case the provisions of this section with respect to truancy shall apply to such child and its parents, guardians or persons with whom such child resides during such further period of school attendance."

You will note that Indian children may be compelled to attend until their 16th birthday. In certain instances, the Department can also compel attendance to the 18th birthday. It is not intended that compulsion to the 18th birthday be applied to all Indian children or even to a large number. This clause was added to the section so that the Department could postpone discharge for an added two years, when home conditions very strongly suggested such action.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

November 14th,
1934.

Dear Sir:

Re: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

I am sorry to have to advise you that Rev. W. A. Hendry, who for over thirty years has been engaged in Indian educational work, has been forced to retire suddenly on account of the very critical condition of Mrs. Hendry's health.

It is the intention of the Executive Committee of our Women's Missionary Society in the near future to nominate a permanent Principal by promoting a man from one of their other Residential Schools to succeed Mr. Hendry in this important position. In the meantime, they wish to submit the name of Rev. W. R. Wood, of Austin, Manitoba, as Acting Principal of the School until June 30th, 1935. Mr. Wood was Principal of the School at Ahousaht at one time, and they are hopeful that he will be able to administer the School at Portage la Prairie to the satisfaction of the Department of Indian Affairs during the interim until the permanent appointee can arrive.

Trusting that this will meet with your approval,

I am

Yours sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

KJB.MT
Ottawa, November 20, 1934.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, informing the Department of the retirement of Reverend W. A. Hendry as principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that the Department regrets that Mr. Hendry has been forced to retire. His lengthy service - over a period of 30 years - in the interests of the education of the Indian youth in Manitoba, is appreciated. The illness of Mrs. Hendry, who was actively associated in the work at this school, is regretted.

The Department approves of the nomination of the Executive Committee, Woman's Missionary Society, of Rev. W. R. Wood as acting principal of the school, until June 30, 1935. It is noted that, in the near future, the nomination of a permanent principal will be forwarded.

Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, and Mr. Agent Waite, Portage la Prairie, are being informed of the change in principalship at the Portage la Prairie School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. 5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of the Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
