PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for whom a grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

**PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA**
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

**PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA**
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils whose names on the Return are determined by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will any credit be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No.2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is calculated by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Indian Residential School
PHONE 110 BOX 136
Portage la Prairie, Man.
January 8th, 1924.

Sirs,

I wish to thank the Department for the new class-room at Portage la Prairie. It is now completed except the slate blackboard and this is expected along shortly.

It is a very fine class-room and is well built. When it was 36 below with a heavy wind, and the Collegiate over town had to send the children home because they could not heat the West rooms, we could keep the new class-room warm without opening up the furnace.

I have never seen a finer room, it is finished in B.C. fir and the boards were all thoroughly sandpapered by the school boys and stained and rubbed. Everyone who come say that it is the most beautiful little class-room they have seen.

The basement is fitted up with a store room for new clothing 24x12, a bed room 12x12, and a good wood work room where we can do our special repair work in winter.

We are all delighted with it and it is going to be economical as the extra expense is the coal only, which will not run over $125.00 a year. We are experiencing no difficulty going to and fro with the children. I believe the little run and the fresh air they get will be beneficial to them.

We wish to thank the Department and to say that we are very much delighted with this gift and would ask to have our gratitude expressed to your architect, Mr. R.Gurney Orr for his splendid plan and for his advice in all matters regarding the building process.

It was most interesting and instructive to me and to the boys who helped, wherever possible, in the work.

I am, Very truly yours,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Mr. Scott,

In the list of new buildings to be erected this year, there is an item of $5000 for an addition to a new barn at Portage la Prairie. This seems a lot of money for an addition to a new barn. Would you give me particulars of the information you got regarding what is required? I hesitate to discuss this matter with the Agent, without knowing what the Department have promised. It looks to me as if it is an entirely new barn, judging from the amount of money that is asked for.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

B.C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
May 14, 1924.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the addition required to the Portage la Prairie School barn, I beg to say that the present barn was built for this school at a time when the farm consisted of 56 acres, and now it comprises 176 acres.

Mr. Hendry, the Principal, desires accommodation for forty or fifty more head of cattle. This would require an addition to the present building of forty or fifty feet. I think Mr. Hendry would be willing to undertake the work, providing he was supplied with the materials and one or two competent carpenters.

It would be well for you to communicate with him and ascertain in detail what he requires.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 14th inst., #127-1-5, with reference to an addition to the barn at Portage la Prairie School.

I note that the Principal desires accommodation for 40 or 50 head of cattle. Surely this must be a mistake. He cannot possibly keep 40 or 50 head of cattle at this institution, and if he could it is, in my opinion, altogether too many and the Department should not be asked to provide accommodation for this number.

We have just completed a barn at the Qu'Appelle School, which is possibly three times as big as Portage, and it is to accommodate 30 head of stock and I do not think we should carry much more than this number of stock at Portage.

In taking this matter up with Mr. Christianson, who was at the Portage la Prairie School a short time ago, his recollection is that they have about 32 head of stock now and that they have accommodation for this number.

Might I ask if the Principal of the School or the chief authorities have been given to understand that $8000 will be expended at this School this year on a barn. If they have I fear they will be dissatisfied if this amount is not spent there.

D. C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I note that you suggest Mr. Hendry would be willing to undertake the work, provided he is supplied with material and two competent carpenters. I do not think this is the idea to hand over the work to Mr. Hendry or to any other School Principal. It is to try and get the work done as economically as possible and take the responsibility ourselves for the expenditure of the money.

I have no intention of handing over the work to Mr. Hendry for direction or supervision unless I am so instructed by you.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner
May 31, 1924.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott.

With reference to Mr. Commissioner Graham's letter relative to barn accommodation at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, I wish to draw to your attention that the Rev. Mr. Hendry has successfully conducted this institution for some years and without doubt is in a position to know exactly what he requires for the satisfactory conduct of the school. I understand that the school management is discontinuing the major portion of the grain production and is desirous of conducting a stock farm. The position of the school on the outskirts of the city leads me to believe that such a programme would be wise.

[Signature]

Supt. of Indian Education.
June 7, 1924.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of May 21st, with reference to the proposed addition to the barn at the Portage la Prairie school.

I understand that the management of the school is discontinuing the major portion of the grain production and is desirous of conducting a stock farm. You may confer with Principal Hendry on this matter. As he is a competent Principal and has operated the institution successfully for a number of years, he will no doubt be able to give good reasons for his desire to have greater barn accommodation.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:

In a letter dated the 3rd of July from W. A. Hendry, Principal of the Portage School, he informs me that last winter he had to plug two of the school boiler flues for leaks. He wrote to the boiler inspector for the Province to come and look over the boiler, and he was there a short time before he wrote. The result of the inspection is that new flues will have to be placed in the boiler.

I wrote to him asking for an approximate cost for having the work done and I am in receipt of a reply from him today, enclosing a copy of a quotation from the Link Manufacturing Company of Portage la Prairie, in which he advises that it will cost $940.96 to re-flue this boiler.

I read this quotation to the Regina Foundry Company here, who do that kind of work, and they informed me that they would do the work in the City of Regina for $540.00, a difference of $400. It looks to me as if there is a wide difference here. This work should not be given to Mr. Hendry to have done until we thoroughly investigate and get prices from different firms.

There is no doubt the work has got to be done, and it should be done now.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott.

A letter has been received from Mr. Graham in which he stated that the Principal of the Portage la Prairie School has advised him that new flues are required in the boiler at the Portage la Prairie School.

As it is important that the repairs to the boiler be made during the summer, I beg to recommend that Mr. Graham be authorized to have this work done, the cost of which will be approximately $600.

ARCHITECT.
Ottawa, August 6, 1924.

Dear Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo, No. 208-11A, with reference to the repairs required to the heating boiler at the Portage la Prairie school, and in reply to say that you are authorized to have the necessary repairs made before the winter sets in.

Your obedient servant,

(A. T. MacKenzie,)
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

There is on file no letter from you of the 8th August or the 8th July. Your letter of the 21st July with reference to the boiler at the Portage la Prairie school was replied to on the 6th August and you were given authority to have the necessary repairs made before the winter sets in.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy'and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Commissioner's Office,
Regina, Sask., Aug. 8, 1924.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to submit herewith a report on the building operations that are being carried on in the three Western provinces under the direction of this office.

I would deal with the different works as they appear on the list submitted to me from your office.

MANITOBA

School buildings.

Portage la Prairie.

School Barn. It was found that it was not necessary to build this barn.

You will see from this report that the work is well advanced and will be completed in good time this Fall.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I wish to inform you that on my last visit to Manitoba I called at the Portage la Prairie School, and while there I saw that some interior painting was very necessary, as the ceilings and walls have not been painted since 1915. I would therefore ask for an expenditure of $350.00 to do this work.

There are also considerable minor repairs to be made around the school, and buildings, and also some work in connection with plumbing for the winter. I would think that there would probably be a week's work for a carpenter, and the same amount of time for a plumber. There will be a little material to buy in connection with this repair work also. This will not amount to much. I would like to have your authority by wire to go on with this work on account of the season being advanced, and I wish to get this work finished before the cold weather sets in.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Ottawa, September 10, 1924.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

You are authorized to expend four hundred and fifty dollars for interior painting and minor repairs Portage Indian Residential School.

Duncan G. Scott.

Chg. Dept. F. A.
Commissioner's Office,
Regina, Sask., Sept. 6, 1924.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to report that I visited the Roseau River Reserve last week and found conditions there fairly satisfactory.

PORTAGE SCHOOL:

I visited the Portage school and found the children just returning from their summer vacation. The school classes had not resumed; however, I saw several of the children who appeared to be quite healthy. The interior of this building requires re-painting at once, especially the kitchen and dining room, in fact all rooms in the basement and on the second floor. I have today written to you specially on this matter, asking for authority to have the work done. While in Winnipeg I arranged with the Vulcan Iron works to go at once and re-flue the heating plant at this institution; I was able to save about $400.00 by placing the order where I did; The price quoted by the Portage firm was altogether too high.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Portage la Prairie, Man.

29th September ....1924

Sir,

I beg to ask authority to employ a carpenter, for about 12 days, to do odd jobs in the Portage la Prairie Residential School, such as repairing and building clothes closets etc., The Carpenter's charge is 75¢ per hour. Also to employ a plumber about 7 days to repair the water pipes etc. The Plumber's charge $1.00 per hour.

It is necessary to have these repairs done before the winter sets in.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 3, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, requesting authority to employ a carpenter and a plumber to carry out some minor repairs at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. In this connection I have to inform you that Mr. Commissioner Graham, early in September last, requested authority to have some interior painting performed and to engage the services of a carpenter and plumber. He was granted authority to expend the sum of $450 for interior painting and minor repairs. The Commissioner will, no doubt, arrange to have this work completed at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

A. Ogletree, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Man.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I was instructed by the Women's Missionary Society when forwarding requests for the buildings for 1925, to state that in addition to the amount of $6000 required for alterations to the buildings at Portage la Prairie, they would like to have a grant sufficient to purchase six Holstein cows. Commissioner Graham on a recent visit to Portage la Prairie, recommended a herd of Holstein cows instead of the present grade of cattle. Mr. Hendry reports that he could look after six in the present barn.

Yours sincerely,

JHE/EB

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-5, part 4)
Ottawa, December 22, 1924.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant and I note that you are requesting a grant of $6,000 for the purpose of providing a principal's residence at the Portage Indian Residential School, so that the present principal's suite can be altered to accommodate more pupils. Consideration to this request will be given in connection with the preparation of the Estimates.

I regret that the Department cannot give favourable consideration to the purchase of milch cows for this school. Our policy is to make replacements to stock, only when the animals at the institution have been condemned.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. J. H. Edmison, D.D.,
General Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
434 Confederation Life Bldg.,
Toronto, Ont.
EXTRACT FROM DR. EDMISON'S LETTER of Dec. 2,
on File 160-4, in which he recapitulated the
requirements of Presbyterian Indian Residential
Schools for the fiscal year 1925-26.

Portage la Prairie - For necessary alterations to take
care of thirty more pupils................. $6000.

Mr. Hendry reports that a promise of $5000
was given by the Indian Department to make
an addition of 40 feet to the barn, but the
work was not started in 1924. As he has now
so many pupils waiting to come in and can
take care of only 90, we would prefer to
have the $5000 with an additional $1000 to
be used in the erection of a residence to
the North of the present building. We could
then use the space now occupied by the
Principal for school purposes. This would
permit of an attendance of 130. Mr. Hendry
reports that he has had to refuse admittance
of children from several reserves for the past
four or five years. If the Government will
grant this request for $6000 Mr. Hendry hopes
in a short time to be able to take care of the
enlargement of the barn out of school funds.

Portage la Prairie, Man.

This school is in urgent need of increased dormitory space. This was promised for 1925.

Regina, Sask., Aug. 24th, 1926.

Dear Mr. Graham:

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This institution was also just re-opening after the holidays and about 80 children were present and they expected about 20 more to arrive this week. Everything in connection with this institution was in shape and I never saw the place look better. There were 35 harvesting and excellent crops and Mr. Henry, the Principal informed me that he expected to thresh about 6,000 bushels of grain. The summerfallow gardens etc., and the premises in general, are a credit to any institution.

The outside buildings have all been painted this summer by the school boys and the work has been well done. Considerable painting has also been done in the interior of the school. The repair work to the balconies, etc. that was authorized while you were in Ottawa has not been done yet but the Principal informed me that he expected Mr. Hamilton, who does any carpenter work of that kind around the school, to arrive in a few days. The only expenditure necessary at the present time is the following:

A ventilating system was put in the barn last year with one ventilator on the roof; we find this is not sufficient, another one should be placed there to insure proper ventilation. This will cost about $40.00. Mr. Henry also asked to be supplied with 20 gals. of paint and 5 gals. of oil to do some inside decorating during the winter. Some of the steps in the stairs should also be replaced as a few of them are practically worn out. Mr. Henry will have these replaced if he is furnished with the material. There is about 14 steps that need replacing. I would ask that this expenditure be allowed.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson.

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Regina, Sask., August 27, 1926.

Dear Mr. Scott:

The report on the Portage la Prairie Residential School is highly satisfactory. We always get good reports from this institution.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham.
Indian Commissioner.
The United Church of Canada
Board of Home Missions

Toronto, Nov. 15, 1926.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have an application from the Woman's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada for the enlargement of the Portage La Prairie Indian Residential School which has been under the management of the W.M.S. of the former Presbyterian Church.

The suggestion is made that the Government Architect prepare a plan for the proposed enlargement. I am informed that there is a waiting list of over thirty pupils who would attend the Portage La Prairie School if there was accommodation for them. The matter of enlargement, I understand, has been under consideration for some years, and it would be very gratifying if an appropriation could be made for this purpose in the near future.

Trusting you will give it your favourable consideration,

I am,

Very faithfully yours,

C.E. Manning
November 17, 1926.

Dear Dr. Manning:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to enlarging the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. There are many pressing claims on the Appropriation for Indian Education, and I believe it advisable to have some of those on the waiting list for this institution enter the one at Brandon, where there are vacancies. It might be well for your office to write to the Rev. Principals interested.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Sir:

I am herewith forwarding Portage la Prairie Agency Voucher No. 4112, amounting to $67.70, in favour of W. F. Lisson, Tinsmith of Portage la Prairie, Man. This expenditure represents the purchase of a ventilator for the barn at the Portage la Prairie Residential School.

A ventilating system was installed in the stable in 1925, but it was found during the winter that one ventilator was not sufficient, that it was necessary to have two. Mr. Hendry, the Principal, therefore had this put in last summer before the barn was filled with hay. At the time this work was under way, Inspector Christianson was at the school and Mr. Hendry asked him if it was possible for the Department to pay this bill, but stated that if they could not see their way clear to do so, he intended paying it out of the school funds. The Inspector mentioned in his report dated August 24th, 1926, that a ventilator was necessary.

I would therefore recommend this voucher for payment, as the Department are very seldom called upon to pay for extra expenditures at this institution.

Your obedient servant,

W. L. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

While on this trip I spent an evening and part of the next forenoon at the Portage School. As usual, things were in excellent shape there; I never saw them any better. They have just completed seeding operations, and the gardens and farm were in first class condition. The grounds were also clean and tidy, and everything around the place bore evidence of good management.

The children all seemed bright and happy and were looking forward to their holidays.

The buildings are also well kept. The only matter that I wish to bring to the Department's attention is that the outside woodwork on the school has not been painted since it was built. This should be provided for in the estimates this year. Mr. Hendry informed me that he had obtained a price, a couple of years ago, for this work of $800.00; it probably can be done for less than that. The dining room tables need new tops as they are in bad shape, and I would suggest that these be factory made with a Linoleum top. They should be supplied this year.

Portage la Prairie Residential School (Cont'd)

year, if possible, as they are badly needed. There are nine tables in all. I might point out that the legs, sides and ends are all right, the top is all that is required.

Signed

M. Christianson

Dear Sir:-

We are having very much trouble with our main lavatories for the school children which are situated in the basement. They will not flush because of lime formation on the bowls which is as hard as the bowl itself and destroys the action of the Syphon and the plumbers tell me that the bowls must be renewed.

The bowls are of the syphon jet type, there are six of them altogether and have been in use for thirteen years. The upper part of the lavatories are pretty well used up and I believe it would be better to have them installed complete.

I wish this matter could be taken up with the Department as soon as possible as we cannot keep the odor down and the lavatories and constantly overflowing on the floor.

I am, Very truly yours,

[Signature]

October 5th, 1927.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the Department's circular letter No. 397, dated Sept 29th, in reference to the possibility of fire in our schools. In reply I beg to state that I believe some changes could be made in this school which would help in case of fire.

1- The fire escapes (sliding poles etc) are at the rear of the building and when the children reach the lower veranda by means of these poles they are still 12 feet off the ground. Your ladders should be provided two for the boys and two for the girls to provide a means of getting to the ground. They should have provision for making them permanent.

2- The fire escape exit is at the rear of the building and the sliding poles pass thru two large wooden wormholes which are over the furnace room where most fires originate and being wooden would be cut off immediately. The fire escape should be built at each end of the school near the front part of the building providing a means of escape should it be impossible to use the hall at either end to get to the main floor.

3- Two fire axes are needed one for use in each of the four dormitories.

4- Two more two and a half gallons chemicals so as to provide one at the end of each floor. The chemicals are invaluable in case of a fire just beginning as the boys can use them with dispatch.

5- The chimneys of the school should be cleaned which require an expert cleaner since they are difficult to get at.

6- There should be a fire alarm box in the school which would ring individually to the Fire Dept of the City. The other institutions have this safeguard, Home for Incurables, Old People's Home, Hospital and Provincial Training School etc.

7- We have two outside hydrants but there are no hose for them but we could do little to save the building with those hydrants and the Fire Dept would bring their own hose.

The City Fire Chief went over the entire building with me and these are his recommendations. We are recharging all the chemicals and having the stand pipe hose tested.

I am, Very truly yours,

Wm. Graham, Commissioner,
Indian Office, Regina, Sask.,

Ottawa, October 8, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, enclosing copy of a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Portage Indian Residential School with reference to fire escapes. You may arrange for the immediate provision of four ladders, to be attached to the lower verandah at the rear of the building near the present sliding pole fire escapes. You may also purchase four fire axes for the dormitories and arrange to have the chimneys at the school cleaned. No unnecessary expense should be incurred.

The Department is ordering two 2½ gallon chemical fire extinguishers.

You may ascertain the cost of a fire alarm box in the school, so that the city fire department would be called immediately. If such cost is inconsiderable, arrange the installation at once; if expensive, you should telegraph a recommendation with estimate.

You should immediately secure prices on the two proposed additional fire escapes for the ends of the building, to be placed towards the front in each case. The sliding pole type is favoured by the Department. This should receive your prompt attention and a recommendation with estimate should be made to the Department by telegram.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

In reply I beg to state that I believe some changes could be made in this school which would help in case of fire.

1. The fire escapes (sliding poles etc) are at the rear of the building and when the children reach the lower veranda by means of these poles they are still 12 feet off the ground. Four ladders should be provided, two for the boys and two for the girls to provide a means of getting to the ground. They should have provision for making them permanent.

2. The fire escape exit is at the rear of the building and the sliding poles pass through two large wooden verandas which are over the furnace room where most fires originate and being wooden would be cut off immediately. Two fire escapes should be built at each end of the school near the front part of the building providing a means of escape should it be impossible to use the Hall at either end to get to the main floor.

3. Four fire axes are needed, one for use in each of the four dormitories.

4. Two more two and a half gallon chemicals are required so as to provide one at the end of each floor. The chemicals are invaluable in case of a fire just beginning as the boys can use them with dispatch.

5. The chimneys of the school should be cleaned, which requires an expert cleaner since they are difficult to get at.

6. There should be a fire alarm box in the school which would ring individually to the fire Dept. of the City. The other institutions have this safeguard - Home for Incurables, Old Peoples Home, Hospital and Provincial Training School etc.

7. We have two outside hydrants but there are no hose for them. We could do little to save the building with these hydrants and the fire Dept. would bring their own hose.

The City Fire Chief went over the school building with me and these are his recommendations. We are recharging all the chemicals and having the standpipe hose tested.

I am, very truly yours,

(Sgd.) W.A.Hendry,
Principal

Wm. Graham, Commissioner,
Indian Office, Regina, Sask.
Dear Mr. Scott:

A short time ago we circularized the Principals of all our Residential Schools, regarding fire protection, fire drill, etc., at their institutions.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter that I received on this subject from the Rev. W.A. Hendry, Principal of the Portage la Prairie School, in which he makes several recommendations, after having gone over the school building with the Chief of the City Fire Department, and in connection with these recommendations I wish to comment as follows,

1. I have instructed the Principal to have these ladders built, as I did not consider it worth while waiting for special authority.

2. I have not done anything regarding this item, but I think fire escapes should be provided at the front of the building, and with your authority I will have this done. I believe these escapes will cost in the neighborhood of $700.00.

3. I am having these axes sent to the school from Winnipeg.

4. Will these chemicals be purchased in Ottawa, or shall I purchase them here.

5. I have instructed the Principal to have the chimneys cleaned at once.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
6. I am ascertaining what it would cost to have an alarm box in the school, connecting with the City Fire Department.

7. I do not think we are called upon to buy hose to attach to city hydrants. When the fire brigade arrive on the scene of a fire they have their own hose with them.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, October 10, 1927.

Dear Mr. Scott:

In regard to the question of fire protection in the residential school at Portage la Prairie, I have received a letter from the Principal stating that the School is outside the City limits and on that account the Fire Department is technically under no obligation to protect the school, and to consent to the placing of a special fire alarm would be an acknowledgement of an obligation. The Secretary,

Referring to your letter of the 10th October last, in which you informed me that prices on fire escapes for the Portage Indian Residential School would be forwarded to this office, my letter of Nov. 1st, advising you that these prices had not come to hand, and your subsequent letter of the 5th instant, I beg to say that there has been some considerable delay in getting the proper data before the Department.

Regarding fire escapes, there are three styles, viz:- the ordinary tread fire escape, with a rail, such as we have been using at most of our schools, the sliding pole escape, such as is used in fire halls and at some of our schools, and then there is the spiral chute, which, in my opinion, is the safest and most satisfactory, but which, unfortunately, costs about twice as much as the iron tread fire escape, the price being from $55.00 to $60.00 a foot. This is a complete cylinder with a door at the bottom which automatically flies open when the children come down. This chute will take four or five children abreast and, in fact, there can be a continuous stream of children coming down from one, two or three floors. The price which I have quoted per foot is for the escape erected. The sliding pole is, in my opinion, the next best. We would have to erect steel platforms at each flat, and instead of the children being asked to go out of a window there should be doors cut. The cost for the pole would probably be less than $1.00 per foot and the platforms would possibly cost in the neighborhood of $150.00. I do not think that the ordinary tread escapes are at all satisfactory.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
satisfactory where there are small children, and especially where we have a high building.

Notwithstanding the cost, I would strongly recommend that we place two of the spiral chutes at the Portage School and two at the Elkhorn School. The order can be placed with the Vulcan Iron Works, of Winnipeg.

When I was at Lebret some time ago the Sisters expressed great fear of using the tread escapes, especially in the case of the smaller children. I am sorry now that we did not supply the spiral chutes there also.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Commissioner.

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE BOARDING SCHOOL:

It is always a great pleasure to me to visit this institution, and I found everything in Al shape. The crop was lighter than usual, but the average of all grains was about 22 bushels to the acre, which I think was better than anything in the vicinity of Portage la Prairie and shows that the farming is properly done at this institution, and the fields are in excellent shape.

There were 97 children in the school. I understand the grant is only for 90, which means that they have seven who are not grant-earning pupils. Mr. Hendry informed me that he had the room for them and for all it cost to keep them he would rather have a few over than under.

While there I went thoroughly into the matter of fire protection. There are three floors in the school, viz:- the basement, which is only two or three feet below the ground level, the second floor, about six feet above the ground level, and the third floor which is thirteen feet above the second floor and about eighteen or nineteen feet from the ground. On the second and third floors there is
there is a wide hall which runs the full length of the building down the centre. There are four dormitories on the third floor where the children sleep, and there are staff rooms on this floor as well. There are two fire extinguishers on each floor, as well as fire axes and two reel hose, making six lengths of hose in all. I tested the hose and found them to be rotten and useless, as they have been in the building for fourteen years. The six 2½ gallon fire extinguishers were in good shape. In case of fire the means for the children to get out would be either by the stairs located at each end of the hall leading down to the second floor, or by way of the fire escape which consists of a sliding pole leading from the back balcony to the balcony of the second floor and from thence descending by two ladders to the ground, which is only a distance of six or seven feet. The only improvement that I could suggest would be fire escapes leading from the two front dormitories to the ground. The Principal considers that one would be ample, but if any are supplied the type which he desires to have is a chute. I have drawn a sketch of the floor where the dormitories are located, in order to give you a better idea of the situation. The Fire Chief from Portage went over the building, and his remark to the Principal was that he did not have very much to worry about so far as fire escapes were concerned.

The building is of brick construction and every precaution is taken by Mr. Hendry and the staff to avert a fire. On a cold night when big fires are on Mr. Hendry stays up until one or two
until one or two o'clock in the morning, and the fireman sleeps in the hall just outside of the furnace room. The staff, as well as the children, have been trained regarding what to do in case of fire, and with the children all in bed the Principal can get them to put on sufficient clothing and get them out of the building in less than two minutes. The only difficulty would be in case a fire started in the boiler room which is located near the balcony where the sliding pole terminates. In that case that avenue would be cut off and they would have to use the stairs. The Fire Chief from Portage thought that putting a chute from one of the dormitory windows, as marked on the enclosed sketch, would make it absolutely safe, as this is the corner farthest from the boiler room.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., December 17th, 1927

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith Inspector Christianson's report on the various schools in the Portage la Prairie Agency.

You will note what the Inspector says regarding the Swan Lake Day School. I should be glad if the Department would authorize an expenditure of $12.00 to supply a flag-pole at this school. I think it is a splendid thing to have flags at all our schools. All rural schools in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta fly the flag during school hours. Once the grounds are cleared up it will be the duty of the teacher and the pupils to see that they are kept in proper order.

Regarding the Dog Creek Day School, I cannot recommend the building of a new school and teacher's residence at this point. I am not in favour of Day Schools, and I think the time will come when we will have to put these children in Boarding Schools.

The report deals at length with the system of fire protection at the Portage Boarding School. I may say that we have now authorized the Principal to go ahead and have two sliding pole escapes erected, one at each end of the building, and when this is done the children will be amply protected against fire. Mr. Hendry runs a very satisfactory institution and is little trouble to this office or the Department.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

December 19th, 1927.

W.M.Graham, Commissioner,
Indian Office,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:-

Referring to your letter of December 9th. No. 208-11A P. I beg to say that The Link Manufacturing Company are sending you drawings and prices on both Pole and Chute fire escapes. They think the pole of no use in cold weather with small children. They are the only concern that I could find that cared to put up the fire escape. I asked Cadman's Babb and Burns but they did not seem interested in the matter.

The Fire Chief does not think much of a pole fire escape and says it is for inside and summer service and would be of no use for the small children in winter.

The Provincial Fire Inspector visited the school and went thro all fire equipment thoroughly and got the children together to see how old they were and the problem we would have to meet in getting them out. He also is much opposed to a Pole and says you simply could not put the small children down a thirty foot pole in cold weather, and he says we would be better not to depend on it at all in winter, but have our fire drill for the other exits.

We are far better fixed than most institutions so far as being able to get out and I am taking no chances in winter as I am having a man sleep in the hall between the kitchen and the fire room until the 1st. of April.

I am, Very truly yours,

(Sgd.) W.A.Hendry

W.M.Graham, Commissioner,
Indian Office,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have had some correspondence with you in regard to the question of fire escapes for the Portage la Prairie and Elkhorn Indian Residential Schools and on the 23rd ultimo, in reply to your No. 127-1-5 of the 26th of November, I forwarded you a copy of a letter from the Principal of the Portage la Prairie School dealing with the subject and expressing his opinion of the unsuitability of using the sliding pole fire escapes. He suggests that in view of this, it might be advisable to erect a chute, the price of which is about $600 per foot.

Since writing on that date, I have received a letter from the Link Manufacturing Company of Portage la Prairie offering to erect another form of chute with the necessary platform at a cost of $185.00. This latter is an open metal chute made of galvanized steel, running from the storey above to the ground at an angle of forty-five degrees. This is bolted to the wall by steel brackets and includes the provision and erection of a steel platform outside the door or window of the storey from which the chute commences.

If you have not already written me in reply to my letter of the 23rd ultimo, I think it might be well to give consideration to the erection of the chute above described at both the schools mentioned. Will you please let me hear from you, as I think some action should be taken as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

Duncan G. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

I received a letter today from Rev. W. A. Hendry, Portage, in which he states that nothing has been done so far re building farmer's cottage. Mr. Hendry very rarely asks for a favour and I know the farmer he had last summer left because he had no place outside Institution in the shape of a home.
June 11, 1928.

Dear Mrs. Clark:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to improvements at the Portage and Round Lake Indian Residential Schools. It is true that a farmer's residence is required at the Portage School; but I regret that I was unable to include an item in the Estimates for this year. I am quite hopeful that next summer the work can be undertaken. This year, we are doing some painting and are replacing the dining room tables at this school.

I was very glad to get your report on the work of Mr. and Mrs. Ross at the Round Lake School. I have given considerable thought to the question of an addition; but the condition of the main building there is such that I am not satisfied with the proposal. Last month I had some correspondence with Dr. Manning regarding Round Lake, and it is our intention to discuss the future progress for this school the first time he is in Ottawa. Of course, no building activity will be undertaken this year. Mr. Commissioner Graham, of Regina, has recently been authorised to provide a root house, to fix up the fire escapes and to effect other minor improvements. I understand Mr. and Mrs. Ross are moving into the principal's residence. This will permit of increased dormitory accommodation.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Mrs. G. Clark,

W. Regina, Sask., 4th July, 1928.

Sir:

I enclose and recommend for payment Regina Voucher No. 5316 in favor of the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works, Limited, representing the cost of erecting two fire escapes at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, under Department Authority 127-1-5, dated 26th November last.

Several types of fire escapes were suggested, but it was finally decided that the ordinary steel stair type would be the most satisfactory. The Representative of the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works at Regina was not able to furnish me with complete particulars in regard to the erection of the desired type, and I, therefore, on a visit to Winnipeg called at the Company's office and arranged that they should send a representative to the school to look over the type of building and give me a price on the erection of the fire escapes. This they did and I enclose with the voucher their letter of the 1st February last. You will note, however, on referring to the voucher that the escapes were actually erected for less than the amount which they quoted. The clause in their quotation letter referring to performing other work on a cost plus 10% basis had reference to fixing up the walls of the building after the erection of the fire escapes; such as, replastering etc., and a voucher covering these extras will be forwarded to you when I have received from the Company a more detailed statement of their account, which amounts to approximately $60.00. With the voucher enclosed are blue prints of the fire escapes which were erected.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sirs:

In reply to the Department's letter No. 127-1-5. May the 31st in connection with the painting of the main building of the Portage la Prairie Residential School I beg to say that I do not expect many of the boys who are over sixteen years of age to return to school after holidays and will have to engage extra help to get the harvest gathered so could not give any help to the painting. They would be of very little use in any case as the work is mostly windows and high from the ground.

I think the most satisfactory way would be to let the work by tender as the cornish work is very high and the men who do painting by the day in Portage have not the equipment to do it.

I have asked the only two firms who have the equipment for such work in Portage la Prairie to give tenders on the work and I am enclosing in this letter one copy of each.

I am, Very truly yours,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sir,

I have given authority to have the exterior of the Portage la Prairie Residential School painted. The Department is to supply the material and I wish to obtain the services of a competent painter who would take charge of the work. I wish him to utilize as much of the school labour as possible, but it may be necessary for him to engage other help. Will you be good enough to let me have as soon as possible the name of someone who would perform this service?

Yours very truly,

(A. S. Williams,)

E. A. McPherson, Esq., M.P.,
Portage la Prairie, Man.
MEMORANDUM

MR. MCLEAN.

It is intended to paint the exterior of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School building. The Principal has forwarded quotations which he received covering the cost of the material and labour in carrying out this work, as follows:

Cadham Hardware Co., Portage la Prairie, $674.80,
Pierce Bros., " " , $890.00.

It will be necessary to obtain an Order in Council, and I would recommend that the contract be given to the Cadham Hardware Company at the price quoted by them, viz. $674.80, for the work, complete; their price being fair and reasonable for the work to be performed. The Principal states that it would be more satisfactory to have the painting done by tender, as the cornice work is very high, and the men who do painting by the day in Portage la Prairie have not the equipment for such work. The above are the only two firms who have the necessary equipment.

As this work should be carried out as soon as possible, I would request that the necessary authority be obtained from Council at an early date.

Funds for the purpose are provided in the appropriation for Indian Education for the present fiscal year.

Sir:

I enclose for payment Regina Voucher No. 5401, representing work performed by the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works, Limited, in connection with the erection of fire escapes at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, and in this connection refer you to my letter of the 4th July last under cover of which a former voucher in favor of this Company was submitted.

You will note a charge appearing therein for Overhead Expense, and in reply to an enquiry of mine I received from the Company an explanation as follows:-

"With reference to the Overhead Expense, we believe that you will agree that it is customary for manufacturing concerns to charge an indirect Expense Account on all jobs and we presume it is the practice in your Department to allow same. In this instance the Casualty Insurance amounts to $2.05 or $6.00 per 100 on the labor and is included in the amount of $16.44. If however, the Department refuses to allow general Overhead Expense charges we suggest that the amount of $14.39 be deducted leaving the insurance charge to stand." As this is the first account I have received at any time including Overhead Expenses, I have allowed them to stand in the voucher for the consideration of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

CANADA
Sir:-

I beg to advise the Department that the columns supporting the veranda of the Portage la Prairie Boarding School have been found to be rotten and the veranda is in danger of collapsing. Mr. Peter Hancock, Carpenter, has made an examination and estimates that it will be necessary to cut from two to four inches from the base of each of eight posts and reset them back in place with base and cap to restore the columns to the proper length. The cost will be $35.00 each, inclusive, or $280.00 for the eight posts. This building is Department property, and I beg to recommend that authority be granted to have the work done at once. The amount seems high for replacing four inches on each column, but a great deal of labour will be involved in jacking up the veranda and removing and replacing the columns.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, September 22nd, 1926.

Sir:

I have your No. 208-11A P., of the 15th instant, relative to the repairs required to the columns supporting the veranda of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, and giving an estimate of the cost of same.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of your arranging to have these repairs carried out. It is considered, however, that the cost is rather high and that a price should be obtained from another competent carpenter with a view to having the work done at less cost than that quoted by Peter Hancock. The work should be completed, if possible, before the extreme cold weather sets in.

The Department will leave the matter with you, to make the best arrangements possible to have the repairs carried out and at the lowest cost.

Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.,
Sept 22nd, 1928.

Sirs:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the Department's letter of August 25th, No 127-1-5 authorizing the Cadham Co., of Portage la Prairie to paint the school.

They have been working on the job for over a week and are getting along fast with the work.

A difficulty has arisen in regard to the painting of the roof; The painters thought that the shingles were surfaced asbestos but find that they are colored right through and were not intended to be painted. The oil absorbs into the shingle and the paint remains like dust on the shingle. The Sherman-Willism took a shingle to Winnipeg and found that by using a filler they can be painted satisfactorily but there is another grave difficulty etc., the shingles being exposed to the weather so long are very brittle and crack when one walks on them and the painters tell me that it would cause many more leaks and there are surely enough of them now. The roof leaks badly in at least thirty places.

The Cadham Company say that they deduct the amount they allowed in the estimate for the painting of the asbestos shingles, $40.00 or will put the same amount of paint on the bark roofs if the Department think as they do that it is very unwise to paint the asbestos shingles.

I shall be very glad to hear from the Department and to know what they think about the matter.

I am, Very truly yours,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sir:-

I beg to inform the Department that the four lavatory bowls in the four dormitories are so badly coreded with lime that nothing can be done to clean them out and the water does not get away.

Our water is very full of lime and the bowls have been in operation for fifteen years with some twenty five children in each dormitory.

If the Department will provide the school with four new bowls I shall be pleased to install them at school expense.

Sir;-

I beg to attach herewith a report from the Rev. Principal Hendry, of the Portage la Prairie Residential School, with reference to the purchase of four new lavatory bowls.

I would advise that muriatic acid has been tried on several occasions, and will not break up the lime deposits, without the aid of a chisel, and under this operation the bowl breaks.

Mr Hendry requests the Department to purchase the New Inverted Trap Bowl, as this bowl has a greater clearance, and will not collect the lime deposits so readily.

The cost of this type of bowl is approximately $12.00 each.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 19, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School in which he requests that four new lavatory bowls be supplied for use in the dormitories to replace the present bowls which are badly corroded.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of four new bowls of the new inverted trap type, as requested by the Principal. We note that the cost of these bowls is approximately $12 each, also that the school will install them without expense to this Department.

After these bowls have been supplied, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Form No. 101.
CIVIL SERVICE MUTUAL BENEFIT SOCIETY

Ottawa, January 26, 1929.

Dear Fellow Member:

Upon studying the report attached in duplicate, you will find the Civil Service Mutual Benefit Society has again made the year 1928 one of achievement and progress—particularly in two directions:

(1) By providing a reserve to cover the cost of relief of superannuated members from their premium rates;

(2) By the declaration, notwithstanding the above, of the regular annual bonus addition which if continuously declared unchanged until age 65 would render an average certificate paid up for its full original amount without any further deduction of premiums.

It has taken a little of our surplus assets to help provide these benefits but the provision once made ought to be sufficient, and next year should see our surplus again on the increase. To mark our continued success, a special drive is being made for new members and your share of this effort will be to hand the extra copy of your report to a likely prospect (lady or gentleman), together with a word of explanation and advice.

This having been attended to, come to the annual meeting (see report for place and date) where the movement on foot to make insurance available at $750 or $1000 is to be discussed and encouraged by your presence there those who are carrying on the Society's business in your behalf. The Publicity Committee, who are sending you this circular, while not expressing any opinion as to the desirability or otherwise of the proposed increase in benefits, do particularly stress the importance of obtaining new members on the principle of extending the Society's advantages to the greatest possible number.

Yours truly,

The Publicity Committee.
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE BOARDING SCHOOL.

As usual, everything at this institution was in first-class shape. I have visited this school a number of times and I have never been able to find any room for criticism regarding the manner in which the work is carried on. I went over the outbuildings and everything was in order. In the stable I found a very fine herd of Holstein cows, seven of which were milking and some more were to freshen in a short time, so the children are getting all the milk they require. Both horses and cattle were in the very best of shape, and the stable and surroundings spotlessly clean. An excellent crop was harvested last fall, so the financial standing of the school is in splendid shape. I also visited the classrooms and saw all the children and I must say that I never saw them looking better. They all appeared well and happy and so far, since the holidays there has been practically no sickness of any kind in the school. The building itself is in splendid condition, and the same remark applies to all the machinery around the school, as if anything goes out of order it is immediately repaired. In going through the dormitories I noted that the beds were not in keeping with the rest

-of the-
of the school, and in lifting the mattresses on the beds I found that the springs had been covered by sewing quilts around them. The Principal advised me that this had to be done in order to keep them together. I was then informed that the beds were about thirty years old, and most of them had been brought over from the old school. Mr. Hendry expressed the hope that the Department could see their way clear to supply him with new beds in the near future, and in view of the fact that the Department is put to very little extra expense in connection with this school I would ask that, if at all possible, new beds be supplied. If the Department have not sufficient funds in this year's Estimates, probably they could be furnished after the 31st. March.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report of an inspection of the Indian Residential School at the Portage la Prairie agency, and also the Day School at Swan Lake by Mr. Inspector Christianson.

The Day School at Swan Lake is doing good work and the attendance up to the time of the 'flu epidemic was excellent. An average attendance of 21 and 22 out of an enrollment of 25 is certainly splendid. You will notice that the grounds which were reported to be in rather bad shape at the time of the last inspection have been cleared up and an effort is being made to put a proper fence around the school. I think the Department might authorize them to spend $40.00 with which to purchase the posts required.

It is always pleasing to read a report on the Portage la Prairie Boarding School. This institution is doing first-class work and the Department is fortunate in having a man like Mr. Hendry in charge. It is a credit to the Department. The children are well fed, well clothed and are receiving a first-class training. There is just one matter that I wish to draw your attention to and that is the condition of the beds. It seems to me it would be an encouragement to Mr. Hendry, as well as a pleasant surprise, if the Department were to see fit to supply him with new beds.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
beds. Beds that have been in use for thirty years in an institution of this kind have served their time. I am particularly anxious that this school should always present a good appearance. It is in rather a public place and they always have a number of visitors, and people get a better impression if everything is up-to-date. With your permission I shall take steps to get prices and see what can be done.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 208-11 of the 29th ultimo, enclosing Mr. Inspector Christianson's report on the Fortage la Prairie Indian Residential School. You may purchase new ones, after getting prices from the Simons and Ives Companies, who have branch offices at Winnipeg. It might be advisable to ascertain what size Mr. Hendry would like.
