Form No. 101.
Sir:-

I have your letter of the 6th instant No. 127-1-5, informing me that the sum of $4,000.00 is available for the erection of a Farmer's residence at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, and authorizing me to proceed with the work.

As noted in your letter, I made a request for this building in November, 1927. Nothing was said about this matter during 1928, and when the Estimates for 1929-30 were sent in the request was not repeated. After receiving your letter of the 6th instant informing me that the money was available, I prepared a plan and submitted it to the Rev. Principal and I am surprised to learn from him now that the building is not required at the present time. He states that the two young men on his staff are single, and not likely to be married, and that if the building were put up now it would probably remain idle for two or three years. Of course, under these circumstances it would be absurd to build. Mr. Hendry goes on to say that Mrs. Hendry is in very poor health and that it will be necessary for her to leave the main building before long on account of the constant noise. For this reason he would like to get a Principal's residence at some future date, perhaps next year. I think that a Principal's residence should be erected and that an amount to provide for this should be placed in the Estimates. $4,000.00, of course, would not begin to build a house for the Principal, and I am making a note to have the proper amount inserted in the Estimates.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, in which he requests that six extra desks be supplied to complete seating accommodation.

In reply I have to say that the desks at present in use in the school were manufactured by the Globe Furniture Co. Ltd., Waterloo, Ont. The western agents of this firm are the Western Seating Company, 179 Bannatyne Ave., East, Winnipeg, and you may place an order with this firm to supply 6 single school desks suitable for pupils ages fifteen and sixteen years. Please obtain an account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the desks. The amount charged should include the cost of the desks F.O.B. Portage la Prairie. After these desks have been received at the school, you should certify the account in the usual manner and send it to the Department for payment. Please arrange for the purchase and delivery of the desks at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.
REGINA, SASK. June 28th, 1930.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your wire of the 26th instant which reads as follows,

"Reference Secretary's letter May 13th,
it would appear that without authority
you have prepared for the construction
of a Principal's residence at Portage
stop - Kindly telegraph explanation"

to which I replied by wire as follows,

"Arrangements were made under misapprehension
for construction Principal's residence
Portage but cancelled again five weeks ago
and no subsequent action taken."

As stated in my telegram, no further action was taken in regard to this matter. I was in Portage la Prairie, and at the time I was under the impression that a residence would be built. I had plans in my wallet of a house that I thought would be suitable, and I showed them to the builders. No one was put to any expense, no contract was let, and I do not understand why your telegram was sent.

I may add that there is no place in the country where there is more urgent need of a Principal's residence than at this point, and I am still hoping that the Department will find funds to erect one.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-5, part 4)
Portage la Prairie, Man.
June 23rd., 1930.

Dr. D.A. Scott,
Supt., of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

Dear Doctor:

Since I came back I find a rather extraordinary condition in connection with the house at the Indian School here.

Mr. Graham had apparently made all arrangements for the building and construction of the house, he had a plan for same and called for tenders and the contract has been let for the supply of lumber to the Corona Lumber Company and for the construction of the house to Peter Hancock, and they expected to start work immediately and were ready to move on to the place when they received instructions to hold up staging pending further word from Regina. I think Mr. Graham has been up in the North Country or Lake Winnipeg for the past week. This, however, places us in a very awkward position as both of these parties are reliable insofar as Contracts are concerned, and the Contractor especially has been holding his men for the purpose of going on to this job as he was told it would be done at once. I would appreciate it if you would take this matter up with Mr. Graham with a view to finding out the exact situation, and while I was inclined to
favour non-construction of this building until a detailed plan and specification had been prepared, in view of the labour situation and in view of the fact of the contracts being signed in good faith I am inclined to suggest that they be carried out. You will realize the difficulty it puts me in and if information had been sent to your office as to the exact conditions my viewpoint would have been entirely different. What I was afraid of was the work would be started improperly on day labour without competent supervision and perhaps without proper protection to the Department for costs.

Yours truly,

E. A. McPherson
Ottawa, June 26, 1930

Mr.

Please report on attached letter and return it to the office of the Deputy Superintendent General.

Do not file.
Ottawa, June 27, 1930.

E. A. McPherson, Esq., K.C.,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Indian Commissioner states by wire arrangements made under misapprehension and cancelled five years ago. You will remember our conversation on this subject. I am not in favour of erecting a house unless the plan is approved by Mr. Hendry and the building in keeping with surroundings. I would favour postponing action until next year.

Let me hear from you.

Chge. D.I.A. Duncan C. Scott.

July 21st, 1930.

Sir:

I was recently informed by the Reverend Principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential School that the plumbing in the children's toilets should be repaired also that the steps leading from the children's playrooms to the first floor should also be looked at. I had Mr. Babb, Plumber, Portage la Prairie inspect the plumbing and here-with inclose his report on same. I had Mr. Hancock, Contractor, Portage la Prairie inspect the stairs referred to and his price for the repair including material is $28.00. At the time of my visit, I noticed that the outside porch is in very poor shape, this porch was erected 16 years ago, and I thought it advisable to have the contractor give a price on the material and erection of a new porch. His price for this work is $29.00. I would advise that the stairs are in a dangerous condition and are liable to break down if extra weight is put upon them.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Department of Indian Affairs,

The quotation which you forwarded for the repairing of the children's toilets was also received.

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, February 5, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School requesting to be supplied with 12 gallons paint for use in painting the outbuildings at the school.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of the quantity of paint mentioned next spring, and a certified account, in duplicate, covering the cost should be presented at that time. Our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are entirely assigned, and we cannot authorize the purchase before the time mentioned above. It is considered that it would be more advantageous to have the painting performed in the spring, when weather conditions would be satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.

Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.,
Feb 2nd, 1931.

Duncan C. Scott, L.L.D.,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Dr. Scott:

In reference to our talk about a residence when you were in the West last fall, we have not seen any building that we think compares with Plan No. 472, which was drawn by Mr. Orr for our residence in June, 1922.

We wish to leave the matter with you Dr. Scott. Times are bad with a dismal outlook in the west for the coming months and Mrs. Hendry and myself will gladly join with others in waiting until there is an upward trend in things. It will cost the W.M.S. $700.00 to operate with a residence as it will require a different type of man in the main building from those that I have been engaging for outside work, and there will be the extra expense of coal, water namely.

Until we reach the bottom of this economic mix up we really do not know how much farther we have to go.

With kindest regards from Mrs. Hendry and myself to you.

I am, Very truly yours,

W.A. Hendry

Duncan C. Scott, L.L.D.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,
Feb. 25, 1931.

Dear Mr. Hendry,

I have your letter with reference to the proposed Principal's residence. At this time I cannot say what funds will be available for our building program this summer, but as soon as a decision has been arrived at I will let you know.

With best regards to yourself and Mrs. Hendry.

I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. W. A. Hendry,
Principal,
Portage la Prairie School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM REV. KENNETH J. BEATON, B.A.,
ASSOCIATE SECRETARY, BOARD OF HOME MISSIONS, UNITED
CHURCH OF CANADA, 299 QUEEN ST. WEST, TORONTO, Ont.
dated January 31, 1931

Re PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE

I hope that it may be possible to proceed this year with the building of a Principal's residence. If we are to retain Mr. and Mrs. Hendry in the service of the Church and of the Indian Department, it is going to be necessary to find a separate place of residence for them. Of course, I realize that this will add to the total expense of carrying on the School, as we shall immediately be faced with the necessity of engaging a Matron. However, I am personally quite impressed with the value of Mr. Hendry's services and I am very anxious to retain him if it is at all possible. They have, I think, borne their full share of the burden for us and the Department by their willingness to reside in the school with all the noise and confusion for so many years.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba,
April 15th, 1931.

Sir;

I beg to advise you that the roof of the Portage la Prairie Residential School, is now in such condition that temporary repairs are very necessary, otherwise the water will effect the plaster. This matter was taken up with the Superintendent General, at the time of his visit to the school, also with Mr Inspector Hamilton on his recent visit to the school. The cost of the temporary repair work would be in the neighbourhood of $100.00. Will you please advise in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 21, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, informing the Department that repairs are required to the roof of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School building, the cost of which will be approximately $100.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of the expenditure required, but no unnecessary expense should be incurred, and the total cost should not, if possible, exceed the amount stated above.

After the work has been completed, please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in carrying out temporary repairs.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The junior classroom is separate from the main building, and is a well equipped classroom. Miss Crockett is the teacher in charge, and the grades are as follows:

Grade I - 25
" II - 15

The children do splendid work, and were bright and attentive.

Miss Havard has the senior pupils, and the classroom is in the main part of the building. There are 53 on the roll, and the grades are ranged as follows:

Grade III - 4
" IV - 11
" V - 22
" VI - 10
" VII - 6
Total - 53

These children were well along in their grades, and spoke out clearly. They do excellent writing, and are fairly good in spelling, arithmetic, and English. I consider that Miss Havard is doing good work.

The pupils were all well clothed, and were neat and clean in appearance.

The dormitories were all well aired, and the beds were neatly made. The toilets were all in working order and clean.

The work in the laundry, sewing room, and kitchen is supervised by members of the staff, and I believe the children receive excellent training. The work was in progress in the various departments, and was being done in a quiet
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

a quiet and orderly manner.

The children, I believe, are well fed with plenty of vegetables and meat. They receive puddings made from bread and rice, also stewed fruits, and are given tea to drink, and milk when obtainable. Porridge is served for breakfast.

The fire equipment was in excellent condition, and I was informed by the Principal that fire drill is observed weekly. Water is secured from Portage la Prairie, so that the pressure is good at all times.

The walls are cracked in places, and the plaster is lifting from the lath. This is due to the leaky roof, which allows the rain to penetrate in many places.

...to be remedied for the present, but no doubt will need to be renewed later.

At present only 10 cows are kept, 5 of which were fresh. Due to T.B., it was necessary to dispose of all the cattle at this school, and the present herd was selected wherever possible in order that milk could be provided for the school.

About 100 rock hens are kept. The poultry house is in fair repair, but lacks light. More windows should be provided.

The horses were all in good condition, and considerable feed remained, especially for the cattle. The silo was half full of excellent corn silage.

The outbuildings were all in good repair, and I found the barns and yards tidy.

The school appeared to be well staffed, and the condition of the school and surroundings would indicate that the...
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

that the various members understand their work and are obtaining results.

Mr. Hendry, the Principal, is keen and alert to conditions existing about the school, and is a good manager. I would not, however, overlook Mrs. Hendry, who acts as matron, and to whom, I believe, a large amount of credit is due for the spirit and harmony which exists throughout the building.
Regina, Sask., April 28, 1931.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various schools in the Portage la Prairie and Manitowapah Agencies. This report was made by Mr. Inspector Hamilton, who was occupied from the 25th February to the 11th April in making an inspection of these two agencies.

The Portage la Prairie Residential School is up to its usual standard and good work is being done. The Inspector points out that the walls are cracked in places, and the plaster is lifting from the lath, due to a leaky roof which allows the rain to penetrate. There is nothing in the estimates for repairs excepting $400.00 to repair the verandah. Part or all of this amount might be used to repair the roof, as it is more important that the roof be cared for than the verandah, if only one of the two jobs can be done.

On the whole I would say that the report on these schools is very satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, May 5, 1931.

Sir:

Referring to Mr. Inspector Hamilton's report on the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, forwarded under cover of your No. 205-11 of the 28th ultimo, I have to say that Mr. Agent Waite drew the attention of the Department to the condition of the roof, stating that temporary repairs could be carried out for approximately $100. He was authorized to incur an expenditure not exceeding approximately this amount in repairing the roof in order to prevent damage to the walls and plaster.

Your obedient servant,

A. W. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Residential School,

May 5th, 1931.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Sirs:—

I beg to report that on May 2nd at 10.00 P.M. Miss Wakefield the cook had some grease in a pan in the oven and in some way it caught fire gave considerable trouble. As it happened I was only a short distance but they were going to use water and than the chemical to put it out. In either case they would have done more harm than good. No damage of any account was done, but I feel that if we had a small quart Pyrene chemical which can be used either on oil or wood in case of fire and is light and can be easily handled by the officer in charge would be a very valuable in the kitchen.

I wonder if the Department would give us one of these quart Pyrene to be placed in the kitchen for just such a case as I have related.

I am, Very truly yours,

W. A. Hendry,
Print.

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, May 12, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, reporting a fire which occurred in the kitchen at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, and requesting that a small Pyrene extinguisher be supplied for use in the kitchen.

In reply I have to say that the Department is today placing an order with the Pyrene Mfg. Co. of Canada, Ltd., Toronto, to ship, charges prepaid, addressed to you, 1 - 1½ Quart Pyrene extinguisher, complete with chemical and bracket for hanging same. This type of extinguisher is for use in case of fire occasioned by oils, greases, paints, etc., and is non-freezing.

The above Company are being requested to forward their account, in duplicate, to you covering the cost of the extinguisher F.O.B. Portage la Prairie. When you receive this equipment, if in good condition, you should certify the account in the usual manner and forward it to the Department, in order that payment can be made.

You should see that this extinguisher is placed in the kitchen where it will be easily accessible and ready for immediate use in case of fire.

The Department is pleased to note that the fire reported by you occasioned no serious damage.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. W. A. Hendry,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

During my recent visit to the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, it was noticed that the walls in the boys playroom and several passages are in need of repair, the plaster being loose through the leaking roof. The roof has been satisfactorily repaired and I asked a local painter and decorator to give me a price on the work of repairing and painting. The main hall should be painted and there are a few repairs to the plaster required. The ceilings in two bedrooms and halls should be painted, as the paint on the metal ceiling is peeling. During my visit the Reverend Principal called my attention to some plumbing repairs which are very necessary also a number of repairs to radiators etc. I asked a plumber to give an estimate on the cost of these repairs, the detailed list and estimate of cost is inclosed.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, July 30, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, relative to the repairs and plumbing required at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School and forwarding quotations which you received for carrying out this work. In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of having the repairs required to the plaster carried out. As our funds this year are extremely limited, any painting and redecorating will have to be performed by the school authorities.

With reference to the plumbing repairs and repairs to radiators, as mentioned in the quotations which you forwarded from J. W. Ramsey, I have to request that you will state the more urgent repairs mentioned as being required at the present time. Could not the school authorities themselves do certain of the work? I have to request that you will forward an amended list of the plumbing repairs really urgent and which cannot be attended to by the school authorities themselves and give an estimate of the cost. It is necessary, this year, to limit all expenditure to the carrying out of the most urgent repairs.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. White, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.
St. James, Man. August 4th 1931

Secretary Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir:

We have been doing some work for the General Contractor who is building the buildings for the Department at Portage La Prairie, Man., and since our work has been completed for some little time, we have asked for at least part settlement and have been informed that he has not as yet received his payments on the work and consequently has been holding up the payments to us.

Now we are not anxious for our money particularly but we just want to be sure that we have received the correct information and if Mr. Grey has not received his payments, we are willing to wait until such time as they are made, but in fairness to ourselves and also your department, we consider it advisable to write you at this time.

Perhaps your department will demand a Waiver covering this work before payments are made in full, in which case we will be glad to comply. We have no good reason to doubt the reason Mr. Grey has given us and any information you might care to give us will certainly be appreciated.

Thanking you for this consideration,

Yours very truly,
Phoenix Furnace and Roofing Co.

Dear Sir:—

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, Aug 13th No 37, dealing with repairs for the school.

In reply I would say that we find it very difficult to keep our finances balanced as the farm which used to average a net income of $2000.00 has not more than carried itself for the last three years. With this amount of income short and all the outlay fixed we can no more than carry on. The Church have no money so cannot put more into this work since cutting down all future expansion they cannot keep up the regular work in hand.

I went over the plumbing and cut out every thing that could stand over, only repairs that have to be done if we are to operate the water system were left in the list. This list will be forwarded to you.

We can do the painting if the Department will supply the paint. It will require seven gallons of flat wall paint six gallons of Stone Buff and one gallon of Cream. We prefer the Sherman Williams Flat Wall paint as we seem to be able to work with it and get better results than with some of the others.

I am, Very truly yours,

[Signature]

J. Waite,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.,

Ottawa, May 25, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School regarding the condition of the brickwork of the fireplace in the heating plant, and requesting authority to incur an expenditure of approximately $50 in making the necessary repairs.

In this connection I have to say that in September, 1930, the Department paid an account of $69 in carrying out similar repairs to this heating plant. It is considered that, if the work was properly carried out, it should have lasted for a longer period than in the present case. You should, after consulting the Principal, decide the best arrangement to be made in overcoming the necessity of frequently repairing and renewing the brickwork.

If you are satisfied that the repairs are necessary at the present time, the Department will approve of you arranging to have the work done at a cost not to exceed approximately $50. If a good grade of fire brick is properly installed, there should not be the necessity of any further repairs for a considerable length of time. After the work is completed, proper care should be taken in operating the heating plant. Please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred, in the carrying out of the repairs required.

Your obedient servant,

J. Waite, Esq.,

WINNIPEG, MAN. February 10th, 1933.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, inspected on January 19th & 20th, 1933.

The senior classroom is in the main building and is in charge of Miss R. Havard. The children are arranged in the following grades:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| IV    | 10     |
| V     | 18     |
| VI    | 13     |
| VII   | 11     |

52

The pupils are well along in the various grades and appear to thoroughly understand their work. The exercise books are all well kept and the work neatly set out. The children speak clearly and excellent discipline is maintained. The classroom is large, well lighted, and is kept well ventilated.

The junior classroom is located in a separate building situated some 200 ft. from the main residence. This building is heated by a furnace in the basement and I understand it is quite comfortable, even in the most severe weather. Miss E. Crockett is the teacher in charge, and the grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| Beginners | 13 |
| Grade I | 8 |
| II | 9 |
| III | 9 |

39

Miss Crockett appears greatly interested in her work and I would judge, from her manner and the way she presents the lessons.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-5, part 4)
Portage la Prairie Residential School (Cont'd.)

the lessons, that good results should be obtained.

The children in both classrooms were neatly dressed, especially the girls, and all were clean in appearance.

The kitchen is in the basement of the main building and Miss M. Wakefield is the matron in charge. The food all appeared well prepared and an effort is made to have it served as hot as possible. The meals served for one day during my inspection were as follows:

Breakfast: Porridge, bread, jam, tea & milk.
Dinner: Potatoes, meat & gravy, bread, butter, water & tea.
Supper: Potatoes, bread & jam, biscuits or cake, tea & milk.

The children were given all the bread they desired. I checked over the charts showing the weight of the children each month, and some of them have made excellent gains, which would indicate that they are at least receiving plenty of food.

The laundry is also in the basement of the building. It is well equipped with machinery, all of which appeared to be in excellent condition. Miss Findley is in charge of this department and also looks after the mending of the clothing.

The sewing room is supervised by Miss A. K. Robertson, and in this department the girls are taught to do all kinds of plain sewing and in most cases make all the dresses required.

Miss J. Watson is the nurse and in addition to this work she supervises the care of the dormitories. At the time of my visit there were no children sick.

The dormitories
Portage la Prairie Residential School (Cont'd.)

The dormitories were all well aired and very tidy in appearance. The toilets were in good working order and clean. The beds were neatly made and the bedding clean. The children are provided with nightgowns in which to sleep.

The fire escape from the dormitories is by way of the window, and although these are locked, in case of a fire, it would be a simple matter to break the window and step out on to the fire escape. Fire extinguishers are placed at various points throughout the building, and I understand from the Principal that fire drill is observed from time to time. The weather was very cold on the night I was at the school, consequently I did not ask for a fire drill. This school is fortunately situated, in that they have the same water pressure as the City.

A small herd of holstein cattle is kept, and I found them in excellent condition. The milk supply at the present time is not large, but a number of cows are due to freshen within the next five or six weeks. Hogs are raised, but only sufficient to meet the requirements of the school. Poultry is kept, and I found that they were receiving good attention, with the result that a fair quantity of eggs are being obtained.

The barns and outbuildings are in good repair and, without exception, were clean and tidy.

The root cellar is in the basement of the barn. This I found well supplied with potatoes, cabbages, onions, turnips, and carrots.

Rev. Mr. Hendry
Portage la Prairie Residential School (Cont'd.)

Rev. Mr. Hendry, the principal, is assisted by Mrs. Hendry, who is matron of the school. Undoubtedly this school is well managed, and the children receive excellent care and good training.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.
Ottawa, February 15, 1933.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your 208-11 of the 10th instant, reporting on your recent inspection of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. The Department is pleased to note that conditions generally at this school are satisfactory; that the children are making progress in their classroom work and that the buildings and machinery are clean and tidy and kept in good repair; also that the school is well managed.

Regarding the fire equipment, it is noted that fire extinguishers are placed at various points throughout the building, and that fire drill is observed from time to time. It is also noted that the fire escape from the dormitories is by way of the window and that these are kept locked. These, as well as door exits, must not be locked or sealed in any manner. I would refer you to paragraph four of the instructions to principals of Indian residential schools dated February 5, 1932, copy of which is enclosed herewith for your information. I would request that you draw the attention of the Principal to the Department's instructions regarding the requirements that windows or doors from fire escapes must not be locked.

In all other respects, the Department is pleased with the satisfactory conditions at this school, as set forth in your report.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Sir:

The Department has received the report of the Provincial Boiler Inspector on his recent inspection of the boiler at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. The Inspector states that, while the general condition of the boiler is good, the following work will be required: "Left side wall of firebox should be rebuilt, as brickwork is loose and cracked".

I would request that you take this matter up with the Principal. If only a small expenditure would be required, he might be able to have the work done by the school staff. If, however, it is necessary to engage outside labour, you should forward an estimate of the cost involved in rebuilding the brickwork of the firebox. When the Department receives an estimate of the cost, consideration will be given to authorizing having the work carried out. Our funds are extremely limited, and it is hoped that no large expense will be required.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 29th May 1933, No. 127-1-5, I beg to enclose herewith an estimate of the work required to re-build the brick-work of the boiler at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. I am informed by Mr. Jeffery that this boiler is in very bad condition and that it will need new material in bricks etc. to make this boiler safe for the use of this school.

I will get a further estimate on this work and forward same to the Department. I might say that we had another brick-layer look over this boiler but he is unwilling to give an estimate he would only do this work by the day as he considers he could not give a fair estimate on the work as a lot of it has to be torn down and re-built, and all new material is required.

August 21, 1933.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. BUSKARD,

It will be necessary to carry out considerable repairs to the boiler at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, forwards a quotation which he received from Mr. Jeffery, Portage la Prairie, to furnish all material and perform the labour for the sum of $318.00.

It will be necessary to tear down the side of the boiler to the top of the fire plates and line the firebox and wall with new fire brick and also repair the front arch over the fire doors. Funds are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education. I would request that you inform me whether it will be satisfactory to have this work performed by Mr. H. Jeffery or what other firms in Portage la Prairie should be asked to quote a price. The school is in the federal district of Portage la Prairie.

Deputy Superintendent General.

With further reference to your letter No.127-1-5, of May 29th, 1933, and my letter of the 9th, I request re-brick work at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. I beg to say that I have had Mr. J.W. Rowe go over this boiler and he considers that $20.00 will put this brick work in good condition. Mr. Rowe did some work on this boiler last year and his work was quite satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

J. Weitz
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
August 21, 1933.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD.

It will be necessary to carry out considerable repairs to the boiler at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, forwards a quotation which he received from H. Jeffery, Portage la Prairie, to furnish all material and perform the labour for the sum of $312.00.

It will be necessary to tear down the side of the boiler to the top of the fire plates and line the firebox and wall with new fire brick and also repair the front arch over the fire doors. Funds are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education. I would request that you inform me whether it will be satisfactory to have this work performed by Mr. H. Jeffery or what other firms in Portage la Prairie should be asked to quote a price. The school is in the federal district of Portage la Prairie.

Deputy Superintendent General.
MEMORANDUM

August 28, 1933

Res: Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School

The Minister has approved of the acceptance of the offer of Mr. H. Jeffery, of Portage la Prairie, to furnish all necessary material and labour in connection with the repairs (as mentioned in your memo) required at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, for the sum of $312.00.

George Buskard
Private Secretary.

per
August 30, 1933.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 21st with further reference to the repairs required to the heating boiler at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, in your letter of August 9th you reported that it would cost $125.00 to put this boiler in proper repair. You now state in your letter of the 21st that $20.00 will repair the brickwork. I note that this $20.00 is to repair the brickwork above the firebox to the boiler, whereas in the Boiler Inspector's report of May 16th of this year, he states that the left side wall of the firebox should be rebuilt as the brickwork is loose and cracked.

From the information that you have submitted in your two letters it is difficult for the Department to decide what work is actually required, and what same will cost. I would, therefore, ask you to kindly explain the two quotations submitted, one with your letter of August 9th and the other of August 21st.

I may say that it is desired that the boiler be put in a safe and satisfactory working condition for the winter, but before authorizing any expenditure it will be necessary to know exactly what is required, and the cost of same.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE, MAN.

Memorandum

Mr. Burkard,

I beg to refer to my memorandum of the 21st ultimo, and your reply of the 28th, with reference to the repairs required to the boiler at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

Since this memorandum was written I have received a further letter from the Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie, in which he submits a quotation from Mr. J. W. Ross of Portage la Prairie for necessary repairs similar to those quoted on by Mr. Jeffrey. Mr. Ross's price is $175.00. Will you please advise if Mr. Ross may be employed as his price is lowest.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sept. 20, 1938.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 15th regarding repairs required to the heating boiler at the Portage la Prairie School, I beg to say that Mr. Ross's price should have been obtained at the same time as the work was being quoted on by Mr. Jeffrey. His price is considerably lower, but it is difficult for the Department to authorize work where prices have been obtained in this manner. There is nothing to show that Mr. Ross did not know the figures quoted on by Mr. Jeffrey at the time he was preparing his quotation.

I would, therefore, ask you to obtain new quotations from Mr. Jeffrey and Mr. Ross for the work required, and submit same to the Department as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

September 23rd, 1933.

The Superintendent,
Indian School,
City.

Dear Sir:

Subsequent to my tender of August the 8th, for doing repair work on the boiler at the Indian School, as requested by yourself, I again inspected this job and checked over the work with a view to cutting down on the cost of repair.

I have come to the conclusion that I can reduce my tender, as previously submitted, by $61.00. To do this, I will make use of some of the old material which will cut down the cost of material somewhat, and in addition to this there are some parts of the brick work which can be left, and will no doubt be good for another two or three years without repair. This will effect a saving in labor and material too.

I would submit my tender for doing this repair work to the boiler, substantially as set out in my tender of August the 8th, with the changes as mentioned above, for the sum of $251.00. You might kindly take this under consideration and let me hear from you.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Sir:

Six new lavatory bowls are required for the toilets at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

The bowls are required to replace the original bowls that have been in use since 1915. The cost of the bowls including seats will cost in the neighbourhood of $57.60, the school paying for the cost of installation etc. The price of the bowls was obtained from Mr. Ramez, Plumber, Portage la Prairie, who inspected the work. This work is very necessary and should be done at once. It was anticipated that the lavatories would last until spring, every effort being made to keep them operating, but it was found impossible. Further prices on the bowls will be obtained as soon as authority for their purchase is approved by the Department. A letter received from the Reverend Principal in regard to this work is attached herewith.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

July 14th, 1934.

Re: Kenneth WALTERS, et al., Portage la Prairie, Manitoba. - Alleged shopbreaking & theft (460) from work shop of The Indian Residential School at Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

ACCUSED: Kenneth WALTERS, aged 19, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba, son of Millie Walters, Sioux Indian.

AMES DEMAS, aged 19, Pipestone, Manitoba, son of William Demas, Sioux Indian.

I have to report, acting upon instructions received I proceeded to the City of Winnipeg police Station where I learned that the above named, Kenneth WALTERS and Ames DEMAS, were arrested at about 8 o'clock this morning by Patrolman T. O'MOND with each a sack of tools. They were escorted to the police station and admitted having stolen the tools from the work shop of the Indian Residential School at Portage la Prairie last night and came to Winnipeg to sell them.

The two prisoners were handed over to me and I escorted them to this office. The tools were also taken possession of. The prisoners were finger printed and the prints forwarded on this date.

Sgt. Gelfer, in charge of Portage la Prairie sub/District was communicated with and arrangements were made to have charges laid and an escort sent from there to take the prisoners back to Portage la Prairie.

The following is a list of the tools etc found in the possession of the two accused:

2 hand saws,
1 small hand saw,
1 hack saw,
1 set punch,
1 large cold chisel,
1 pair of tin snips,
1 stiletto wrench,
1 trowel,
3 wood chisels,
1 file and handle,
1 key hole saw,
1 brace & bit,
1 ball pein hammer,
1 scrub brush,
1 Yankee drill,
1 blacksmith's tool,
1 hoof trimmer,
1 emery stone,
1 square,
1 spray gun,
1 pair of new boots,
1 new blue work shirt,
1 overall coat.

Cont. on page No.2.

Fyle numbers must be quoted.

5. Most of these tools are badly worn and I do not consider that the total value is over ten dollars.

6. The prisoners were lodged in the R.C.M.P. cells in Vaughan Street Barracks to await the escort from Portage la Prairie.

NO EXPENSES INCURRED.

Dear Sir -

I have examined the porch
to front entrance of Indian School
and requested and find it in a very
bad condition. The base of both columns
have decayed and broken down
leaving no support to roof.
The railing and pediment on top of porch
have decayed so badly they are falling
down and will have to be replaced.
The turned columns above base are
in fair to good condition. I would suggest
putting a 6x6 post inside columns for
support and forming a cement base
of sufficient height to make up the decayed
portion or if preferred done with wood.
Temporary repairs are out of the question
and to repair and renew the damaged
portions of this porch as I suggest will cost
$48.00. I thought mention that the balconies at
the back are about as bad as this one and
should have attention. Yours Truly
J. Hamilton
Sir:

In reference to my letter No. 37, of the 8th instant, enclosing letter from the Reverend Principal, Portage la Prairie Residential School in connection with some necessary repairs to the balcony of the school, I now beg to enclose a report on this work received this date from Mr J.M. Hamilton, of this City. The letter is self explanatory.

Mr Hamilton mentions that repairs are also very necessary to the rear balconies. I asked him if he could give a price on the repairs he considered very necessary. He advises that the work of getting out specifications for these repairs would be very costly, and should be done by an engineer. He recommend that an Engineer of the Public Works Branch see this repair job.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, September 17, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a report stating the repairs required to the balcony at the front entrance to the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

The Department will approve of the repairs required being carried out, as suggested by Mr. Hamilton, viz.: the installing of a 6" x 6" post inside columns for support and also the installing of a wooden base of sufficient height to make up the decayed portion of the columns. It is considered that wood would be more satisfactory than cement for this purpose. The railing and pediments on top of porch should also be repaired. It is noted that the cost of the repairs and the renewing of the damaged portions of the porch will be approximately $45. You may have the work done as early as it can be arranged, keeping the costs as low as possible. After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Regarding the repairs to the rear balconies, it is considered that it should not be necessary to have specifications prepared for these repairs. It is believed that a competent carpenter could state what is absolutely required at the present time and furnish an estimate of the cost. You might submit an estimate of the repairs absolutely necessary to the rear balcony. Our funds are extremely limited, and it will only be possible to authorize work that is urgent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Form No. 101
Indian Residential School, Portage la Prairie,
February 27th, 1934.

J. Waite, Esq.
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Dear Mr. Waite,

There are two pieces of work which in my judgment ought to be done in the immediate future to bring the equipment of the School here up to standard; and as these would be somewhat in the nature of capital expenditure, I am desirous of placing the facts before the Department through you with a view to requesting a grant to cover the outlay.

I. THE STABLES.

The first is in connection with the stables. The present stable was erected when the farm was only fifty or fifty-five acres and is quite inadequate for the stock now kept much less for any expansion or specializing in stock which might be undertaken. At the present time six horses seven milk cows, a bull, three young cattle and two calves are housed indiscriminately in a space about 40' x 50'.

I do not suggest a new building, but the use of a skeleton extension already erected at one end of this building. It is of the same width as the stable proper and similar in outward appearance, and requires only to be double-lined, floored and stalls erected to make it usable for a portion of the stock. I estimate that the work would require 2250 feet spruce sheeting, 2250 feet four inch fir ceiling, six rolls building paper and fifty sacks of cement. A local lumber merchant quotes the figure of $195 on these items. In addition there would be required material for partitions or stalls making, as I estimate a total of about $250. This would house the stock comfortably and give much better opportunity for doing effective work in this department. The work of equipping the stable with these improvements could be done by the staff with the bigger boys and a very small minimum of additional labor.

II. THE PLAYROOMS.

The second piece of work is the fitting of the two large playrooms with fixed wide benches around the walls. At the present time there is practically nothing for either the boys or girls to sit on, and I find that squatting on the floor in the most primitive fashion tends
to become common. While in charge of the Ahousat School some years ago we fitted the playrooms with fixed wide benches nearly all the way around the walls, and with satisfactory results. They not only afforded comfortable seating, a good chance for organized play and could even be used for reclining or resting at length. The cost is not great and the work of putting them in could be done without any expense. The plank required is quoted by a local dealer at $118, which with the nails or spikes necessary would make the total cost about $120.

I trust that these two proposals will receive favorable consideration and that the Department may see fit to provide a grant covering the cost of the material estimated at a total of $370.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Principal.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba,

March 9, 1935.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Agent Waite, Portage la Prairie, Man., forwards a request from the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, (Federal District of Portage la Prairie) to be supplied with lumber, cement, building paper, nails, and spikes, to complete an extension to the stable, to provide sufficient accommodation for the stock at the school, and also to provide benches around the walls of the two large playrooms in the school building. He estimates the total cost of the material required to be $370. The labour in carrying out the work will be performed by the school staff, without cost to the Department.

There are funds available in the current year's Appropriation, and, provided the purchase can be made before the end of the present month, I would request your approval to incur the expenditure required - the local Indian Agent to obtain prices from firms on the approved list in Portage la Prairie and purchase the material from the firm quoting the lowest price.

Deputy Superintendent General.
March 9, 1935.

Ottawa, March 13, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing a communication you received from the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, requesting that building materials be supplied to complete an extension to the stable and also to provide benches around the walls of the two large playrooms in the school.

In reply I have to say that, provided the purchase can be made and certified accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost, forwarded to reach the Department before April 10th, next, approval is granted for the purchase of the materials, to an amount not to exceed the sum of $270. You should obtain prices from firms on the approved list in Portage la Prairie and purchase the materials from the firms quoting the lowest price.

It is to be understood that the labour will be performed by the school authorities, without cost to the Department. It would be well to consult the Principal as to the materials required. I would request that you give the purchase your prompt attention and have the accounts forwarded to reach the Department by the date mentioned, in order that payment can be made from the current year's appropriation.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.
March 29, 1935.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

The Honourable the Minister, in phone conversation, requested that I forward you a memo, regarding the purchase of lumber and other building material to complete an extension to the stable and provide benches in two of the playrooms in the main building of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

In this connection I would refer you to memorandum of the Deputy Superintendent General dated March 9th, last. In view of the Minister's approval for the expenditure required, Mr. Agent Waite was authorized to obtain prices from firms on the approved list in Portage la Prairie and purchase the materials from the firm quoting the lowest price. Mr. Waite was informed, further, that he should give the matter of the purchase his prompt attention, in order that the accounts covering the cost of the materials could reach the Department in time for payment before our books close for the present fiscal year.

Form No. 101
According to information received from Mr. Sutherland, Director of Indian Education, the Agent at Portage la Prairie purchased the lumber required for certain work at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School from the Corona Lumber Company of Portage.

This Company is not on our purchasing list, and the Minister would like an explanation from the Agent, Mr. Waite, as to why he secured the lumber from this firm when he was given positive instructions to buy the material from firms on the approved list. There are at least two dealers in Portage la Prairie who were in a position to furnish this lumber.

You might also obtain from the Agent a statement as to the extent of the lumber orders placed with the Corona Company during the past twelve months, and the extent of the orders placed for lumber with the firms on the list.

Private Secretary.
Ottawa, April 10, 1935.

Sir:

I have to refer to official letter of the 13th ultimo, relative to the purchase of building materials to complete an extension to the stable and to provide benches around the walls of two large playrooms, at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

An account has been received, showing that the bulk of the materials were purchased from the Corona Lumber Yards, Limited, Portage la Prairie - which company is not on our purchasing list. The Department would like an explanation as to why you secured the lumber from this firm, when you were given definite instructions to buy the material from firms on the approved list. There are at least two dealers in Portage la Prairie on the list, who were in a position to furnish this lumber.

You should also forward a statement as to the extent of the lumber orders placed with the Corona Lumber Yards, Limited, for any departmental purpose during the past 12 months and the extent of the orders placed for lumber with the firms on the approved list.

The Department would appreciate your early reply, explaining why you did not place the business mentioned above with a firm on the approved list, and also giving the other information requested.

Your obedient servant,

JF/GS
June 14th, 1935

Department of Health,
Legislative Building,
WINNIPEG.

Gentlemen:

Our Health Officer, Dr. Gordon, has had some correspondence with your department from year to year in connection with the Indian Industrial School situated just West of the City, draining the septic tanks into Crescent Lake.

The report of your official has always been to the effect that this did not cause anything harmful and was perfectly in order. Personally I was never satisfied that it was, but of course I am not a medical man.

However, at a meeting of the Board of Trade this very matter was brought up by a number of the residents of the City, and they are all complaining very strongly over this practice being continued. Myself I do not think it is right that the Indian School should allow this drainage. Even if it is not harmful to say the least it is not clean in any event, and I know that the citizens do not like it. I would imagine that this School, which is financed I believe by the Dominion Government, should be able to put in a proper sewerage disposal plant so as not to drain into the Lake.

On behalf of the City I am therefore asking that the practice of draining this overflow into Crescent Lake be stopped forthwith.

Yours truly,

"Signed" J.G. Miller
MAYOR

May 18th, 1954

Dr. H.A. Gordon,
Medical Health Officer,
City of Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

Re Indian School—Sewage Treatment and Disposal

In accordance with your letter of request dated May 8th, inspection was made during May 11th, and we desire to state as follows:

The sewage from the building in question is treated in a septic tank and the effluent is discharged into Crescent Lake. Judging by the quality of the effluent, collected over three different periods, the tank was giving satisfactory service. The effluent was comparatively clear, there being only a slight turbidity with faint odor, which disappeared in twenty-four hours.

There are two discharge drains from the plant, one only, being in continuous operation, the other being an auxiliary to care for any stoppage or flooding. The drain or sewer is above the present lake water level and in consequence effluent drips on to the bank and traverses a distance of about ten feet before entering the water. On the intervening area between the water and terminal there is naturally a soaking of the ground and resultant decomposition of the minute flocculent sewage particles on the surface. Odors from this condition were noticeable only in close proximity. As the lake is apparently fed from the Assiniboine River by pumping, it is not certain whether the lake level was higher at the time of the septic tank installation some twenty years ago.

From a general observation of conditions over practically the entire lake shores, there was not any evidence of nuisance or offence due to sewage, decomposing solids, or offensive odors, except the minor conditions referred to at the point of effluent discharge, which would show that the dilution, oxidation, and other natural purifying agencies are more than adequate.

From a public health standpoint there is at present no hazard.

The Lake is, according to information, not used for bathing, boating, nor as a domestic water supply and would not appear to be adversely
affected even as a rendezvous or sanctuary for wild bird life. As the sewage is being treated and not discharged in a raw condition into a body of water there is no infraction of the Regulations.

In conclusion there is no condition, in our opinion, at present, which would warrant any apprehension or be detrimental to the health of the citizens.

Yours very truly,

J. Foggie
CHIEF SANITARY INSPECTOR

JE/GS
June 29, 1936.

Sir:

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant referring to a letter that had been received from the Department of Indian Affairs under date of June 18th with reference to the discharge of sewerage from the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian School into Crescent Lake.

On June 25th, the writer proceeded to Portage la Prairie, looked over the situation at the Indian Residential School and also interviewed the Mayor of the Town, Mr. Joseph Miller. Prior to proceeding to Portage la Prairie, the writer interviewed Mr. Foggie, Chief Sanitary Inspector of the Department of Health and Public Welfare of the Province of Manitoba with reference to the situation.

I was surprised to read in your letter that a complaint had been received from the Department of Health and Public Welfare of the Province of Manitoba, inasmuch as this question of the situation at Portage la Prairie had been discussed with the writer previously and I was of the opinion that the Province of Manitoba officials did not see fit to make any complaint themselves to the Department of Indian Affairs with respect to the situation at Portage la Prairie. In looking over the file in the office of the Department of Health, I noticed that the Department itself makes no complaint with reference to conditions at Portage la Prairie, insofar as the Indian School is concerned but that they merely forwarded a complaint received from the Mayor of the Town of Portage la Prairie.

In discussing the matter with Mayor Miller of Portage la Prairie, he stated that it was inconsistent of the Town to object to the situation at the Indian School, while at the same time the Town of Portage la Prairie was passing all its raw sewage into the Assiniboine untreated. However, a few residents who live possibly a quarter of a mile from the Indian School were quite loud in their complaints about the odor in the early spring and late summer months and the matter had recently been brought up at a Board of Trade Meeting by one of its members who lives in that vicinity. Mayor Miller explained that very few members of the Board of Trade knew anything at all of the situation and the suggestion was passed to him that he write to the Department of Health protesting the situation. He is very anxious that a disposal bed be put in so as to stop the complaints above referred to.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.
I am enclosing with this letter the report by Mr. Foggie, Chief Sanitary Inspector, made to the Medical Health Officer of the City of Portage la Prairie, in connection with the Indian School sewage treatment and disposal situation at Portage la Prairie. I think this report is a complete answer to any complaints that have been received from the Mayor of Portage la Prairie. The writer does not believe that at any time of the year any residents of the town can detect odors from the effluent of the Indian School unless they proceed in close proximity to the outlet.

The Department of Health and Public Welfare of the Province of Manitoba say that it would be very inconsistent on their part to make any representations to the Department of Indian Affairs with respect to improving the sewage disposal situation at the Portage la Prairie Indian School while the Town of Portage la Prairie is such a great offender against the regulations as set forth by the Department. They furthermore state that there is no infraction of the Regulations on the part of the Indian School. Under the circumstances the writer is of the opinion that it is not necessary to carry out any work at the Portage la Prairie Indian School. However, it would be advisable to notify the Principal of the School that annual cleaning out of the septic tank is essential for efficient operation and that the same should be attended to.

If it is still the wish of the Department of Indian Affairs that the source of the complaints from the few residents of Portage la Prairie should be eliminated, it would be possible to construct an underground tile system that would eliminate the offensive odors at the outlet. If a report and estimate of cost of carrying out this work is desired, the same will be given attention upon the request of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

July 25th 1935

Statement of improvements urgently needed.

The flooring, some of the jacks and two of the pillars are rotted and in a dangerous condition as they support the balcony. This should be repaired at once and at the same time the verandah and upper balconies should be screened and fitted with hinged storm sash. Mr Wood has reported the difficulty in heating the building in severe weather, especially on the North-West side, the fitting up of these open balconies will make the building warmer, provide sleeping balconies, and will help the segregation problem.

I have made a careful estimate of this work, including 66 special sashes, special screens, stairs, doors, hardware, flooring, framing, paint, and the services of one carpenter. The school boys will assist in this work. The total cost will not exceed $790.00. May I suggest that the Indian Agent purchase the material from the Corona Lumber Yard, and also pay the carpenter at the rate of 70¢ per hour.

Improvements to the barn.

We have in the barn at the present time 8 horses (2 I have just bought to replace the aged wornout team) 9 cows, 2 steers, 2 calves, 1 bull. All these are in the one stable, this is not desirable, milk cows should not be housed with horses.

It is proposed to fit up the shed at South end of barn for the horses, remove the horse stalls in the cow barn and keep that part exclusively for the cows. At the present time we have not the cows we need to supply for the school; three of the cows are dry, three are poor milkers, and the other three are fairly good. When the pupils return to school we shall require six good milk cows in addition to the present herd, and later I propose to replace the poor milkers in the herd by better stock.

To do this it is absolutely necessary to fit up the barn in a smart and adequate way. To this end I have made careful estimates of materials and costs. The lumber and cement on hand recently purchased is inadequate to the requirements, so my estimate is in addition to the required material on hand.

Additional Lumber ........................................... $23.20
70 sacks of cement ........................................... $5.00
22 yards of gravel @ 2.10 delivered ......................... $46.20
Hugh Winton's tender for skilled labour, use of concrete mixer, putting in cow mangers, stalls, and horse stalls. (Indian Boys assisting) .................................. $71.00
Beatty's tender for 6 additional stanchions and all the necessary fittings, including partitions .................................................. $98.90
Beatty's tender for installing 9 double water bowls, 1 single water bowl, one 567 gallon water tank and piping from tank to water bowls .................. $115.10
This system will supply water in front of the cows all winter, will give the cows water when they need it and thus increase the milk supply.

8 Storm sash .................................................. $24.00

Implement shed.

At the present time the separator is housed in the old barn on the "Stacy Place" this barn is about to fall down. I propose to take it down and use the dimension lumber and boards in building an implement shed 16 feet x 40 ft. This will house the engine and separator, this with the other shed will provide shelter for all our machinery. For this new shed I shall require 2 m ft. of fir siding 1 x 6 .................................................. $104.00
10 m shingles .................................................. $47.50
30 bags of cement for foundation wall ...................... $15.00
6 yards of gravel @ 2.10 delivered ......................... $12.60
Hugh Winton's tender for skilled labour, use of concrete mixer .................................................. $18.00
Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.
June 29th, 1935.

To The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Before my connection with the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School is severed I wish to place before the Department certain features of the present situation which appear to demand immediate attention.

First let me express my personal appreciation of the uniformly courteous and obliging treatment I have received from your local representative, Mr. Waite, during the whole term of my principalship here, and no less of the ready response of the Department to my plea for material for improving stabling conditions and more fully equipping the Boys' and Girls' places in the main building. The grant of $600 provided ample material for the work required, and when it is completed conditions will be greatly improved. I have found the Department in this case, as in former relations with it - ready to accede to every reasonable request, and in all things desirous of providing the best conditions for carrying on the operations of the School.

I have now to direct attention to certain situations arising mainly out of the fact that it is twenty years or more since the main building of this School was erected and that most material things suffer from the lapse of years.

I. The verandahs across the west side of the building from the basement to the third storey, - especially the floors, but, I judge, also the framework - are in need of repair, - if not of replacement. In several places the floors are quite worn through, and very soon might become dangerous to the limbs or even the lives of the children using them. They should be inspected and necessary repair made before another winter.

II. A not less important matter is the condition of the windows, especially on three sides, north, west and south of the main building. They are, without exception so slack in their frames that it becomes increasingly impossible to heat any side of the building if at winter temperatures the wind is directed against that side. For some winters past it has been necessary to pack many of the windows with quilts or other material - a very Indian-like and unsatisfactory method in order to make the dormitories habitable at all. It has even been necessary on occasion to move the children from the side exposed to the wind to the less windy side; and in extreme weather the condition is literally intolerable.

I am advised that there is now available patented metal window strip which can with a minimum of work and expense be fitted to any ordinary window, and will make it practically air-tight. In my judgment there should be no delay in taking some such course with some sixty odd windows of the main building. Without some such provision the building cannot be made reasonably comfortable for staff or pupils next winter.
III. The whole problem of the heating of the main building must be faced in the near future. I am not at the moment suggesting a new system; but pending an investigation of furnace efficiency and review of the system I believe that much help might be derived from some system of ceiling insulation—even with ordinary sawdust. It cannot be doubted that much heat is wasted escaping by way of the old-fashioned brick-and-plaster or patent metal ceilings. I am convinced that ceiling insulation on the second stories the whole length of the building would add measurably to the comfort both of the staff and pupils in coming winters.

The boiler and furnace are both antiquated and much worn, and it may be expected that the boiler inspector one of these years will order their replacement.

IV. Some years ago soft water cisterns for saving the rain water from the roofs for laundry work were constructed, being located in the earth a little distance behind the north end of the main building. They are to all appearance in good shape, but the water they hold has never for any considerable period been available, owing to the fact that there is no connection with the building, or only a connection which does not connect. Without such connection the cisterns are useless. Pipe connection with the building and some means of getting the water into the water heating system used for laundry and bathing should be established at the earliest possible moment. With expert advice on the best method of such connection the cost need not be very great. But most certainly the School should have the use of the soft water which is there;

V. Certain defects in the roofing of the main building are also coming to constitute a real problem. I am informed that the difficulty dates back to the time of a cyclone or severe wind storm a good many years ago which it is alleged strained or warped the tile system so that it has not been possible to avoid serious leaks into several of the staff rooms on the second floor when heavy rains occur. For example during the heavy rain of today (June 29th, 1935) water in pailfuls came down into the senior teacher's room upstairs. An expert inspection of the roof and some repair is urgently needed.

VI. In the matter of farm equipment there is a tractor—a very ancient Rumely Oil-Pull which is still conscripted each fall and made to furnish power for the threshing. It has not, I believe, been used for anything else for some time. The Oil-Pull is out of date and requires constant tinkering, and in my judgment should be replaced by an up-to-date tractor which could be used not only for threshing, but for plowing and other field work and for running a grain crusher or grinder.

There is a grain crusher—a small one—which has not been capable of normal work for several years. Thus it has been necessary that most—almost all—of the grinding and grain chopping for several years has been done at a milling plant downtown (Portage la Prairie) at very considerable cost. If a modern crusher of moderate capacity were installed driven by an up-to-date tractor it would be a real economy.
May I respectfully suggest that some competent person or persons be employed under the Indian agent to report on the conditions referred to, and that steps be taken — very especially in regard to the building repairs necessary, before winter approaches, to meet whatever needs are found to exist.

Very respectfully yours,

Acting Principal.
August 7th, 1935

Portage la Prairie
Manitoba.

CANADA
Ottawa, August 15, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing a communication from the former Acting Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School and also a statement from the present Principal, regarding the improvements and repairs required, with an estimate of the cost.

In this connection I have to say that our Estimates for the current fiscal year provide an appropriation, to the amount of $300.00 only, for general repairs to the above named school. I would request, therefore, that you take up the matter with the Principal and inform the Department of the repairs considered absolutely urgent, stating in detail what work you would advise be carried out and the cost of the material and labour. You should also state what outside labour would be required, in excess of the work that can be carried out by the staff of the school. The total estimated cost of the urgent repairs should not exceed the amount provided, as stated above. It might be advisable to consider the placing of weather strip around the windows and repairing the roof of the main building.

The Department will have no funds to provide the cost of supplying a tractor or a grain crusher or to change the present furnace at the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.
In acknowledging receipt of the above noted letter of the 15th ultimo, I beg to advise that I have been over the repairs suggested by the Department at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. It is my opinion that although the windows are in some respects ill-fitting, this is not altogether the cause of the school being cold. I believe the cold wind comes around the casements, as beside the regular sash, there are two storm windows in addition. The fixing of the casements would be very expensive and could be overcome by the glazing in of the balcony as suggested by Mr. Jones. The roof has not leaked since Mr. Jones took over, although this is an expense that will have to be considered in a year or so's time. The roof was damaged in the cyclone in the year 1923 and has been repaired from time to time. The balcony will have to repaired, otherwise I am afraid serious damage, perhaps involving a number of pupils, may result. The cost of a temporary repair will be in the neighbourhood of $10.00, the staff of the school furnishing the labour. This will only be temporary, and an amount of approximately $790.00 should be spent in completing and improving this balcony next year.

The Principal is purchasing a herd of Jersey cows and the stable should be enlarged to accommodate this herd. The amount required for this, and it should be done before the cold weather sets in, is $154.50. This estimate includes the cost of material, and labour. A further sum of $254.00 should be spent on barn improvements next year.

The Principal feels that money can be saved in the installing of a new furnace, and requests an amount of $180.00 for this purpose. I also believe a saving can be made, as wood fuel in this district is now dearer than coal, and the cheapest kind of coal could be burnt. The installation of a coal furnace may overcome the cold condition of the school to some extent, as the fire would not be in and out, as in
in a wood furnace.

The Principal has done considerable repair work around the school at own expense. He has removed the silo from the Stacey farm to the Home Farm buildings. This will give him considerable more space for ensilage at home. Windows and wire screens have been repaired at a cost of $194.00. In addition a team of horses have been purchased at a cost of $175.00, and a herd of cows at $1750.00.

I beg to recommend that the sum of $300.00 be spent as follows; improvements to barn $155.00, converting furnace from wood burner to coal burner $186.00.

I would also be pleased if the following amounts be placed in Estimates for repairs and improvements next year.

Repairs and improvements to balcony $790.00
" " " " cow barn 254.00
" " " " implement shed 209.00
" " " cistern and new piping 65.00
Paint, varnish etc, interior decorating 75.00

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

Three Hundred Dollars is provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year for carrying out general repairs at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School (Electoral District of Portage la Prairie) Man.

The local Indian Agent, Mr. J. Waite, was requested to advise the Department of the work considered necessary and give an estimate of the cost of material and labour. He recommends as urgent the following work:-

1. Enlarging stable - material and labour - $165.00
2. Converting present furnace from wood-burning to coal burner - $186.00

The Principal is purchasing, without expense to the Department, a herd of Jersey cows, and it is necessary that the stable be enlarged to accommodate this herd.

Regarding the alterations to the furnace, the Agent states that a saving can be made in the use of coal, as wood fuel in the district is now dearer than coal, and the cheapest kind of coal could be burned. He states, further, that the installation of a coal furnace would overcome, to a great extent, the cold condition of the building.

The Principal has done considerable repair work around the school, at his own expense. He has removed the silo to a new site and repaired it, giving more space for ensilage. Windows and wire screens on the main building were repaired and a team of horses and a herd of cows purchased.

I beg to request your approval for an expenditure of approximately $351.00, for supplying material and labour in connection with enlarging the barn and for converting the present furnace from wood to coal burning. I shall be pleased to be advised of the names of the firms from whom the materials for the barn should be purchased and also the name of the firm who should make the alterations to the furnace.

Deputy Superintendent General.
