The Principal is purchasing, without expense to the Department, a herd of Jersey cows, and it is necessary that the stable be enlarged to accommodate this herd.

Regarding the alterations to the furnace, the Agent states that a saving can be made in the use of coal, as wood fuel in the district is now dearer than coal, and the cheapest kind of coal could be burned. He states, further, that the installation of a coal furnace would overcome, to a great extent, the cold condition of the building.

The Principal has done considerable repair work around the school, at his own expense. He has removed the silo to a new site and repaired it, giving more space for ensilage. Windows and wire screens on the main building were repaired and a team of horses and a herd of cows, purchased.

I beg to request your approval for an expenditure of approximately $335.00, for supplying material and labour in connection with enlarging the barn and for converting the present furnace from wood to coal burning. I shall be pleased to be advised of the names of the firms from whom the materials for the barn should be purchased and also the name of the firm who should make the alterations to the furnace.

Deputy Superintendent General.
MEMORANDUM

September 16, 1935.

I am returning your memorandum of the 9th instant, from which you will observe that the Minister has approved of the expenditure of approximately $555 for some work required at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

The Principal might consult Mr. W. H. Burns, of Portage la Prairie, as to the firms from whom the necessary materials should be purchased, and also as to the firm to make the alterations to the furnace.

Private Secretary.
Ottawa, September 18, 1935.

Sir:

I have your No. 37 of the 31st ultimo, regarding the repairs, etc., required at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School and recommending that the sum available in our Appropriation be spent as follows:-

Improvements to Barn - $155.
Converting furnace from wood-burning to coal burner - $186.

The Department will approve of the expenditure in carrying out the above work, to a total cost not exceeding $341. The Honorable the Minister has directed that the Principal consult Mr. J. H. Burns, Portage la Prairie, as to the firms from whom the necessary materials should be purchased and regarding any outside labour required and also as to the firm to make the alterations to the furnace.

It is understood that the greater part of the labour in enlarging the stable will be carried out by the staff of the school, without expense to the Department.

Itemized accounts, in triplicate, should be obtained, covering the cost of the material and for the expense in altering the furnace. These accounts should be attached to proper voucher forms, certified in the usual manner and forwarded for payment.

Besides the above work, it is noted that the balcony of the school building will require temporary repairs, at a cost of approximately $10.00; the staff of the school furnishing the labour. The Department will approve of an expenditure to the above amount in having the temporary repairs carried out.

When our Estimates for the coming fiscal year are being prepared, consideration will be given to including the amount required in carrying out the repairs and improvements to the balcony, cow barn, implement shed, cistern and supplying paint and varnish for interior decorating.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.

Re Truck T-6771

Dear Sirs,

We have been consulted on behalf of Mrs. Lucy Elders who was struck by the above mentioned truck at the corner of Portage and Furby on October 19th. We find that the truck is registered in the name of the Government Indian School at Portage la Prairie. Mrs. Elders suffered severe injuries and is at present in the Winnipeg General Hospital suffering from several fractured bones. We are calling the matter to your attention at this time as the accident may result in a claim against the Department as we assume the Indian School is under your jurisdiction.

Yours truly,

ALLAN LAIRD MAGINNES & MILNE,
Per "M"

Department of Indian Affairs,
4th Floor, Commercial Building,
WINNIPEG.
Sir:

Attached is a copy of a letter received from Allan, Laird, MacInnes & Milne, Barristers, of Winnipeg.

I am requesting Mr. Jones, Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, to submit a report and will forward same as soon as it is received.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.
Nov. 12th 1935.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Dear Sir,-

Further to our conversation re-Inspector Hamilton's inquiry about our Truck T6771 being involved in an accident, I wish to say that this truck (owned by the school management and not by the Indian Department) was taken by my two sons aged 20 and 18 to Winnipeg on the 19th of October. While proceeding along Portage Ave., the above mentioned accident occurred. The boys were in no way to blame as they were proceeding very carefully and slowly at the time. I do not think you require the details of the accident. I only wish to point out that the Department of Indian Affairs do not own the Truck, therefore are in no way responsible for the accident. I am going to visit the injured lady this week and will call on Mr. Hamilton while in Winnipeg.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) Joseph Jones
Principal
Sir:-

Further to my letter of the 12th instant, I now enclose copy of a letter from Mr. Jones, Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, regarding the accident in which the school truck was involved.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Sir:

I have been in conversation with the Rev. Mr. Jones, Principal of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, and he is very uneasy in connection with the fire hazard at this school. We are fortunate in having the City water pressure, but the building is old and, if a fire started, I doubt if it could be checked. Mr. Jones asked if the Department would supply him with the services of a night watchman during the winter months. He would be quite prepared to carry this out himself, but unfortunately his finances will not permit it. The services of a suitable man will cost from 25 to 30 dollars per month.

I am quite prepared to recommend that this be granted, but I would much prefer if the Department would also install a proper punch clock. My experience has been that a night watchman is not much good unless we have some means of checking on his time. The money involved in connection with this matter is not great for the satisfaction obtained and I am quite sure the extra precaution would justify the expense.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, November 20, 1935.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letters of the 12th and 13th instant, with reference to the truck of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School being involved in an accident in Winnipeg on the 19th ultimo.

This truck is not the property of the Department, and, therefore, we are not liable for any claim that may be made for damages. It is noted from the copy of the Principal's letter dated November 12th that he realizes that the school management are responsible for any damages that may have occurred.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.
Ottawa, November 20, 1935.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant, you may inform the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential School that the Department will allow a grant of $30 a month for the period December 9th, 1935, to March 31st, 1936, in order that he may engage the services of a night watchman.

A voucher should be forwarded by Mr. Agent Waite at the end of each month. This voucher should be prepared in a similar manner to the one enclosed.

Owing to lack of funds, the Department is not prepared to purchase a watchman's clock at the present time. Before signing the voucher at the end of each month, the Indian Agent should assure himself that the night watchman's duties have been properly performed.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.
Indian Residential School,
Portage-la-Prairie,
Man.,
Nov. 9th 1935

Mr J. Waite,
Indian Agent,
Portage-la-Prairie,

Dear Sir,- We are in need of beds and Mattresses. At present we have to put two children in one bed which is an undesirable arrangement. When I took charge in July we checked over every bed and found that many of the mattresses had to be destroyed, also many of the springs were beyond repair. With the admission of new pupils we require increased bed accommodation.

10 single bedsteads (smallest size)
20 Mattresses to fit the above bedsteads.
3 Doz. Pillows.

I shall be grateful if the Department could supply the above as early as possible, it is impossible to purchase these from my grant as I have had to spend considerable sums to improve and equip this institution.

Yours sincerely

Joseph Jones
Principal

- Pillows - $1.50 each

Your obedient servant,

Form No. 518
February 12, 1936.

His Worship, the Mayor,
City of Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

Your Worship:

I have had some complaints from people living in the west end of our City in regard to the very foul odor coming from the effluent from the septic tanks at the Indian School. It is evident that something radical has gone wrong with these septic tanks and it would appear to me that they have not been attended to for some considerable time. As there is considerable effluent from these septic tanks they should be cleaned out at least once a year in order to keep them operating as they should. I happened, on several occasions, to watch the construction of these tanks and, in my opinion, they were properly constructed and should be efficient if they are properly attended to.

I would suggest that you take this matter up both with the Health authorities of the province and with the Minister of Health at Ottawa. I believe the Dominion authorities are responsible for the proper care of these septic tanks, or the Department of Indian Affairs, and I would strongly recommend that prompt action be taken in order to clear the matter up as it is a very great nuisance and is bound to be detrimental to health, particularly when the Spring opens up. As the Institution is outside the Corporation of our City I would think that we had no direct jurisdiction in the matter but as the effluent is delivered into our lake it may affect the health of the citizens unfavorably and therefore should be rectified. I am sending the original and four copies of this letter so that you will have one on file and the others can be forwarded to the proper authorities.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Yours obediently,

HAG:KGM

Feb. 26th 1936

A.F. MacKenzie, Esq.
Secretary,
Department Of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir,

The sewage disposal system of this school has not been working satisfactorily for some years past and many complaints have been made about the odour from the septic tank and the outlet into Crescent Lake.

Mr Foggie of the Department of Health for the Province of Manitoba was here last week in response to the above complaints. We went into the whole matter thoroughly and he recommends a larger septic tank and a chlorine treatment to the liquid before discharge into the Lake. This chlorine system would involve considerable additional expense for construction and yearly maintenance.

I have consulted with Mr Porter (the Engineer for the City of Portage-la-Prairie) on this sewage problem; he agrees with Mr Foggie that our present system is unsatisfactory and inadequate and ought to be replaced with a larger system as early as possible.

When I took charge last July I was informed of the constant trouble with the sewage disposal. I had the tank cleaned out, the tree traps cleaned, and excavated to the outlet drain and uncovered the tank. Since then we have had to pump out the tank nine times, the drain has been plugged between the school and the tank and between the tank and the outlet. Not having the necessary equipment to release the obstructions Mr Porter has kindly loaned the City equipment and sent along two men who are used to this kind of work.

Not having any plans of the present system I have traced out the tank and drains and enclose a sketch of the same.

May I respectfully ask for your early consideration to this important problem.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones
Principal

March 5, 1936.

Memorandum: Mr. Jackson.

Referring to your memorandum of the 23rd ultimo with regard to the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, I would say that complaints were received last year regarding this system and an investigation was carried out, at the request of the Department, by Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water Power Branch in Winnipeg.

Mr. Gow advised that: - "The Department of Health and Public Welfare of the Province of Manitoba say that it would be very inconsistent on their part to make any representations to the Department of Indian Affairs with respect to improving the sewage disposal situation at the Portage la Prairie Indian School while the Town of Portage la Prairie is such a great offender against the regulations as set forth by the Department. They furthermore state that there is no infraction of the Regulations on the part of the Indian School."

Mr. Gow then states that in his opinion it is not necessary to carry out any work at the School except the annual cleaning out of the septic tank, in order to ensure its efficient operation. This report was dated June 29, 1935.

I am again, however, asking Mr. Gow for a further report in case there have been some new developments since that time.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Form No. 518
REPORT OF SPECIAL INSPECTION.

February 21st, 1936.

PREMISES: Indian School (Sewage Treatment Disposal Plant).

LOCATION: Rural Municipality of Portage la Prairie.

COMPLAINT: Alleged offensive odors from septic tank, due to improper care or functioning (See letter from Dr. Gordon, M.H.O., City of Portage la Prairie). See previous reports 1934-35.

Following receipt of information, by telephone, from Dr. F. W. Jackson, Deputy Minister of Health, I proceeded to Portage la Prairie at 11 p.m. via C.P.R.

Inspection was made on the above date, conditions noted, and the situation discussed with Mr. J. Jones, Superintendent of the School.

From information received it would appear that the sewage disposal system had failed to function on four occasions this winter, resulting in sewage backing up through the traps in the basement floor of the building. In order to remedy conditions assistance was asked from the City of Portage la Prairie, and a diaphragm pump was provided to pump out the contents of the septic tank. No definite cause was given for the choking, and at time of inspection no trouble was being experienced.

Failure of the system may have been due to a number of causes, namely - careless or improper use of the main house drain, due to entrance of some object, entrance of soil into the house drain through a defective joint or break, accumulation of sludge or solids in the tank sufficient to prevent entrance of sewage, freezing of the main drain due to leaky fixture traps providing a thin film of cold water, combined with an extreme frost penetration and freezing, choking of the septic tank outlet or drain. This latter suggested cause was not evidently a factor as water poured into the drain was discharged to the lake. Observation of the residue left after pumping out the tank contents shows that a small amount of sludge had been present.

It is now suggested that the septic tank is too small for the load imposed, the design being originally for some 60 persons. There are at the present time 115 persons including staff. No plans are, or have been, available to show dimensions or capacity, the local federal authorities in Winnipeg have no such data. There may be some truth in the idea that the tank is too small but no additions have been made to the building, and it is likely that those who designed the tank would provide capacity for full occupation. After more than twenty years of service it is possible that certain drain or other repairs may be required.

Prior to the present superintendent taking over duties in July 1935, investigation showed that the system was giving satisfactory service, judging by the quality of the effluent, a sample of which we still have. At that time the tank was being cleaned not frequently, several times each year, a procedure which should not be necessary as a general rule.

ODORS:

During previous inspections no grossly offensive condition was ever noted, except in close proximity to the point of discharge on to the lake bank. Occasionally there will be from any such system a sudden discharge.
of gas from decomposing solids, and in this particular job a wooden vent elevated to a height of about twelve feet above the tank and within 30 - 40 feet from the roadway will provide exit. Persons passing by, driving or on foot, will immediately become aware of the offensive odors and naturally register objection, and suggest danger to the public health based on the old miasmatic theory.

Owing to the distance between the school and the nearest house or residence within the City of Portage la Prairie, I question if any house owner or occupier has ever noticed objectionable sewage odors from this site.

It may be well to mention that during the recent cleaning and plumping operations, offensive odors would be noticeable at a considerable distance, due to the discharge and spread of highly septic sewage. At time of inspection there was a distinct odor noticeable; its magnitude being due, in my opinion, mainly to the recent cleaning and covering of the ground surface. On approach and in leaving the premises no odor was noticeable from the roadway.

Complaints have been received on several occasions, mainly about discharge of tank effluent into Crescent Lake. As previous reports will show I have repeatedly denied existence of any hazard to the public health insofar as the lake was concerned, because this artificial body of water is not used as a domestic water supply nor for bathing purposes. Periodic filling is from the Assiniboine, a water already sewage polluted, combined with the facts that part of the raw sewage of the City of Portage la Prairie was discharged into the Lake within the limits, a condition corrected since October 1935, and finally the discharge of raw sewage into the Assiniboine River from the City, creating a definite and obvious hazard to those downstream who, by force of circumstances, are obliged to use river water for domestic purposes.

REMEDIAL MEASURES.

In order that any defect be corrected in the drainage system, and whether or not the septic tank is of sufficient capacity, I would recommend that the federal authorities make a survey and carry out any necessary changes or repairs. The elevated vent mentioned might be dispensed with its function meantime being as a periodic disseminator of odors close to the main roadway. Venting should be through the tanks along the main drain and up through the soil stack or stacks to the roof. At this elevation, odors are less likely to cause offense. Definite printed instructions concerning the care of the septic tank system should then be provided for the use of those in charge of the building.

Such measures, if attended to, will tend to remove trouble in future, but provide no guarantee of any change in so far as the effluent and Lake are concerned, no matter how well designed a septic tank may be or how apparently well the scheme functions. There is a desire apparently to change the final method of disposal and a field tile system has been suggested. As the existing depth of the outlet around eleven or twelve feet, a disposal system is out of the question. A collecting tank, automatically controlled pump, and shallow field disposal system would be necessary. For a job of this size I do not recommend such a system. Filtering before discharge into the lake would be of little value and probably increase the possibilities of offensive odors.

The cleanest and most efficient method of treating the effluent before discharge into the lake is by the application of chlorine. This treatment will not only prevent offensive odors, but may be arranged to
give complete sterilization. Initial cost of specially insulated housing, water supply, and chlorinator would be the greatest expense. The amount of chlorine required would not be very great.

In conclusion it is well to note that the City of Portage la Prairie has now ceased to discharge raw sewage into the Lake; this alters to some extent the question of the Indian School, but I would not, in my official capacity, insist on chlorination at present nor until the City of Brandon and the City of Portage la Prairie have adequate sewage treatment systems in use, and no longer continue to pollute the Assiniboine, on which Crescent Lake is dependent for its supply.

Chief Sanitary Inspector.

Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School (United), Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, inspected March 5th, 1936.

The senior room is in charge of Mr. S. Bailey, who at present is sick. A qualified teacher is substituting. The grades are as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| IV    | 10     |
| V     | 9      |
| VI    | 18     |
| VII   | 9      |

45

The pupils speak out well and do very neat work. I consider they are making good progress and are fairly well along in their respective grades.

The junior room is supervised by Mrs. Billyard, who is a qualified teacher. The roll calls for 52, arranged in the following grades:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 31     |
| II    | 17     |
| III   | 4      |

52

It will be noted that the beginners, or Grade I class, is large and I can assure the Department it certainly keeps one on the move with 52 small children. The teacher is alert and is, I believe, doing excellent work.

The pupils were all neatly dressed and clean.

I was especially pleased with the well combed heads of hair.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
hair, which, in all cases, appeared to be clean. The pupils are not timid, but good discipline is maintained in both rooms.

The sewing room is supervised by Miss Robertson. They have recently received three new sewing machines which will greatly help in speeding up the work. At present there are 96 pupils enrolled and this naturally necessitates a lot of sewing and patching. The work is well done and the girls appeared to enjoy themselves.

The laundry is in the basement and well equipped with the necessary machinery. Miss Findlay is in charge of this department. The soft water reservoir is underground, outside the building, and I understand has been out of use for some time. The connections are broken, no doubt due to the frost. During the summer, this should be given a thorough overhauling and put in good condition as soft water is most essential for washing. The machinery I believe to be in good condition.

The kitchen is supervised by Miss Desell and apparently is under good management. The children are well fed and appear to be in splendid health. I have never yet received a complaint in respect to the kind or quantity of food served at this school.

The dispensary and infirmary is in charge of Nurse Hull. Mr. Jones, the Principal, claims she renders good service and is especially helpful in Girl Guide work.

The dormitories were clean and the beds neatly made. All four rooms are full; in fact, it would be difficult to put in more beds and have any passage-way or space.
or space between beds. There are 98 pupils in residence; one quite sick, and I understand suffering from T.B., is isolated in the infirmary. Mr. Jones states he wants his allotted number increased from 90 to 100. However, before this is granted, I think the cubic feet of air in each dormitory should be carefully checked. I think, rather than overcrowd the pupils, it would be much better to allow some to attend Brandon School where there is plenty of room. Both schools are supervised by the United Church and consequently no difficulty should arise.

The fire escapes were all in good condition and fire extinguishers placed in prominent places throughout the building. Water is supplied from the City, consequently there is always good pressure. The night watchman is much appreciated and a punch clock was installed by the Principal.

The furnace room was clean and everything in good condition. Mr. Dunfield is fireman in the winter and gardener in the summer.

Mrs. Jones, wife of the Principal, is matron of the school.

The barn and outbuildings are all in good repair. Mr. Jones altered the interior of the stock barn and made more room for his cattle.

He purchased 21 purebred jersey cows and I found these in excellent condition. The whole milk is used for the children and for cooking. Butter is purchased from the City.

They now have 6 horses. Recently a new team was purchased at a cost of $400. They are of percheron breed.
breed and in excellent condition.

Mr. Jones is a splendid carpenter and is anxious to obtain a shop where the boys can be taught this very useful trade. If funds can be found, I would like to see a suitable building erected and a quantity of tools supplied. Instructions in carpentry and blacksmithing would be of value to all Indian boys and I believe Mr. Jones is very thorough in his work.

There is a good spirit prevailing throughout the school and the children seem to be very happy. Mr. Jones is greatly interested in his pupils and appears to be a hard worker. I consider the general management of the school quite good.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.
Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School (United), Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, inspected March 5th, 1936.

The senior room is in charge of Mr. S. Bailey, who at present is sick. A qualified teacher is substituting. The grades are as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| IV    | 10     |
| V     | 9      |
| VI    | 15     |
| VII   | 9      |

43

The pupils speak out well and do very neat work. I consider they are making good progress and are fairly well along in their respective grades.

The junior room is supervised by Mrs. Billyard, who is a qualified teacher. The roll calls for 52, arranged in the following grades:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 31     |
| II    | 17     |
| III   | 4      |

52

It will be noted that the beginners, or Grade I class, is large and I can assure the Department it certainly keeps one on the move with 52 small children. The teacher is alert and is, I believe, doing excellent work.

The pupils were all neatly dressed and clean.

I was especially pleased with the well combed heads of hair.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
hair, which, in all cases, appeared to be clean. The pupils are not timid, but good discipline is maintained in both rooms.

The sewing room is supervised by Miss Robertson. They have recently received three new sewing machines which will greatly help in speeding up the work. At present there are 98 pupils enrolled and this naturally necessitates a lot of sewing and patching. The work is well done and the girls appeared to enjoy themselves.

The laundry is in the basement and well equipped with the necessary machinery. Miss Findlay is in charge of this department. The soft water reservoir is underground, outside the building, and I understand has been out of use for some time. The connections are broken, no doubt due to the frost. During the summer, this should be given a thorough overhauling and put in good condition as soft water is most essential for washing. The machinery I believe to be in good condition.

The kitchen is supervised by Miss Dezell and apparently is under good management. The children are well fed and appear to be in splendid health. I have never yet received a complaint in respect to the kind or quantity of food served at this school.

The dispensary and infirmary is in charge of Nurse Hull. Mr. Jones, the Principal, claims she renders good service and is especially helpful in Girl Guide work.

The dormitories were clean and the beds neatly made. All four rooms are full; in fact, it would be difficult to put in more beds and have any passage-way or space.
or space between beds. There are 98 pupils in residence; one quite sick, and I understand suffering from T.B., is isolated in the infirmary. Mr. Jones states he wants his allotted number increased from 90 to 100. However, before this is granted, I think the cubic feet of air in each dormitory should be carefully checked. I think, rather than overcrowd the pupils, it would be much better to allow some to attend Brandon School where there is plenty of room. Both schools are supervised by the United Church and consequently no difficulty should arise.

The fire escapes were all in good condition and fire extinguishers placed in prominent places throughout the building. Water is supplied from the City, consequently there is always good pressure. The night watchman is much appreciated and a punch clock was installed by the Principal.

The furnace room was clean and everything in good condition. Mr. Dunfield is fireman in the winter and gardener in the summer.

Mrs. Jones, wife of the Principal, is Matron of the school.

The barn and outbuildings are all in good repair. Mr. Jones altered the interior of the stock barn and made more room for his cattle.

breed and in excellent condition.

There is a good spirit prevailing throughout the school and the children seem to be very happy. Mr. Jones is greatly interested in his pupils and appears to be a hard worker. I consider the general management of the school quite good.

EXD.

Ottawa, March 17, 1836.

Dear Sir:

I have your 208-11 of the 11th instant, reporting on your inspection of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

The Department is pleased to note that general conditions at this school are satisfactory, that the pupils are making progress in their studies, are well fed and in splendid health, and that the building is kept in a cleanly condition.

Regarding the condition of the soft water reservoir, outside the building, which has not been in use for some time, owing to broken connections, the matter of repairs should be brought to the attention of the Department next summer. Information should be given concerning the work required and the cost.

Relative to the request of the Principal, that a grant be provided for an increase in pupilage, from 90 to 100, I have to say that, when our Estimates were being prepared for the coming fiscal year, definite instructions were received that no increase in pupilage at residential schools could be provided. It will therefore not be possible to make an increase during the coming fiscal year in the pupilage at this school.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.
March 11, 1936.

Sir:

I have for attention your letter of March 7th with enclosure relating to complaints being made by the Town of Portage la Prairie regarding the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian School.

Following my report of last June re this matter, I was informed by Mr. J. Foggie, Chief Sanitary Inspector, Department of Health and Public Welfare of the Province of Manitoba, that as a result of further investigations carried out by himself, he had ascertained that the Town of Portage la Prairie had a 12" overflow sewer discharging into Crescent Lake and that at times large quantities of raw sewage was being discharged into the lake. Such being the case the Town's complaints about the effluent from the septic tank, one year ago, were rather out of place.

Last autumn the Town of Portage la Prairie completed a secondary branch sewer that enabled the town to discontinue dumping sewage into Crescent Lake and probably the officials consider that their protests are now more in order. However, the writer does not consider that the town has any grounds for complaint as long as they continue to outlet all of their raw sewage into the Assiniboine River contrary to the regulations of the Manitoba Department of Health.

I have discussed the situation with Mr. Foggie since the receipt of your letter and we also discussed the matter of these complaints two or three weeks ago. The attitude of the Chief Sanitary Inspector is that the septic tanks are sufficiently large, that they are operating efficiently, that the sewage disposal plant meets with the requirements of the Manitoba Department of Health and that there is little ground for complaint and that as long as the Provincial Government permits the Town of Portage la Prairie to dump its raw sewage into the Assiniboine River, it would be most inconsistent for the Provincial Government to make any representations to the Dominion Government about the discharging of the effluent from the septic tank of the Indian School into Crescent Lake.

In view of the fact that the Manitoba Department of Health have on several recent occasions investigated the complaints regarding the sewage disposal system at the Indian School and have found no reasonable grounds for such complaints, the writer is of the opinion that there is no need for the Department of Indian Affairs to consider any extensions or alterations to the existing system. However, I would again draw to the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs, the necessity of having the septic tanks

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6273, file 583-5, part 5)
at all Indian Schools cleaned out frequently. The writer has found from visiting several of these schools, that this matter is frequently neglected. As a result the septic tanks frequently fail to give the efficient results that are possible and accordingly become the source of complaints from near-by residents.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.
In further reference to your letter of the 3rd instant regarding complaints made by the City of Portage la Prairie, with reference to the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian School, I enclose herewith, a letter received from Mr. Gow, dated the 11th instant covering this matter. His conclusion is that the City has at present no reasonable grounds for complaint but he suggests that the septic tank should be cleaned out at regular intervals.

Your obedient servant,

J.T. Johnston,
Director.

A.F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

RUSH.

April 1st, 1936.

Dr. McGill,

Will you kindly advise if it is the intention to do any repairing to the plumbing of the Indian School at Portage la Prairie in the near future. You might also let me know if it is the intention to do any painting.

If a painter is required Mr. Thomas Curtis, of Portage la Prairie, should be employed.

Private Secretary.
April 2, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

I have the memorandum of Mr. Pratt, Private Secretary, of the first instant, requesting to be advised if it is intended, in the near future, to carry out any repairing to the plumbing and any painting at the Indian School at Portage la Prairie.

It is intended to carry out the following work at this school during the coming summer - funds for the purpose being provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education:

Repairs to balcony of school building - $800.
Repairs to cow barn and implement shed - $475.
Painting and interior decorating, main school building - $100.

Besides, it will be necessary to do a small amount of plumbing in repairing the broken connections of the soft water reservoir, outside the building. It is planned that the above work will be carried out during the summer holiday period.

I have noted that, when the services of a painter are required, Mr. Thomas Curtis, Portage la Prairie, should be employed.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, April 3, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge, with thanks, receipt of your letter of the 13th ultimo, enclosing the communication received from your Mr. Gow, regarding complaints made by the City of Portage la Prairie, with reference to the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. It is noted he considers that the city has at present no reasonable grounds for complaint.

This Department is instructing the local Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, to see that the Principal of the School has the septic tank cleaned out at regular intervals.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Director,

Hydrometric Bureau,

EX'D.

Ottawa, April 3rd, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department has received the report of Mr. D. B. Gow, Acting District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, Winnipeg, on his investigation into the complaint, made by the city of Portage la Prairie, regarding the condition of the septic tank at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School. Mr. Gow states that the attitude of the Chief Sanitary Inspector, Department of Health, is that the septic tanks are sufficiently large, that they are operating efficiently, that the sewage disposal plant meets with the requirements of the Manitoba Department of Health, and that there is little ground for complaint. Mr. Gow is of opinion that there is no need for the Department to consider any extensions or alterations to the existing system.

Mr. Gow draws attention, however, to the necessity of having the septic tank cleaned out frequently. He states that, by neglecting to have this done, the septic tank fails to give the efficient results that are possible and, accordingly, becomes a source of complaints from nearby residents.

I have to request that you will inform the Principal that he is expected to see that every attention is given in the operation of the septic tank and that it is frequently cleaned. It is considered that this work should be done by the school, without expense to the Department.

Yours truly,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.

April 10th 1936

The Rev. Mr. Jones,
Indian School, City.

Dear Sir,

According to your instructions I submit the following prices for proposed work at the School.

No. 1 To supply three water fronts for kitchen range.
1. 115 Gallon (Imperial) Range boiler & Stand.
Boiler to be extra heavy, tapped 1½", 24" in diameter and 72" high. To connect the three water fronts to this boiler and arrange the piping so as to supply the kitchen with hot water first and to be residue if not needed into the general supply. I agree to supply above material and all necessary pipe, fittings and labour for this work and to leave everything connected up in good shape and ready for use for the sum of One hundred and eighty eight dollars ($188.00).

There is a lot of work connected with this job as Gurney informs me that the water fronts will have to be fitted and there are no holes for them in the range which will mean moving it out. Please notice that the boiler is 24½ x 72 and contains 115 Imperial gallons. This is not the same as the old 100 gallon boiler which is now called #100 and only holds 77 Imperial gallons. 58" x 22".

I have been thinking over using the tank in the dairy but I do not think you would get enough heat from the stove to make it really hot so you would only be getting warm water.

No. 2 To changing small steam boiler into water heater. To supply all material and labour to enlarge openings in boiler and connect up to hot water system for the sum of fifty four dollars ($54.00). This includes the two 2" gate valves we spoke of using. If these are not needed deduct $12.00. We must remember in using the steam boiler that the flues would have to be cleaned at least twice a week and the smoke pipe would have to be arranged so as to be easily removed.

No. 3 To supply material and labour for replacing heating coil in boiler and to take out old coil and replace for the sum of thirty dollars ($30.00).

Hoping to receive instructions to go ahead with the work.

I am

Yours very truly,

(Signed) J.W. Ramez
J.W. Ramez, Plumber & Fitter.
The attached letter was received from the Reverend Principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential School this date. On receipt of the letter I immediately proceeded to the school and inspected the hot water system.

The water for the laundry, baths, and ablution basins has been heated by a small jacket heater in the basement. The heater is very old and is now beyond repair.

The hot water used in the kitchen is from pans heated on the cook stove.

The reservoir tank of the jacket heater is also warmed by pipes through the flue of the heating furnace, the pipes being a supplementary heating system to the jacket heater.

There is a steam boiler in the laundry which has not been used for a number of years, for the reason stated in Mr. Jones' letter. The suggestion is that this boiler be moved to the basement to replace the jacket heater, which should be scrapped. The cost of moving the boiler, and the additional labour of enlarging the openings to make it adaptable for a water heater would be $54.00. The two 2" Gate valves would be required. Item No. 2 of the attached estimate.

The coil through the flue of the heating furnace is corroded and full of a lime deposit, and will have to be renewed. The estimated cost of this work is $30.00. As previously stated, this coil forms an additional heating system for the reservoir tank, and could eliminate the use of the steam boiler (the one to be moved) except on those days when additional hot water is required for laundry and bathing. Item No. 3 of estimate.

The cost of a range boiler and stand, including water fronts, labour etc., is estimated in Item No. 1. at $188.00. At the present time there is a small boiler attached to the cook stove with a capacity of about 40 gallons. The pipes to this are burnt out, and the boiler is only large enough for an ordinary household. There is no doubt that to have a very necessary supply of hot water on hand in the kitchen at all times a larger boiler should be installed. The heating of water in pans on the cook stove is not only inadequate but very dangerous.

The estimate enclosed was asked for by the Reverend

Reverend

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa
Reverend Principal from Mr. J.W. Ramez of Portage la Prairie. The work asked for by the Principal is, I consider very necessary and urgent. It would also be cheaply installed and also furnish an adequate supply of hot water at all times. If the Department approve of this work other estimates could be obtained from plumbers in the City of Portage la Prairie if necessary.

Will you kindly advise in this matter at your earliest convenience as at the present time the school is without hot water for laundry and bathing purposes.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Enc. 2
Indian Residential School,
Portage-la-Prairie,
Man.

April 20th 1936

A.M. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

May I call your attention to the lack of an adequate method of heating water in this school.

The only method that has been in use is a small jacket heater made of cast iron, a little over a year ago Mr Wood had to send it away to be welded, one month ago it began to leak again and I called in the plumber who stopped the leak with iron cement, it is now leaking in another place. Due to the accumulation of scale in the cast heater the circulation has been retarded and the heater has become useless.

The coils in the heating furnace have been of no use for some years now, they are full of scale so there is no circulation of water.

The Kitchen Range is not fitted with coils, this range has three fire boxes and if fitted with coils would give a good supply of hot water for kitchen use. At the present time the water has to be heated in pans on the top of the stove.

When the Laundry was first equipped it was intended to use a steam boiler for heating the water, but this would involve engaging a certified steam engineer, which evidently was considered too expensive. This steam boiler is standing in the laundry having never been used except to test it. I propose to move it to the basement and use it as a hot water heater.

I am enclosing an estimate of the cost of these three suggested changes.

I shall be pleased if you will give this your early consideration.

Yours sincerely

Joseph Jones
Principal
